PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 3 December.

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee is considering the Native Title Amendment Bill and amendments 253A, 253B, 253C and 253D moved by Senator Bolkus for the opposition in relation to topic 21, the miscellaneous group. The question is that the amendments be agreed to.

—Very briefly, these Senate amendments give the capacity to the Federal Court to send matters to the National Native Title Tribunal, as opposed to a state one, where the court deems it appropriate. We had the debate last night pretty extensively. We were about to take a vote when Senator Minchin called time out. It was two minutes early, but there were reasons for that. I think we can put this one to a vote.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wanted to say something to the chamber in respect of this whole issue of equivalent state or territory bodies, particularly in respect of Senator Harradine's amendment which the committee accepted earlier regarding the membership of an equivalent state or territory body. That amendment substituted paragraph 207B(4)(f) so that the Commonwealth minister would have to be satisfied that the relevant state or territory legislation would require a member of the NNTT to be a member of the equivalent state or territory body.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Harradine said last night in the debate that he does think it important that the NNTT member have a proper role within the state or territory tribunal. Certainly, from the government's point of view, we would expect that the experience of NNTT members ap pointed to a state tribunal would be fully utilised by the state or territory in question. But obviously, if that were to mean that the national tribunal member had to be involved in every mediation or exercise of the power to register claims under the determined regime operating in the state, the process would not be workable, although I do not think that is exactly what Senator Harradine intended to do.

The government does accept that it is important that the role of the member of the NNTT in the state or territory equivalent body be clarified and will for that purpose be making a statement on that role after there has been an opportunity to talk to the states and territories who wish to establish equivalent bodies about the implications of the amendment moved by Senator Harradine and how those intentions might be best reflected in operational arrangements.

TALK.START.PARA: —So that the Senate will not be terribly surprised at the time, I wish to flag that there are some further amendments in relation to the role of judiciary in the states and territories and how that role can be made equivalent so that everybody knows where they are. These are being drafted now. I just wanted to flag that at some later stage we will be seeking to come back to this small area we are dealing with now so that we can look at my subsequent amendments. They have not been circulated yet, but I would like to go back to that at some stage.

—I thank the minister for his comments. It is an important amendment that has been incorporated into the legislation by the committee. The objective of the amendment is to assist in a common approach and a not inconsistent approach by the various bodies in the various states. I thank the minister for his comments. I will be looking forward in the new year to a further major statement from the minister consequent upon his consultations with the states.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to say that a statement from the minister for us is absolutely no satisfactory alternative to what is necessary in practice. Statements are often made by ministers and from my experience as a minister—and Senator Harradine knows this very well—I can say that you can very easily skirt around issues and assure people in this place, but at the end of day in practice what you are concerned about when you raise the issue is not really satisfied. Senator Harradine should know better than most that, if he is going to rely on a statement from the minister some time in the future, then that is really like saying the cheque is in the mail and you do not really know what the amount is going to be.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no substitute for giving the Federal Court a capacity, in a practical ongoing way, to ensure that this system does not go off the rails. By doing this we can foresee in a couple of years time that the National Native Title Tribunal will be rendered a shell. The states will go on their merry way, having the local equivalent of a fishing warden handling these sorts of issues.

They are not just land management issues; they are national issues relating to the issue of race. It is pretty important. Spirituality in native title is important and we really should have an ongoing capacity for the Federal Court to act as a bit of a monitor on the system. Unfortunately, Senator Harradine, I am not satisfied, and nor should you be, with a commitment from the government to say, `The government has produced this legislation to satisfy concerns in the future.' Your amendment goes some way, but I am sure you recognise by your participation in this part of the proceedings that your amendment, as good as it is, does not really cover the field in terms of our concerns. I encourage you to adopt what is a pretty reasonable proposal by the opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not supporting the opposition's amendments but we would prefer amendment 253D to be amended so that, in proposed subsection (6), in the second last line, the word `recognised' is omitted and the word `equivalent' is inserted. It is a minor technical change.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —We are prepared to accept that. I seek leave to amend the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (253D) Schedule 2, item 20, Page 170 (after line 8), at the end of section 86B, add:

PARA.TAB: (6) Notwithstanding the operation of section 207B, where a recognised State or Territory body has been determined by the Commonwealth Minister under section 207A and the Federal Court, at any time in a proceeding, considers that the parties will be able to reach agreement on, or on facts relevant to, any of the matters set out in subsection 86A(1) or (2), the Court must refer the whole or part of the proceeding to the relevant equivalent State or Territory body unless any party to the proceeding objects.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments 253A, 253B, 253C and 253D, as amended, not agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will now move to opposition amendment 165A on revised sheet 818.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition opposes items 31 to 33 of schedule 1 in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: (165A) Schedule 1, items 31, 32 and 33, page 124 (lines 15 to 27), TO BE OPPOSED .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Items 31 to 33 are what the Greens (WA) call the platypus amendment. Only certain people who were involved in the debate in 1993 know what this means. Section 211 of the current act provides a guarantee that certain native title rights such as hunting and gathering can continue where a law restricting or prohibiting an activity allows that class of activity to be carried out under licence.

SPEECH.PARA: Item 31 represents a substantial watering down of this guarantee. As long as there is permission to carry out the class of activities to non‐Aboriginal people, then Aboriginal people should be able to carry out the class of activity. It is not unreasonable that Aboriginal people should be entitled to exercise traditional rights in all circumstances where there is not a complete prohibition on carrying out a traditional activity. If emergency situations were what the government had in mind—for instance, public safety—then the government should say so. A great deal of scientific research is carried out for private commercial purposes. In those circumstances, indigenous people should be entitled to exercise rights which are fundamental to their own existence.

Item 32 is a note stating that the exercise of native title rights is subject to laws of general application. This note is unnecessary and has the potential to create confusion as to which laws apply and the extent to which section 211 rights may be exercised or abrogated by state regulations.

With regard to item 33, section 212 ensures that any confirmation is not a backdoor way to further impair native title rights. The current act requires that such confirmation does not extinguish or impair any native title rights or interests. This is a fundamental protection for native title rights.

The statement on page 332 of the explanatory memorandum that the amendment is justified because ownership or exercise may technically impair the enjoyment of native title in some respects misses the point of the provision and the protection it is supposed to provide. It is not technical; it is a substantive authorisation for the states to impair native title rights without any procedural rights being afforded. It is discriminatory in that no other person's rights are abrogated in this way. I urge the committee to support the removal of items 31, 32 and 33.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will put on the record the government's position on these matters. It is true that under section 211 of the current act native title holders are able to exercise certain native title rights which are stated as hunting, fishing, gathering or those involving cultural or spiritual activities without needing to obtain a licence or permit. That is preserved prima facie, but we have put in item 31 to make it clear that that special exemption to native title holders does not apply where the law under which the licence or permit is granted only allows the activity covered by the permit to be carried out for the purposes of research, environmental protection, public health or public safety. Therefore, like everybody else, in those circumstances, native title holders would need the requisite licence or permit. We think that is an important matter of public policy.

SPEECH.PARA: The note inserted by item 32 simply makes it clear that where native title holders do exercise their native title rights under section 211, they have got to do so in accordance with generally applicable laws regulating that activity, which means things like being subject to the normal criminal laws of the state. We think that is essential to ensure certainty about what laws apply to what people and to make clear something which I would have thought was important from a coexistence point of view and a reconciliation point of view—that native title holders, like every other member of the community, are subject to the general laws of the community, for example, the criminal law. So it does not interfere with the essential right to engage in native title activities with those two caveats which we think, from a public policy point of view, are important.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition supports the Greens (WA) in opposing items 31 to 33 of schedule 1. We do so for a couple of reasons. We recognise the importance of the area we are talking about. The minister just a few days ago gave an assurance that section 211 would be saved and protected, but this is a substantial watering down. There are two things I need to say about it.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, it is an unjustifiable watering down. There is no reason why we should be removing the protection that is listed in section 211—no reason at all. The minister still says that that is what that clause should be about, but he refuses to ensure that it is reflected in the legislation. Once again, the court would rather have it in the legislation than by way of any comment by the minister in the committee stage, though those comments will probably be used in court.

Secondly, Senator Minchin, we have not been going at a bad pace on this legislation this week and a degree of flexibility on your part on some of these issues may help us to complete the bill sooner than later. Quibbling about things like this is really something that is not essential to your 10-point plan. You cannot hide behind that cover. This is an important protection and the opposition agrees with the Greens and the Democrats that these particular provisions of yours should be opposed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to point out to the minister that research these days has a fairly broad application. It can, in fact, be research for commercial purposes. We know what the Japanese mean by research for whaling. We also know that in Western Australia there is commercial exploitation of things like smoke bush. Basically, the Department of Conservation and Land Management is selling off native plants for their genetic lines for commercial exploitation.

SPEECH.PARA: So the reality is that it is a far too broad application. Under the broad heading of research we may end up having research for commercial exploitation, research for mining and all sort of research being okay and, as the minister suggested, indigenous Australians being held on criminal charges for undertaking their traditional activities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that the Democrats will be supporting the Greens (WA) in opposing items 31 to 33 of schedule 1. I would like to underline what Senator Margetts has just said, particularly in relation to research, because it is a very broad term, and certainly in terms of the inquiry that the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport References Committee has been conducting for the past 12 months in terms of exploitation of native wildlife.

SPEECH.PARA: We have lost so much of our native wildlife to overseas. An example is the wild flower. The world market for the wild flower industry is now concentrated in Israel. They grow Australian wild flowers and sell them into the international market. The cautionary principle that Senator Margetts is enunciating ought to be supported.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to ask the minister if can he give me any circumstance at all where sections 211 or 212 of the existing act have been found to be a problem?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is more a case of the confusion as to what the legal regime is, who is allowed to do what and what laws apply in the circumstances generated by section 211. Generally speaking, in Australia we are all as Australians subject to the general law. These items seek to make clear that you cannot breach the criminal law. No-one can breach the criminal law with immunity. So this is simply to make that proposition clear, because it is unclear at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: So it is in the vein of seeking to achieve some certainty as to the application of the general law under the operation of section 211. In relation to the operation of section 211, where native title rights can be exercised without needing to obtain a licence or permit, that does not extend to the situation where licences or permits can be obtained only for the specified purposes set out in item 31. So they really are to deal with what is clear after four years of operation of the act as to the uncertainty of the operation of the law in the circumstances that are generated under section 211.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister. I ask the minister a further question. Which sections of the criminal law do the current sections 211 and 212 allow indigenous people to breach?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —The point is that there is some uncertainty and confusion about that. All we are stating is what I would have thought would be obvious—that the general laws would apply. In the face of assertions that that is not the case and that section 211 bestows upon native title holders an immunity from the general laws of the community, we wish to make it clear that that is not the case. Certainly we believe that to be the appropriate legal position. To the extent that anyone asserts that it is not, we wish to make that clear in the bill.

—I think we are getting closer to the point. Who is coming up and saying that this is a problem? Is it not what you are saying that, up to now, traditional activities have not been considered criminal but, from now on, we may be led to believe that you will consider some traditional cultural activities of indigenous Australians to be criminal activities? Is there a problem now; on what basis has it been seen to be a problem; and is it not what you are suggesting that, from now on, there may be some traditional activities which you may conveniently call criminal activities?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think a relevant example is the question of gun licensing. Section 211 allows hunting, so the question of whether you can do so with a gun arises in this context. If a licence is required to hunt with a gun, then that would apply to native title holders.
—They can still use them now.

—Because that level of uncertainty does arise, the question is: does section 211 allow hunting with guns regardless of the general laws of the state? That issue has arisen and it is an area of uncertainty. So it is making that section clear. If, generally speaking, a licence is required to hunt with a gun, then that will apply to native title holders.
—Is the minister suggesting that, somehow or other, the Native Title Act covers the purchasing or illegal purchasing of guns; is that what the minister is suggesting?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —These amendments, which I agree with Senator Bolkus we should proceed to a vote on, simply make it clear that that is not the case. To the extent that it could be asserted that section 211 is so wide as to allow hunting with guns regardless of the relevant laws of general application, this is the sort of provision which will make it clear that that is not the case.

BREAK.PARA: We think it is appropriate to have these provisions to clarify that uncertainty and to ensure that, generally speaking, while native title holders can exercise their traditional rights as declared under 211—for example, on things like public safety which are matters relating to guns—they would be bound by the general laws. If they wish to hunt with guns they would need to obtain the relevant licence or permit in the jurisdiction in which it occurs.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is one of the most disgraceful bits of scaremongering I have seen so far in this legislation. I would like to remind the minister that what we are saying is that it is not unreasonable that Aboriginal people should be entitled to exercise traditional rights in all circumstances where there is not a complete prohibition on carrying out the traditional activity. We know, as you know, that the area of illegal firearm possession does not fit into that category. So I think what you have given is a furphy. It is disgraceful.
—I want to put this point on the record as well: the only instance that Senator Minchin can come up with was the question of guns.
—I gave an example.

—That is the only example you have come up with. I just cannot believe the minister is suggesting that Aboriginal Australians would not have to conform with the general laws in respect of guns—they do. To the extent that they do not, they like others have to abide with the consequences under law. But it is just over the top to suggest that this is what this amendment is about. This amendment is not necessary and I hope the chamber votes against it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are simply making it clear that that is the case, because there is some uncertainty about the operation of section 211. Section 211(2) states:

SPEECH.PARA: If this subsection applies, the law does not prohibit or restrict the native title holders from carrying on the class of activity . . .
in exercise or enjoyment of their native title rights and interests.

And hunting is one of those rights. I would have thought this amendment is unexceptional. There should be no objection to making it absolutely clear to remove the uncertainty. That is clearly the case in section 211. It should be unexceptional.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let the record show that the minister really could not come up with any good example to support this; let the record show that he has not been able to show that, over the last few years of the operation of this legislation, there has been a problem. He has come up with a theoretical problem relating to guns, which is no problem at all.

—I just want to emphasise that item 33 is, in fact, a major change to the current situation. It is actually another backdoor way to impair native title rights. The current act requires that confirmation does not extinguish or impair native title rights or interests. But this particular section is discriminatory. It is not, as the minister suggests, like any other Australians. He is actually saying that, for one group of people, we are going to take away their rights.
—The question is that items 31 to 33 on schedule 1 stand as printed.

—Senator Margetts, your sheet 830 has just been circulated. These are amendments in relation to topic 21, miscellaneous, which we are now on. Amendments Nos 1 and 2 are to schedule 2, item 71, page 201, after line 9 and then after line 33. Do you wish to move those now or to deal with them at some other stage?
—These were the ones that I did foreshadow. I would like to have a small amount of time to seek some advice on these amendments. I would prefer to defer them just a little while.
—In that case, is it the wish of the committee that we move to revised sheet 14, Validation? There being no objection, it is so ordered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —This is one of the more contentious issues in relation to this legislation. The opposition believes that because of the way that the government has tackled it there are issues of equity, constitutionality and discrimination that the Senate will have to address and for which the Senate will be remembered by history.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us spell out the problem here. Numerous potentially invalid grants of interest in land have been made between the commencement of the Native Title Act on 1 January 1994 and the Wik decision by the High Court on 23 December 1996. These grants are potentially valid because they fail to comply with the processes under the Native Title Act.

This happened for a number of reasons. There was a belief held in good faith by some that native title was extinguished by historic pastoral leases. We all know that a misreading of the law is no real excuse at law. Everyone is presumed to know the law, especially the states.

Another reason this happened was that some states refused to recognise the authority of the Native Title Act. Western Australia was one, but I have to say in respect of Western Australia that once the Waanyi case was determined they then decided to comply with the processes under the act. You cannot say the same about other states. Other states were totally irresponsible in respect of their obligations under the law. These two reasons essentially underpin the third. Some people just took a risk that pastoral leases extinguish native title. Some took that risk in the belief that no native title was claimable over particular pieces of land even when vacant crown land was involved.

There has to be a recognition by this parliament that, despite some of the reasons for this intermediate period problem, we have to tackle the problem now. There are a number of ways of tackling that. There is the avenue by agreement, which is always the most preferred way to go. There is the avenue available for us to ensure that the processes of the act are now complied with as they can be under the section 29 provision on a one by one basis. I think it has been accepted by the opposition and the government that there needs to be a more wholesale appraisal of this particular problem and see if there can be a process adopted which would provide what could be called an up-front validation of the problems involved.

I have to say in that context, that, although the opposition and government have considered those approaches, the alternatives put up by the respective sides are massively different. Can I say in embarking upon this debate that one has to be concerned about the native title holders. They are the people who, time and time again, are having their rights eroded. There is a huge capacity in this legislation to erode them in respect of this particular validation regime being proposed by the government. It is important to focus on them. Historically, they fought for 200 years to assert that Australia was not terra nullius. Since the Mabo case they seem to be fighting to retain what they achieved in that case and in subsequent cases.

We also need to factor in that some people in the intermediate period obtained rights and did so in good faith misled by the governments, misled by the range of factors and those people also have to be considered in this particular process. The government has an all embracing, broad, far‐reaching solution which validates all intermediate period acts which occurred over freehold or leasehold land, other than mining lease land but including pastoral lease land, and land on which a public work was constructed.

The problems for us with the government's proposal is that it goes well beyond the decision in Wik. That is problem No. 1. It applies to land covered by any lease, other than a mining lease, and not just pastoral leases. It applies to land on which public works were constructed or established. Public works include roads, stock routes, wells, bores or any major earth works. This means that titles granted over land could be validated just because there was at some stage in history an old well or an old stock route on that land. It goes too far.

The third problem with the government's proposal is that by going too far not only indigenous Australians will suffer an erosion of rights but also taxpayers will have to pay for gratuitous extinguishment. At the same time as that, under the government's proposal we are going to be rewarding states that have deliberately set out to breach the Native Title Act. What we will also be doing is extinguishing when the common law has left that issue substantially open. The common law has laid a number of inferences that would indicate that suppression rather than extinguishment is what is to happen in these circumstances.

In terms of further problems, it goes too far. If we look at the government's category A of scheduled interests, we find that the schedule itself is a huge problem. It is not a schedule of actual leases. It is a schedule of empowering legislation, categories of leases. So there is no certainty that what we would be adopting, if we were to adopt the schedule, would be instruments, leases or whatever that, in practical effect, have been exclusive possession aspects to them. The schedule includes things such as golf links, rifle ranges, defence, water tanks.

The other pernicious part of this proposal is that the schedule can be added to by way of regulation and there is absolutely no assertion by the government that there is any boundary in terms of what can be scheduled by regulation. The government has made it clear that they do not think a boundary around what the regulations should include is appropriate.

If we in this parliament were to adopt this particular proposal, we would be saying to the government that we accept their schedule now even though it does go too far. Evidence before the committee has showed that. At the same time, if they missed something out in accommodating the shopping list from all the states—and that is what the schedule is; it is a shopping list from all the states which was put up and was, in some respects, vetted by federal authorities—they can come back, and it does not matter whether it comes under the broader definitions that are provided by the section, and we will ensure that we can regulate.

It goes too far. Not only does it go further than the common law but also it goes further than what was justified by the Wik decision. Also, we go beyond past acts which were validated by the original Native Title Act. What we are doing here is validating acts which were carried out unlawfully in the intermediate period and which could not be validated under the Native Title Act.

Another concern is the right to negotiate. The effect of the validation provisions is that native title holders have lost their right to non-discriminatory treatment and the right to negotiate where this applies during the intermediate period. As to constitutionality, let us place on the record that the notification provisions here are nowhere near substantial enough to satisfy requirements.

The opposition is saying, `Let's look at a way of providing certainty, but let's look at a fair way of doing it.' Obviously the minor parties do not agree with us, but we believe our alternative is a constructive way to go. We propose a validation regime limited to those acts on pastoral leases, or which were subject to a pastoral lease, not on land which just happened to be covered by other leases some time in the past and not on public work land. If the act in the intermediate period is a pastoral activity, it is validated, and this follows the form defining pastoral activities. If it is not a pastoral activity, then the means by which validation is allowed is by gazettal. The government wanting to validate the act must publish a notice in the Gazette and must give notice to the relevant rep bodies within four months of the commencement of the section, and the notice has to include sufficiently detailed information about the act or the grant.

Native title claimant groups or representative bodies can apply to the Federal Court on two limited grounds: the act was not genuinely an intermediate period act as defined; or proper procedures were not followed. That protection needs to be there. We propose the non‐extinguishment principle and compensation being payable. Also, to meet the form requirements of the just term provisions of the constitution, compensation should be paid by way of a fast track to ensure that the Deane requirement in the Tasmanian dams case is satisfied.

BREAK.PARA: Validating now and providing for compensation in five or 10 years time does not satisfy the constitutional requirements. Our fast track proposals permit effective native title holders to apply to the Federal Court for compensation. Claims can then be referred by consent of the parties to the tribunal. The court or the tribunal, on assessing the claims, can order compensation as long as it satisfies the requirements of the registration test in 190B. If the compensation is not on just terms, the Commonwealth will have to top it up, provide additional compensation, to rectify the failure. The government can also apply for an order from the Federal Court for a declaration. Let me anticipate the normal argument of the Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister, Senator Minchin, about this. We have had this checked by senior Queen's Counsel, and the advice that we have is that this proposal meets the constitutional requirements of Brandy.

It would be our much preferred approach if these acts could be validated by agreement as part of the ILUA—indigenous land use agreements. There is no better way to provide a cooperative spirit and there is no better way to implement the spirit of Wik than to ensure that coexistence is the motivating force. We are successful in amending the provisions in the bill to ensure that rep bodies can participate or there can be indigenous land use agreements in respect of past and intermediate period acts, and we would advocate that as a way of handling these particular problems.

People have to go on living with each other after the validation. They have to coexist. One person asserting the brutal force of the law over others—`others' normally being Wik—and people not knowing their rights do not lead to a spirit of coexistence and reconciliation. The fair process that we provide, which is totally different from the government's, will enhance that spirit of coexistence.

To those who are waiting in anticipation for this legislation to get through in substantial part and to those who think that if we pass this legislation in a reasonably modified form—I do not accept the definition they give to the word `reasonably'—there will not be a double dissolution and we can go on living happily together by the middle of next year, I say this: this issue will not go away. To the extent that there is injustice and for the time that there is injustice, indigenous Australians will not lie back and accept what this Senate is meting out to them. The issue will continue to haunt us until we provide a just regime for native title.

The immediate confrontation that has been proposed and talked about by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) in terms of a race debate is not our major worry. The major worry we have is that, given our diversity—the fact that so many of us come from different parts of the world—given that we have not been seen by the world to have adequately tackled the situation with our indigenous people and given that we are being seen by the world now as handling it very badly, the issue of race will affect us and haunt us socially both internally and internationally as it affects our image and consequently our trade potential.

Do not delude yourselves into thinking that if we give the Prime Minister something now Australia will settle down by the middle of next year into a cohesive society. I know, and deep down we all know, that what we are doing in this legislation is ripping the arms and legs off the system of native title. Indigenous Australians practising in the field know that full well. If we keep going the way that we have been going, we can guarantee that we will be haunted by issues dealing with our indigenous population in at least my generation and for longer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —While Senator Bolkus says there is a massive gap between his position and that of the government, I must say that I do not see that gap to be massive at all. On this particular issue, the Labor Party and the government are quite close together. I want to put on the record the difference between the Labor Party's and the government's amendments and those of the National Indigenous Working Group and the Democrats‐Greens.

SPEECH.PARA: I also want to acknowledge the presence in the gallery of Doug Woolla and Jonathan Korkaktain, who are from Aurukun. We often talk about Wik as though somehow or other it was perhaps a Latin phrase dreamed up by the High Court. In fact, it is a generic word which describes a number of groups who live on western Cape York. Doug, Jonathan and Norma Chevathun are here to watch the debate this week, and it is good to see them in the gallery.

The issue of validation of intermediate leases is one that has dominated the Wik debate because it is absolutely key to protection of native title in this country. How we treat all those thousands of titles issued on pastoral leases and other forms of title after Mabo is crucial. If we take the easy route and issue blanket validation, that is de facto extinguishment of native title rights.

And what is the justification for doing this in defiance of the High Court Wik decision? The excuse used by the government—and, I have to say, some in the Labor Party—is that in 1993 there was legal advice floating around that native title would be extinguished on those leases. As if in any other legal case—sex discrimination, industrial relations; take your pick—it would be okay to say, `We are going to legislate in direct contradiction of the High Court, because the High Court's decision is not the same as some earlier legal advice.' When you look at it that way you can see that it is wrong, unfair and, worst of all, racially discriminatory, because it would not happen with any other High Court decision.

The government's proposed validation of these intermediate leases has in part the support of the Labor Party, for that is the effect of the Labor Party's position. It is only a hair's breadth away from the government on this issue, and that is where our amendments are going to try to keep the Labor Party honest.

I want to put on the record the Labor Party's history on this issue, for we know now why the ALP supports legalising unlawful leases. It is because the majority of those leases were issued by the Labor government in Queensland—about 1,500 out of 2,000 that were issued in the intermediate period between 1994 and 1996. These titles were issued by the Goss government without going through the process of the Native Title Act. We know that there is an election coming up in Queensland which Peter Beattie wants to win. I presume he does not want to upset the applecart by going in against something his party did in government. And we do not even know where Mr Beattie stands on the discriminatory validation of pastoral leases where native title may exist, because he has not told us.

I think it is important that we put these facts on the record, because the Labor Party is presenting itself as the great white knight on native title. But it has changed its policy on native title in the past few months, probably hoping that no‐one will notice. Well, the Democrats noticed.

I suppose some in the ALP will say it is mean of us to point out these inconsistencies, but there is a crucial reason why we do this. Labor is now painting itself as new Labor, new warm and fuzzy Labor that learned from its mistakes. Well, here is the hurdle which will determine whether we have new Labor or old Labor.

I am afraid history reflects this sad story. Former Queensland Premier, Wayne Goss, has come a long way in embracing native title in recent days, but let me remind you of a few of his views when the Mabo legislation was being introduced back in 1993. When it came to mining and native title rights, Mr Goss made it clear that mining always came first. He would give pretty promises about native title and non‐discriminatory ways of extinguishing it and then he would turn around and try to elbow Aborigines out of the way if they were in the way of mining.

Let me give you some examples. Mr Goss told ABC Radio on 23 July 1993 that uncertainty over an earlier native title claim by the Wik people over the land near Weipa in Far North Queensland had to be removed to secure Comalco's mining project. Mr Goss said:
That uncertainty is of concern, and we believe that the company, the State Government and the Federal Government are going to have to co‐operate to remove it.

There is not a lot of support for coexistence or recognition of Aboriginal rights there—just `Get out of the way, native title holders. Comalco's coming through.' And I quote Mr Goss again on ABC Radio on 13 August 1993:

My main concern is a 2 thousand jobs project . . . a Wik claim could be brought at any time against any project anywhere in Australia, so it really is a national responsibility in terms of creating jobs and winning investment.

At the time, Aboriginal people accused federal Labor of selling out to the states over Mabo. Noel Pearson said that the lowest common denominator in the native title debate had been set by Wayne Goss and the Queensland government. The former Premier of Queensland was all for validation; he was one of the chief proponents of it. He put intense pressure on federal Labor to validate all the illegal leases that may have had native title on them and to do it pronto.

In fact, Wayne Goss has the dubious honour of issuing more of those unlawful intermediate titles than any other state leader, including the Nationals' Rob Borbidge. Of the new mining tenements issued between the Native Title Act 1994 and the Wik decision in December 1995, the Goss government gave out 1,582 mining tenements—73 per cent. The Borbidge government gave out 581 new mining tenements—a total of 27 per cent.

The Labor Party has the very dubious honour of holding the record for de facto extinguishment of native title in this country by issuing thousands of potentially unlawful titles on pastoral land. It ignored Paul Keating's Native Title Act and, when Aboriginal people showed their genuine distress at this, Mr Goss said that they had raised their hopes unrealistically. How patronising. But the Wik people continued their fight to get back to their traditional land. In December last year the High Court found some justice for them and recognised their native title. Now history is repeating itself. Vote‐hungry Queensland Labor leaned on Kim Beazley and got him to sell out Aboriginal people who may have native title surviving where around 25,000 intermediate titles are set to be validated by the government and the Labor Party.

I want to discuss the subject of legal advice for a moment. The government have steadfastly refused to release key pieces of legal advice on the constitutionality of their bill. The opposition have quite rightly pursued them—vigorously pursued them—to have this advice released, with Democrat support. But what of the legal advice to the opposition? From newspaper reports we know that the Labor Party have received advice from Alec Shand QC on the government's amending legislation. In the Sydney Morning Herald of last Tuesday week we read that Mr Shand said the bill was racially discriminatory in many areas, including validating past unlawful acts of the Queensland and Western Australian governments, deeming extinguishment of native title on thousands of leases. We know that the ALP have had legal advice from a top QC saying that the validation of intermediate period acts is racially discriminatory, yet they will support that discrimination by opposing this Australian Democrats and Greens amendment—an amendment which is supported by the National Indigenous Working Group. That is against their own legal advice, or at least as much of that legal advice as we can read in the newspapers.
It seems that Mr Shand's advice went to the matter of the government bill yet, on Wednesday of last week, Mr Beazley is quoted as saying on ABC Radio:

We have advice that what we are putting forward is 100 per cent kosher as far as the constitution is concerned, which differentiates our amendments dramatically from the government bill as it now stands.

Clearly this is not the Shand advice. Perhaps it was the Ron Castan advice referred to in a Sydney Morning Herald article on 27 November by Margo Kingston which, like the Shand advice, has not been publicly released. I would again call on the Labor Party to release both sets of advice so that we can know. The Democrats say plainly and forthrightly to the Labor Party that what is good for the goose is good for the gander. Release the legal opinions that you have or look foolish for pursuing the government over theirs.

Mr Beazley's statement, if supported by advice, may be true. The ALP amendments may be 100 per cent kosher; however, his words create a false impression. Clearly the government's validations section in its bill is not 100 per cent kosher. Advice from Alec Shand QC says so. How can the ALP now vote to maintain that section of the bill which Mr Shand says is racially discriminatory and put any spin on it other than that they are doing it to protect the interests of the Labor Party in the upcoming Queensland election? I have spoken earlier about the record of the Goss Labor government, which the ALP would like to cover up. They will do this by hiding behind a catch‐all, Racial Discrimination Act amendment. I say to them again: the validation section of this bill is not 100 per cent constitutionally kosher, it is not beneficial to indigenous Australians and you should release that legal advice.

Finally, I want to make a crucial point. The Howard government and the National Farmers Federation have been travelling all over the country claiming that they have to extinguish native title on pastoral leases to help the farmers. The Democrats asked some questions about that claim. We asked the Queensland government: how many pastoral leases have been issued in the state since the Native Title Act was passed in 1994? We wanted to know how many farmers' leases were potentially invalid. The answer was: not one. Not one pastoral lease has been issued in Queensland in the intermediate period between the Native Title Act 1994 and the Wik decision in 1996. The validation issue is one where Labor and the government are as one—almost as one. So who are they protecting? The other part of our question to the Queensland government was: how many mining titles have been issued in the intermediate period? The answer was: 2,163 mining tenements were issued in that time. The figures give the lie to the government's claim that their validation plans are about helping pastoralists.

The Prime Minister's speech on Sunday night conspicuously referred to farmers throughout. There was only one mention of the mining and resources industry. The speech constantly referred to farmers, to the concerns of farmers, to the needs for guarantees for farmers and to how sad it would be if Australia did not have a rural sector. Was the Prime Minister playing down the fact that mining companies stand to gain most from his extinguishment plans?

BREAK.PARA: In Queensland the unlawful validation of those thousands of leases and the wiping out of native title will help miners and not one single farmer. It will help struggling Aussie battlers like Rio Tinto, BHP and Western Mining! That is what the Howard government wants to do. I am sad that Kim Beazley and the Labor Party also want to do that. It must be remembered that that is the truth behind the words we hear from Labor on native title.

The Democrats have nothing against the mining sector per se. But I get angry when people like Premier Rob Borbidge say that Aboriginal people are greedy for asking for some control over their land near the site of the Ernest Henry mine, when these figures show that successive state and federal governments have bent over backwards to give the green light to mining, even if it means the unnecessary extinguishment of native title.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a very important part of the government's bill—one of the most important and one that we find it extremely disappointing that the opposition is not prepared to support. We believe that invalidity of the thousands of titles issued over pastoral leases between the operation of the Native Title Act and the Wik decision is simply not tenable. It is essential that the validation that occurred in the Native Title Act for all past acts be applied in the case of those otherwise valid titles and that leases issued in good faith between the operation of the Native Title Act and the Wik decision be validated.

SPEECH.PARA: The titles were issued in good faith, in our view, for the following reasons. There is absolutely no doubt that the Native Title Act was drafted on the presumption that pastoral leases extinguished native title. As former Senator Gareth Evans said in this place in the 1993 debate, the Keating government was:

. . . proceeding on the assumption that the native title had been extinguished by the pastoral leases concerned; that is the clear intimation of the High Court so far as the common law position is concerned . . . The working assumption is that the vesting of a pastoral lease extinguishes native title, so there is nothing left to claim.

That is clearly the state of the law as a result of the Mabo judgment, and the lead judgment of Chief Justice Brennan stated that leaseholds extinguished native title. There was no suggestion that there should be any distinction in relation to pastoral leases, and of course Chief Justice Brennan was entirely consistent between the Mabo and the Wik decisions. In Wik he made it quite clear that a pastoral lease fitted the description of lease, as described by him in Mabo, and that it completely extinguished native title—and he was joined by Justices McHugh and Dawson.

The Mabo law—that is, that all leaseholds extinguish native title—was reflected by Justice French in the Waanyi case in February 1995, by the majority of the full Federal Court in the Waanyi case on 1 November 1995 and by Justice Drummond in the first hearing on the Wik case in early 1996. They were restatements of the law that pastoral leases extinguished native title. The Native Title Tribunal itself did not accept any claims over pastoral leases without reservations for Aboriginal people from early 1994 to the middle of 1996.

It is our view, therefore, that governments that issued titles over pastoral leases were operating on the valid assumption that the law was that pastoral leases extinguished native title—and, indeed, that was the law. What happened in Wik was that the law was changed and, as a result of the Wik decision, pastoral leases could no longer be presumed to automatically extinguish native title. We know that now to be the law—that they do not necessarily extinguish native title from 23 December 1996 forward. But we believe that governments acted entirely in good faith in issuing titles over pastoral leases and other leases between the operation of the Native Title Act and 23 December 1996.

The previous Keating government went out of its way to assure everybody and to make it absolutely and fundamentally clear that pastoral leases extinguished native title. So it is quite unreasonable to suggest that state governments should have acted in any other way than they did in issuing titles.

The fact is that we are talking about nearly 23,000 various permits, licences, leases, et cetera, that were issued in that period in good faith. Any suggestion that this parliament should not provide that they be validated would be a gross dereliction of our responsibilities to the Australian nation and to the certainty which the national economy, the investors and the human beings involved in this process require. This involves the lives and livelihoods of many people—as we are seeing with the Ernest Henry mine case where there is a huge investment, based on a title issued in this period, employing Aboriginal people and generating jobs, income and export income for this country. You cannot have a situation where there is any doubt about the legal validity of such titles.

For that 1994, 1995, 1996 period, we think it is essential that our validation regime be put in place. We are absolutely amazed that the Labor Party is not prepared to support it. I hate to think what the Queensland and Western Australian Labor parties think of the position adopted by their federal colleagues on this question, because to leave some doubt over these titles is a gross dereliction of responsibility.

In 1994 the Labor Party and the parliament felt it appropriate to provide for blanket validation of everything that had occurred prior to 1994 for the reason that certainty was essential. As former Attorney‐General Lavarch said on 24 November 1993:

Because of the possibility that some past acts which affect native title may have been rendered invalid, particularly by the operation of the Racial Discrimination Act, but also potentially by other laws, the Commonwealth has decided to include in its legislation for the validation of such past acts in order to remove any doubt whatsoever.
That is exactly the situation we face now. I agree with Labor's Attorney‐General: it is essential that in the case of the titles issued in this period we remove any doubt whatsoever.
Senator Gareth Evans, in one of his more colourful statements in a debate in this chamber said:

The whole point of this particular provision about validation of past invalid acts is to, with a sweep of the legislative pen, validate any past act that may be invalid for the particular reasons spelt out in the legislation, namely, the interaction of the existence of native title with some other law.

Again, it was felt appropriate then by the former government and by this parliament that that validation be provided. We think that in the circumstances we now face where, clearly, there was a change of the law—the law changed as a result of Wik—it is absolutely irresponsible of this parliament not to ensure the validity of the titles issued in good faith in that period.

Our validation regime is not as sweeping as Gareth Evans's sweep of the legislative pen; it is a more limited validation regime than that. It covers only acts and grants done on land in relation to which it was reasonable to assume that native title had been extinguished. It does not extend to acts done on land only previously the subject of a licence or a reservation or which has always been vacant crown land. It also does not extend to invalid acts consisting of the making of legislation, except where the legislation itself directly creates an estate or makes a grant or a reservation.

We have made our position abundantly clear in the public arena. I do not need to delay the Senate by again putting our case; I think you understand it. But we are absolutely clear on the need for this validation regime. We have provided the proper provisions in relation to compensation and non‐extinguishment where it is a non‐extinguishing act. Where it is not exclusive possession that is being granted, the non‐extinguishment principle applies and full just terms compensation. But, as a matter of ensuring the certainty of Australian law, we believe this validation regime is essential. We have a number of technical and other amendments to this section which I will formally move now. I move:
(1) Schedule 1, item 9, page 6 (line 13), omit the heading to Division 2A, substitute:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Division 2A—Validation of intermediate period acts etc.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Schedule 1, item 9, page 7 (line 16), omit "(3), (4) or (6)", substitute "(3) or (4)".
(3) Schedule 1, item 9, page 9 (after line 6), at the end of Subdivision B, add:

TAB.TAB: (a) an act that is attributable to the Commonwealth consists of:
(i) the creation of a right to mine; or
(ii) the variation of such a right to extend the area to which it relates; or

(iii) the extension of the period for which such a right has effect, other than under an option or right of extension or renewal created by the lease, contract or other thing whose grant or making created the right to mine; and
(b) the act took place at any time during the period from the beginning of 1 January 1994 until the end of 23 December 1996; and
(c) at any time before the act was done, either:
(i) a grant of a freehold estate or a lease was made covering any of the land or waters affected by the act; or
(ii) a public work was constructed or established on any of the land or waters affected by the act;
the Commonwealth must, before the end of 6 months after this section commences:

(d) give notice containing the details set out in subsection (2) to any registered native title body corporate, any registered native title claimant and any representative Aboriginal/Torres Strait Islander body, in relation to any of the land or waters affected by the act; and
(e) notify the public in the determined way of the details set out in subsection (2).

PARA.TAB: (2) The details are:

the State or Territory must, before the end of 6 months after the commencement of the law of the State or Territory that validates intermediate period acts attributable to the State or Territory in accordance with section 22F:

(d) give notice containing the details set out in subsection (2) to any registered native title body corporate, any registered native title claimant and any representative Aboriginal/Torres Strait Islander body, in relation to any of the land or waters affected by the act; and

PARA.TAB: (2) The details are:

(b) the kind of mining involved; and

SPEECH.PARA: (50) Schedule 1, item 39, page 126 (lines 14 and 15), omit "beginning on 1 January 1994 and ending on 23 December 1996", substitute "from the beginning of 1 January 1994 until the end of 23 December 1996".
(51) Schedule 1, item 39, page 128 (line 16) to page 129 (line 6), omit subsections (5) and (6).
(52) Schedule 1, item 39, page 129 (lines 11 to 16), omit subsection (8), substitute:

PARA.TAB: (8) An intermediate period act is not a category A intermediate period act if it is:

TAB.TAB: (a) the grant or vesting of any thing that is made or done by or under legislation that makes provision for the grant or vesting of such things only to, in or for the benefit of, Aboriginal peoples or Torres Strait Islanders; or
(b) the grant or vesting of any thing to or in a person to hold on trust for the benefit of Aboriginal peoples or Torres Strait Islanders; or
