(iv) any other lease granted over particular land or waters, if at the time a lease covered by subparagraph (ii) or (iii) is in force over the land or waters.

SPEECH.PARA: I will briefly speak to the amendments. Amendment No. 1 simply replaces the heading to proposed division 2A. It is a very technical amendment. Amendment No. 2 is technical also. It removes a reference to subsection 232B(6) from paragraph 22BA. In amendment No. 3—and I would hope that there would be some acknowledgment of what we are doing here—we are proposing notification requirements.

Amendment No. 3 inserts new section 22EA into division 2A. That new section imposes certain notification requirements on the Commonwealth in relation to certain acts relating to mining that are attributable to the Commonwealth and took place in the period between 1 January 1994 and 23 December 1996. Amendment No. 4 does the same thing, imposing certain notification requirements on states and territories that legislate to validate intermediate period acts attributable to them. We agree that proper notification should be put in place.

BREAK.PARA: Amendment No. 50 changes the way in which the period running from 1 January 1994 and 23 December 1996 is described as a technical drafting change. Amendment No. 51 is an amendment to proposed section 232B which defines the term `category A intermediate period act'. The amendment removes subsections (5) and (6) from 232B. These subsections are to be removed out of concern that they may have resulted in the creation of some national parks being included in the definition of category A intermediate period acts. This was never the intention and the amendment simply puts that beyond doubt. Amendment 52 is a similar provision to ensure the exclusion of:
(b) the grant or vesting of any thing to or in a person to hold on trust for the benefit of Aboriginal peoples or Torres Strait Islanders; or
(c) the grant or vesting of any thing over particular land or waters, if at the time the thing covered by paragraph (a) or (b) is in effect in relation to the land or waters.

Amendment 53, the final one, amends section 232C which defines the term `category B intermediate period act'. The bill already excludes from the definition leases granted by or under legislation that grants leases only to or for the benefit of Aboriginal people or Torres Strait Islanders. The amendment will also exclude from this definition:
(iii) a lease granted to a person to hold on trust for the benefit of Aboriginal peoples or Torres Strait Islanders; or
(iv) any other lease granted over particular land or waters, if at the time a lease covered by subparagraph (ii) or (iii) is in force over the land or waters.

I would have thought that, while the Labor Party and other parties oppose our general approach to this thing, at least those amendments would be acceptable and do put in place proper notification requirements.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I must rise at this point to disagree quite strongly with what the minister said before he got on to the technical detail of his amendments. Again, we have this emotive issue of a major catastrophe if we do not pass what the government wants us to pass. I must take issue initially with the idea that somehow we are going to wipe out all these leases; that there is going to be major economic disruption. All that Aboriginal people are asking for is that the native title rights are recognised on these leases.

SPEECH.PARA: Minister, you suggested that the state governments acted in good faith. In a moment I will go through a little bit of history to show you why that simply is not the case. It was well known that this is a live issue—it was made very clear in this chamber during the Mabo debate—so let us look at what you are asking us to do. You are asking us to use our votes to retrospectively endorse various actions of state governments between the commencement of the Native Title Act and the Hight Court's decision on the Wik case. The Democrats believe that this retrospectivity, presented here as `validation of intermediate period acts', is unjust. We are very surprised indeed that the ALP is supporting you in this.

I would like to remind senators that, in 1993, parliament was aware of potential state acts which were open to challenge and had a very strong view on the matter. In presenting the government's bill to the Senate, Senator Chris Schacht tabled a second reading speech which made the point quite clearly. I will quote from that speech:
The Bill has four key aspects:
. provision for clear and certain validation of past acts—including grants and laws—if they have been invalidated because of the existence of native title.
Later on in the same second reading speech, under the title `Validation and Security for Existing Grants', he went on to say:

This Bill sets out a regime for the States to validate grants with certainty. It does not prevent States and Territories from attempting to validate on their own terms. But they would do so at their own legal risk. And the Commonwealth would obviously not, in that case, help meet any resulting costs.
Let me repeat that:
But they would do so at their own legal risk. And the Commonwealth would obviously not in that case help meet any resulting costs.
So it is clear that that was the Labor position in 1993. A line was drawn at that time and we said, `No more.'

In 1993, the Australian Democrats were also very concerned about the potential for renegade states to try to get around the Native Title Act, and we proposed a number of amendments to ensure that this did not happen. Then Senator Cheryl Kernot made our concerns clear in her speech at the second reading stage. I quote again:

At this stage the Democrats intend to move an amendment to clarify that, should there be any ambiguity in future time, the Racial Discrimination Act shall prevail because it provides protection for native title, and an overarching legislative and constitutional protection for that title is essential. It is essential to prevent capricious actions by state governments and, even in the foreseeable future, by the Commonwealth government itself.
How prophetic that statement was. There was, it turns out, no more capricious government than the Goss Labor government in Queensland.

In 1993, it was crystal clear. A majority of the parliament, over the howls of the coalition parties, decided that the line would be drawn at the time of the commencement of the 1993 act. It goes to the heart of the essential agreement between the parties in framing that original act that trade‐offs involve the agreement of indigenous communities to validation of past acts and grants in exchange for, in the future, agreeing to the right to negotiate. The coalition government, which opposed this whole issue in 1993, is now trying to water it down on both points. The ALP, by voting against the Democrats‐Greens amendment, is aiding and abetting in the process for reasons, I would argue, of pragmatism not of principle.

The Labor Party also made it crystal clear in 1993 that any state government which sought to get around this law did so at their own peril. Between 1993 and 1997, the Labor Party changed its mind somewhat. Indeed, I would argue they have gone soft on this issue. They will not do as they said they would; that is, stare down state governments who tried it on. Basically, the ALP has done a backflip on this issue by saying, `We were prepared to talk tough during the 1993 debate when the prime transgressor was the Court Liberal government, but we are not prepared to talk tough on this in 1997 when the prime transgressor is the Goss Labor government'—certainly not on the eve of an election which, we now read, is probably going to be fought in Queensland on this very issue by Premier Borbidge.

Basically, what we have is the Goss legacy which has led the ALP to be moving their own amendments and not supporting what we are arguing is directly in line with decisions taken by this chamber in 1993. They have done a 180‐degree turn from their 1993 position. Any potential claim on the converted leases which has been done in direct contravention of the Keating government's legislation, and indeed is in defiance of their direct warnings, will now be extinguished with the collusion of new Labour. I do not think, in this debate, we are going to change the Labor Party's mind because I think their priorities are set, and their priority is winning the Queensland election. Hopefully, all senators listening to this debate will understand what the government is doing. It is trying to turn around what was decided in this chamber in 1993 to the advantage of those people who are benefiting from state government decisions which are not just contrary to the act but, if anyone bothered to read the Hansards of the time, directly contrary to what was stated very clearly in this chamber as the will of this parliament.

We will be taking this issue to the vote today because it is one of the key issues. It will extinguish native title on such a broad area, particularly in Queensland, that I do not think we can let this one pass.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the issue of validation, we have seen massive loss to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders of the right to negotiate. Once again, state governments have sabotaged the native title process and will, with the assistance of both the government and the ALP, get away with it. Why is it that conservative state governments—and in this sense I include the Goss Labor government—cannot bring themselves to accept native title and simply sit down with Aboriginal people and discuss how their acts will affect traditional Aboriginal lands and people?

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Minchin said—and I would like to strongly protest his use of the terminology—that the law was changed by the Wik decision. That is nonsense. The law was unclear. Senator Minchin himself said so during the Mabo debate. In fact, he clearly said that his reading was that pastoral leases did not extinguish native title. The High Court has clarified the law; the High Court has not changed the law.

We know that in Western Australia there are many examples where the Court government have ignored the future act provisions. We know that they are, and were, sabotaging the Native Title Act. We know that there were three very expensive abortive native title High Court challenges and I think it is quite clear why the Court government in Western Australia would like to make the issue go away. But it is not going away and I stand strongly with the Australian Democrats on this issue. It is not good enough for the ALP as well to merely get into what they think is pragmatic and election politics in order to prepare for the Queensland election. This is a massive issue which sends a signal to state governments that they are not subject to Commonwealth laws. I wonder whether that is the message that the Labor Party are wanting to give to current and future state governments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —There are probably two rafts of criticism that I have to respond to and I will start with the government. This is one of those three areas which, on 25 July this year, Chief General Counsel Henry Burmester advised the government would raise problems with the Racial Discrimination Act. We say to the government: you have not treated that advice seriously enough, nor have you treated the issue of race seriously enough with respect to this bill. You want certainty, but the only certainty you will get by slavishly pursuing this particular proposal is that you will finish up in the High Court within hours of this legislation being given effect.

SPEECH.PARA: You can laugh, Senator Minchin, but we told you that was what would happen with the Hindmarsh Island Bridge Bill and that is exactly what did happen. That is going to be listed in the High Court early in February next year.
The only certainty you will get by going down your road of validation is a High Court challenge and continual arguments about the racist nature of this legislation. You will not get certainty.

You quoted former Attorney‐General Michael Lavarch and said you agreed with him, that to eradicate doubt you have to legislate in this way. Why did you not go back further to see what the previous Labor government did in terms of its validation regime? We recognise full well that, if you were to baldly validate, you would have both RDA problems and constitutional problems. That is precisely why, in formulating the 1993 legislation—and it is something you have never been able to accept—we actually put together an overall package, a special measure of overall benefit to indigenous Australians.

That is why we went to provide certainty in terms of confirmation. That is why we went to provide certainty in terms of processes. That is why we went to accept as a trade-off for their general common law rights the right to negotiate in certain areas. That is why we adopted the social justice package, which has not been delivered on. That is why we adopted the indigenous land use fund. There is a way to meet the constitutional requirements and the requirements of non-discrimination. The RDA provides that way of doing it—that is, it provides a special measure with an overall beneficial impact to the group with which you are dealing.

You are not doing that here. You say in respect of some areas that they are of benefit to some indigenous Australians. But they have told you, Australia and the world that those beneficial measures are essentially no more than embroidery. That is something that you will have to worry about if this legislation finally gets Governor-General approval, if it gets Executive Council approval. That is the one thing you will have to worry about within 24 to 48 hours of that approval. You will be in the Hight Court and you will be arguing over this particular point.

BREAK.PARA: You say that people acted in good faith and, as a consequence, have a real right to certainty. We do not disagree with that. We do not say that in all circumstances they acted in good faith, but we do understand that in most circumstances people on the ground have been the victims of this—and the major victims of this, of course, have been indigenous Australians. You go on to say that your validation regime is nowhere near as comprehensive as ours was in 1993. But, let us face it, Wik is one‐tenth of the problem that Mabo was in terms of trying to get a legislative solution. Mabo was an unprecedented decision of the High Court which laid down and confirmed in our legal system the existence of native title.

You have been asked to pick up some problems with respect to that intermediate period between the Native Title Act and this legislation. In doing that, you have used Wik as an excuse for a wholesale slaughter of the Native Title Act, and you do not pretend to do otherwise. We say to both you and the minor parties that you can validate in a constitutional, non-racist way. Our 1993 legislation was endorsed in its validity by the High Court in Western Australia and the Commonwealth, and it was endorsed particularly because of a number of factors. It did have general agreement of indigenous Australians—and that is a factor of relevance in the legal system—and it was a package overall, a special measure which acted in an overall way, to the beneficial interest of indigenous Australians. Your package does not do that. We maintain that our package does that.

We have been accused of backflips. We have been accused of pragmatism. I suppose all of us in this place by the very fact that we are in this place can be criticised for being pragmatic. Even Senator Brown, who is looking at me intently, I am sure sometimes can be accused of being pragmatic. But we are part of the parliamentary process of government and we have to confront problems.

The problems that we are confronting now are different from the problems that we confronted in 1993. The issues we are confronting now are different from those issues. The stark reality is that you have had thousands of permits, leases or whatever issued over that intermediate period. That has already happened. The other reality is that, with respect to probably 95 per cent of them, they would attract the expedited procedures provisions of the Native Title Act. With respect to the others, there might be—and I say `might be'—some issues, but the advice that we keep getting is that, apart from a small handful, there is not.

I say to you and to the parliament that, under the Native Title Act, no-one disputes that all those entitlements, interest granted, will have an ongoing effect. Section 29 notices can be issued, but those who have attracted those interests, those who have obtained those interests, will be able to keep on exercising them until those processes are completed. Let us face it: under those processes there is no right of veto. So with all those interests they will have continuing effect.

The one thing that will not be satisfied, though, under the existing act, which is what the minority parties want to pursue, is the immediate problem of indigenous Australians. Whilst those interests have been acquired and people exercise them, indigenous Australians will be waiting for compensation. Under the existing act, under the provisions that you want to protect, they will be waiting for five or 10 years to get it. What we say is that, in validating, put into place a fast track provision for compensation, the one that we are proposing, and ensure that there is some justice to those people as well. If this is the Native Title Act, that should be of immediate concern to us.

When it all boils down to it, essentially your choice is whether you make indigenous Australians wait a decade for compensation or whether you provide a fast track mechanism for them to obtain it in the immediate future. That is why I say there is a new problem here now, and the challenge for us is to see how we can tackle that with a degree of equity. The government does not provide that equity in its system. It does not provide any fast track proposal. It does not provide the pro cedural guarantees that we provide, and it is worth listing those procedural guarantees.

Those guarantees go to the capacity to protect sacred sites. They go to issues of curtailing the extent of validation. They go to issues of non-extinguishment. They go to proper processes, procedures and appeals with respect to non-genuine acts. They go to, as I say, compensation. They go to the capacity of the Federal Court to ensure some override in limited circumstances. They also go to the capacity of this matter to be resolved by agreement.

This was always going to be a three-way spat, and I suppose the surprising thing is that it has not happened earlier in the process. I do say in the spirit of some degree of cooperation here that it is very easy to accuse us of being pragmatic but, if you were an indigenous Australian, then you would want to get, I think, something out of this process. Okay, we are not pursuing the preferred model of the Indigenous Working Group here but, for those living on the ground with the consequences of this decision, let us try to provide some immediate justice for them, and that is what I say our proposal does.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell, Sen Ronald

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a brief contribution on this. The ALP amendments confirm validation for pastoral activities and pastoral leases granted before January 1994 but do not validate leases granted following government actions in the period between January 1994 and June 1996. They introduce a gazetted act to cover mining leases. These gazetted acts have conditions, and the conditions are that the government has to provide to representative bodies when issuing leases a notification of the description of land and project within four months, then there is a 90-day period for representative bodies to take action to the Federal Court.

SPEECH.PARA: I acknowledge that most people in this chamber have a legal background and I do not, but I would say with the best will in the world that Senator Bolkus seems to be prejudging what a High Court will do, and I really say to him that it is not his duty to do that. His duty is to look at the legislation, look at what he understands would be in the best interests of the Aboriginal community and the best interests of miners, and then combine that and come up with a decision. He seems to be basing his decisions on what is going to happen rather than what should happen.

I just want to say what will happen if the Labor Party amendments get up. Some 5,000 mining leases in Queensland—and I also think a great number in Western Australia—were issued or renewed between 1 January 1994 and 1996. We saw a claim on Ernest Henry mine by the Mittakoodi and Juhnjlar people and, if the government gets its legislation through, that would be prevented. I want to say to these particular people—and I do not know who they are—there were exhaustive representations—

TALK.START.PARA: —What would be prevented? Tell me.

—What would be prevented would be this claim on the Ernest Henry mine. There would be no claim if the government's legislation got up. I want to say to Senator Margetts—because I do not doubt her sincerity in this debate—that strenuous negotiations, large negotiations, went on for months and probably years between the local Aboriginal community and the Ernest Henry mine. I think there were negotiations that the Aboriginal people there got the contract to run the trucking business and they came out of it pretty well. They were happy with it. Jobs were provided for them in the mine. Then another group of people came in over the top and lodged a claim.

SPEECH.PARA: There are 5,000 mining leases in Queensland that will be affected—they will be open to claims—if the Labor Party amendments get up or Senator Margetts's amendments get up. There are a number of people out there who, going on to Christmas, will be wondering about their jobs in the mine, including the Aboriginal people who have gone into hock to buy the trucks which they probably purchased on hire purchase. They will be concerned about this claim on the Ernest Henry mine. All these mining companies do go into very long and involved negotiations with the Aboriginal people. These leases have been issued. Millions of dollars—about $304 million—have gone into this mine to get it up.

I say this to everyone in the Senate. The exploration budgets of the Australian mining companies are going up, but they are not going up as fast as they are spending money in exploration overseas. You just do not switch on a mine overnight. It takes six, seven or eight years to get it up. The exploration budgets are not being spent in Australia. They are going overseas and putting money into South America, and that is where they have got to do it. Their bottom line is that they have to do the best for their shareholders, so they are walking away from Australia. The result of that is that we are now seeing the downturn—and we will see it more in the future—of mining in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —The figures don't support that, Ron.
—The figures do support that. There is a lot of money going into mining—that is correct—but it is not going into exploration. It is going into getting the mining projects up.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Woodley will know the town of Georgetown; he has probably been there. About five or six miles out of Georgetown there was a mine called the Union mine. It was a good mine; it was a fairly new mine. There were 43 people working in the Union mine. That has been closed down now because of native title claims. There were only 43 people, and we can argue that that is not a significant number, but right throughout Australia we are going to see that. That mine sustains the economy of the town.

TALK.START.PARA: —What's that mine—Georgetown?

—Yes, the Georgetown Union mine. Those people who own the Union mine went to their local Aboriginal people, who happen to come from Mareeba, and said, `Look, if you want a job in the mine, just send the boys out and we'll give them a job. If they want a job, we'll give them a job.' If we follow this down, I think there was some movement that the Union mine might even have been used for training Aboriginal people who wanted to work in the mine.

SPEECH.PARA: I am saying this: there are 5,000 leases in Queensland that, if this legislation does not go through, are going to be under threat. Do not think that we can walk away from it. Exploration is being stopped. Jobs will be stopped. We will not feel the effects of this in the next three or four months, but there is an effect building up now. If we do not provide these jobs, we are closing down regional Australia. What follows is that the jobs will close down. I earnestly ask you to really consider what you are going to vote on in this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to put a couple of comments on the record. I do not know who the mine had consultation with, Senator Boswell. I presume they actually did have fairly extensive consultations because the manager of the mine certainly talked to me about it. However, I need to say that the Mittakoodi people are the people from around Cloncurry. In fact, I helped to establish a housing cooperative for the Mittakoodi people back in 1970.
—Didn't the Kalkadoon people come from there?

—No, they come from Mt Isa. I do not know the ins and outs of the Ernest Henry issue, but I think we need to sit down carefully with those people and find out what is going on there, because it is important that we do not hold up those kinds of developments. I offer no criticism of the mining company in this case, but we do need to sit down and work out why this hiccup has occurred.

SPEECH.PARA: There really has been, I believe, a lot of misinformation in terms of mining and what is happening to it. I will put on the record figures from the Australian Bureau of Statistics, which were released on 27 November 1997. They show that, in the four years following the Mabo decision, mining investment has gone up 110 per cent. In other words, it has more than doubled. On those figures, I do not think you could suggest that mining was not progressing. The relationship between statistics and what is happening is all to do with interpretation.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's not in exploration.

—I heard you say that, Senator Boswell, and I accept what you are saying, but that is not a problem. What I am trying to say is that, when you take figures, we can all interpret them. It is as valid for you to say what you have said, I am not denying that—what are you saying, Senator Heffernan?
—There is no greenfields development. You are talking about exploration on existing programs. Hop out of the pulpit.

—I beg your pardon! I have taken interjections from Senator Heffernan before. He seems to have an obsession with the fact that I happen to be a minister of religion, because he constantly makes references to the pulpit. I am happy for you to come and speak from my pulpit just the same as you should be happy for me to speak in this forum, Senator Heffernan. I do not know why you make these constant references to the pulpit. I find them objectionable but, if you keep on making them, I am happy to keep on answering you. Remember, I am prepared to stay here as long as it takes. I hope you are.

BREAK.PARA: I will go on. I was talking about the figures put down by my friend Senator Boswell, and I accept what he is saying. I will also put on the record that, against those, we have other statistics which show that mining has done very well in the period. I am not saying that it has done very well because of the Mabo decision. But, by the same token, it is drawing a longbow sometimes to say that, while there have been problems—and I would certainly be very disappointed in the closing down of a small mine like that at Georgetown because I know how dependent it would be on the mine. I have certainly been to Georgetown on a number of occasions. I wanted to say that.

Senator Bolkus spent 10 minutes explaining why the government is wrong in its proposals. He then spent another 10 minutes explaining why these illegal acts should be made legal. I have to say to Senator Bolkus that native title claimants have not asked for compensa tion. They have asked for a minimum for their rights in these cases. Compensation is not a second‐best option; it is a last‐but‐one worst option. However, I would ask that—and it is obvious why I would be asking this—when we come to vote on these amendments, we vote on the Democrat‐Green amendments first, then a second option we have, and then the Labor Party amendments. I make that appeal, if that were possible. I think that is all I need to say at this time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to respond to Senator Margetts about the state of the law because I think it is important to place on the record why we believe state governments acted in good faith in issuing these titles and why we are having to act the way we are now that the Wik decision has occurred. I remind you that the preamble to the Native Title Act passed by this parliament says:

SPEECH.PARA: The High Court has:

(c) held that native title is extinguished by valid government acts that are inconsistent with the continued existence of native title rights and interests, such as the grant of freehold or leasehold estates.
Former Prime Minister Keating said in his second reading speech on the Native Title Act:
I draw attention also to the recording in the preamble of the bill of the government's view that under the common law past valid freehold and leasehold grants extinguish native title.

As to Senator Margetts's objection to my statement that the law was changed, I am a humble former solicitor. I refer you to the opinion of the Solicitor‐General, Dr Gavan Griffith, probably Australia's most experienced constitutional lawyer. He said in his opinion on the Native Title Amendment Bill:

Somewhat unexpectedly, a bare majority in Wik peoples versus Queensland (1996) 141 ALR 191 (Wik) held that the grant of pastoral leases under Queensland law did not confer exclusive possession and therefore did not necessarily extinguish native title rights and interests. I say unexpectedly because, as the powerful dissent of the Chief Justice confirms, the effect of Wik (with its recognition of coexistence, factual enquiry and possible revival) effectively overruled much of which had been stated in Mabo as basic principle for the recognition and extinguishment of native title rights.

So it is not my humble view—it is the view of the Solicitor‐General of Australia that that is what occurred. We accept that it has occurred. The whole point of the Native Title Amendment Bill is to acknowledge that legal fact and to incorporate the Wik decision into the Native Title Act. But in so doing, one of the fundamentals problems we have to deal with is the validation of acts and leases and things issued in good faith in that intermediate period. That is the effect of these provisions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Briefly—and I am sure Senator Cooney would like to mention this too—in the words of Mandy Rice‐Davies, Gavan Griffith would say that, wouldn't he. He was counsel for the Commonwealth in that case. What else would you expect him to say except that he was surprised? I remind Senator Minchin that he himself in the debate in Mabo said that the words in the preamble were not sufficient to remove unclear issues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —The Solicitor‐General, Gavan Griffith, is a very eminent constitutional lawyer, a member of the Melbourne bar before he came here and a most honourable man. What he has said is quite correct, that what the High Court does is never known until the High Court delivers the judgment; that the High Court itself does not know until that happens. There is one point I want to make about that and it is this: if the High Court says the law is the law, that is it. There has been an attitude taken where people say, `Well, look, the High Court in some way did the wrong thing in coming to the decision it did in Wik.' That is not right. What it did was apply the law as it is. To say, `Look, there is a four‐three split,' seems to me to be quite beside the point because the constitutional balance requires it to do that.

SPEECH.PARA: No doubt people have been disappointed over the years with decisions in tax cases and what have you. The position of saying, `Look, we all thought the law was one way until the High Court decided it and therefore we should change the law,' has dangers not only here but also in tax cases. There have been tax cases where the parliament has changed the law and changed it retrospectively. There is no doubt that in this case the parliament proposes to change the law retrospectively, and that is a bad thing.

Many of the comments since Wik have risked prejudicing the standing the High Court deserves to have in the public view. It must have this standing in the public eye for the well-being of Australia. As a parliament we have not fulfilled our function of giving the High Court the support we should have as one of the three arms of government. I think we have failed in that. I just make that point. Parliament can change the law relating to those matters over which it has power, but it should not change the law on the basis that the High Court has somehow done the wrong thing or the reprehensible thing. That is not correct. The High Court has acted in a very honourable, proper and direct way in the decision it has made on the matter of Wik.
While I am in the mode of vindicating things, I noticed in the Herald‐Sun this morning this statement:
Senator Brian Harradine's role in the point‐by‐point destruction of the Howard Government's Wik legislation makes a mockery of the democratic system.

I would have thought that Senator Harradine is one senator amongst others. To blame him for, as it were, determining the fate of the nation is a wrong assessment of what goes on. We are all here as senators and we all should take a position according to our consciences.

I also want to get into a parochial mode. The debate concerns all Australia, but a lot of the examples are taken from Queensland and Western Australia. I just want to put in a plea for Victoria. I notice Mr Geoff Clark is in the gallery. He has done great work, as have others, for the indigenous community in Victoria. Victoria has a very big indigenous community. It does not have any pastoral leases, but it has other problems that have to be solved, such as the closure of government roads and whether farmers can use them for transit and what have you. Although Queensland and Western Australia are great states, we have our problems and relationships to solve in Victoria. I have noticed Geoff Clark. I might also mention Monica Morgan and the Yorta Yorta tribe. They have done great work there.

I would like to do something now that will require the leave of the Senate. To show we have a big indigenous group in Victoria, I have some documents here which are headed up `Petition' but which do not, by any means, conform to the way petitions ought to be got together. I have shown this to various people around the chamber. It is a non-broadcast day. I seek leave of the Senate to table what is headed up as `Petition' but is really not a petition from a young man Damien Cook from Castlemaine. There are all sorts of addresses here from people all over the great state of Victoria. You would appreciate this, Senator McGauran.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bartlett, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is important to emphasise what the Senate is discussing at this stage in the Native Title Amendment Bill under the general heading that is being used of `validation'. What we are talking about is whether or not the Senate—as Senator Cooney pointed out, it is a decision for the whole Senate; it is not all of us sitting here watching what one particular person might do—should support retrospectively validating illegal grants of mining permits.

SPEECH.PARA: I wanted to speak on this in particular because it is an issue that is particularly relevant to Queensland. Western Australia is the other state that is mentioned a lot. I take very seriously the responsibility I have of representing my state. I think it is important that someone stand up in this chamber to speak for justice for indigenous people in Queensland. The Democrats are doing that.

It is important to stress again in this debate that of the many amendments that this chamber has introduced to this bill this one is the one where there is a very clear divide between what the Democrats, the Greens and the Labor Party are apparently agreeing to do on this matter. I think it is important to emphasise why the Labor Party is taking this course of action. It is a sad course of action it seems determined to take. Certainly journal ists who have been following the debate so far know why. An example of this insight was Margo Kingston's article on Thursday last week, which had the headline `Labor puts principles through hoops'. It said in part:
Kim Beazley, a pro-development man clinging to a marginal seat in the rabidly anti-Wik State of Western Australia, was desperate to do a deal with the Coalition.
His deputy Gareth Evans was equally hard‐headed—and made a personal offer to negotiate privately to John Howard at US President Bill Clinton's dinner at Parliament House.
Howard's response was to reveal that Evans had told him not to worry about "Daryl", his firebrand Aboriginal Affairs spokesman.
Ms Kingston went on to say:
The Left did get rolled—on validation of the States' illegal grants of mining permits since 1994.

This was because Labor feared it would blow its chances at the pending Queensland election. Labor also got rolled on the right to negotiate over coastal waters. That is basically it in a nutshell. The Labor spokesperson on Aboriginal affairs and the shadow Attorney‐General were rolled by the right‐wing leadership group of the Labor Party.

Why are the ghosts of the last Queensland election so haunting the leadership of the ALP that they will backflip on this key principle? Again, it is important to emphasise that this issue we are discussing now is a key principle. It is worth a quick reminder of the context behind this.

Labor now holds only two House of Representative seats in Queensland and one of those, the seat of Brisbane, would have been lost if not for the flow of Democrat preferences to the sitting member, Arch Bevis—something I am well aware of because I was the Democrat candidate for that seat at the last election. Labor knew they were on the nose in Queensland for many months before the fall of the Keating government. After all, in 1995 the Goss government had managed to turn a healthy lead in the election campaign into a near loss and eventually defeat thereby surpassing, outperforming or underperforming, depending on what you want to call it, even the mediocre performances of Nick Greiner before him and John Wayne Olsen fairly recently after him.

BREAK.PARA: At that time Mr Goss and Queensland Labor blamed Paul Keating for their defeat. Perhaps there was some truth in this assertion because the then Deputy Prime Minister, Kim Beazley, was wheeled in to try to stem the tide and Mr Keating was kept out of the state of Queensland. I guess it must have been a bitter experience for Mr Beazley. Not only did Wayne Goss lose office around the time just leading into the 1996 federal election after the Mundingburra by-election, but Mr Beazley himself could not hold back the tide at all from the federal poll in March of that year. It seems the spectre of a repeat, where Labor is kept out of office in the imminent round of state and federal elections, because of Queensland, must haunt the opposition leader in a very personal way.

After all, as we know, the National Party Premier, Mr Borbidge, has already declared his eagerness to run native title as the central issue in the next state election in Queensland. I and the Democrats as a party have been very critical for some time of Mr Borbidge's inflammatory actions on this issue, but at least he has displayed his colours and made clear where he stands, unlike the state Labor leader, Mr Beattie, who has been unfortunately quiet on the native title issue. He seems unfortunately reluctant to speak up for the key issues of justice that are at stake here. Again, they are at stake in this issue as much as any other in the entire bill.

The Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Mr Gareth Evans, under pressure on this issue, explains it away as just a decision of a party which is an alternative government—this pragmatism that Senator Bolkus was referring to before. I also see this as a sideswipe at the Democrats which is not unexpected, I suppose, coming from Mr Evans, but it says more about Labor than it does about my own party. It gives a big signal as to what Labor would be like if they got back into government—that is, they will be the same as they have always been: selling out on core principles as soon as they sense that votes or corporate dollars in donations may be at risk. A reasonable interpretation of Mr Evans's comments is simply to say that Labor will continue to do whatever it takes to get elect ed, even at the expense of those they claim to champion—in this case, indigenous Australians.

With that background, an explanation of the ALP's clear motive in basically supporting this reprehensible section of this bill—which is, in my view, a form of retrospective extinguishment by governments that refused to follow the processes that were laid out in the original Native Title Act and just wanted to do it their own way, because they did not want to have to negotiate and did not want to talk to indigenous people—is that they just wanted to help the mining companies.

I would like to direct my final comment to Senator Bolkus. I know that you have to put up a good show in this debate, as is your role, just as my predecessor must now also toe the line of the party that she is now in, if she is to get on—no matter how offensive the policy decision is. I am sorry that you were rolled, but you must understand that the Democrats must take this issue to a vote to have it clearly on the public record that Beazley's Labor senators went soft in a spectacular way on a key matter of principle and in doing so caused a great injustice. It is a shame to me, as a Queensland senator, that this betrayal of justice will have such particular impacts on my home state. Just as Labor did on work for the dole, now this backflip seems to have happened. The reasons for doing it seem to be remarkably similar.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not going to rise to speak in this debate again and I will make these comments very brief. I sat here and copped a bit of criticism, but can I say to the last speaker that we have actually spent 25 or maybe 30 hours on the debate so far and I have got to say that, on one point or another, all contributions actually addressed something that we needed to address. I have got to say to Senator Bartlett that that was probably the worst contribution that we have had in the debate. I say that in a spirit of being constructive because I think perhaps you can learn from this.

SPEECH.PARA: If you were to look at the public record, on 4 April this year the Labor Party, under the signatures of the leader, Kim Beazley, Gareth Evans, myself and Daryl Melham, put out a statement. In that statement we made it very clear that we were going down this road in terms of intermediate period act validation. That was an agreed position some seven months ago and it was a position that was adopted by the party just a few weeks ago. We have some 350 or so amendments and I think it has been an enormous management and policy achievement to be able to get primarily the four people involved agreed on all those amendments. I, in no way, feel as if I have been rolled. Anyone who thinks they can roll Daryl is probably deluding themselves.

Let us put on the record, and in the spirit of non‐confrontation, that this has been a long‐stated position of the party. It has been a long‐stated position because right from the start we have been trying to confront the new issues, as opposed to merely defending something that might be in legislation but which we thought did not provide a constructive outcome at this particular stage. In saying that we understand quite clearly that the indigenous working groups have a different position. Can I say to you that the degree of cooperation between them and us, in terms of the overall package and an ongoing relationship, recognises there are some differences, but we are working constructively together in a very friendly atmosphere and very few of them, if any, confronted us with those same allegations. Senator Bartlett, I understand why you are saying it, but let me put it to you that you are a bit unfair.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is reasonable for us to ask Senator Bolkus to explore that a little bit further given that this is a very major departure from the working group's position and certainly from our position. To dismiss this as being a small difference which we all need to bear is pretty unreasonable. As I understand it—I will go back over what my colleague Senator Lees has said, and others here today—the validation of past acts between 1975 and 1992 was agreed to by indigenous people on the understanding that there would be a strong right to negotiate. That was ultimately reflected in the Native Title Act. My question is: why is the ALP now re‐opening what was a deal at that time? I understand that deal involved Mr Keating at the time. Doesn't that represent a major sell‐out of that deal? How does your position sit given that we are yet to debate the question of the right to negotiate?

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me that this is a sell‐out, and it may in fact be a worse sell‐out than what we are looking at now. When we get to that point of debating the right to negotiate, if that is lost, what does this represent in terms of the agreement which was reached earlier? Am I missing the point here about negotiating? We are owed a further explanation from the ALP about that position.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I say to you, Senator, that it was not all that long ago that I actually went through the reasons why we have taken our position. I can spend another 15 minutes doing that, but can I suggest to you that the best way to get the answer is that I will send you the pinks from my earlier contribution in the debate. I really have nothing further to add than what I have said. I have comprehensively gone through our position and explained why we think it is a position that is a better one now. You can ask all the questions you like, and I am sure Senator Brown will get up and ask me a question as well, but the record and the debate on this particular point has been adequately addressed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I return to the position that concerns me fundamentally about this debate, and that is the absence of an indigenous voice in this chamber. If I were a member of the indigenous community at this stage, I would be thinking back to 1993 and the passage of the Native Title Act and the expectation that this was going to be a balanced outcome leading to a negotiated process for the establishment of a native title claim as well as for the progress of the interests of pastoralists, miners and other stakeholders. That expectation has led to three years in which, at best, one or two small claims have gone the way of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. But we are discussing here more than 20,000 mining and pastoral lease determinations being given. That is the balance that we have seen in the last four years. That is about 20 per day, if you do a rough calculation.

SPEECH.PARA: The position for the indigenous people who have found their law being repeatedly overridden by the laws of materialism, which are core to our society and which are so often determined in this place, is that they had to then go to the courts to get a determination as to whether or not those 20,000 leases to mining and pastoral interests, licences and determinations did shut them out. They felt that surely this could not be so after the promise of 1993.

Right through this process, right up to the High Court, all stakeholders knew that there was a question mark over this. Yet Senator Minchin says that it was done in good faith. The Labor Party says likewise. I say that it was done in the expectation that the indigenous interests would be extinguished. But the High Court found that that was not the case. It determined that there is an indigenous interest here, even under our system of laws. There was a renewed feeling that something would go the indigenous people's way in this process.

Here we are today saying, `We'll deal with that. We'll retrospectively take away the rights that the indigenous people had over those three years. We'll retrospectively validate the illegal, because that is in the interests of this materialist society.' The land users see the country which the indigenous people have such a deep, ancient, cultural and spiritual attachment to as a place for sustenance and the making of money. That must prevail. That is what this is about. That is why the two great parties, the big, old parties, are saying, `We are going to retrospectively change the law so that those moneyed interests get their way over the spiritual and traditional interests of the indigenous people. It was even illegal under our laws, so we will change our laws not now and into the future but retrospectively.' If I were an indigenous person under those circumstances, I would feel crushed and demoralised.

I wonder how they can keep going. It is a remarkable testimony to their spirit and their attachment to the land that long ago they did not take other forms of action to be part of this process, which comes under the much abused word `reconciliation'. The Labor Party may not like this, but it is on trial, along with the Liberal Party and Senator Harradine, in this circumstance. We are saying to the indigenous people of this country, `Yes, you had to go to our courts to get justice. However, now that you have it, we in this parliament are going to retrospectively take it away from you again.' That is what this is about. It is nothing more and nothing less. It makes me ashamed to be a part of this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, you're quite welcome to leave, of course.

—I have no doubt that that interjection from the senator opposite would be put to an indigenous person were that person here. That person would be told, `You are quite welcome to leave this place, you are quite welcome to stay out of the courts and you are quite welcome to leave your land. Just get out of our way, because you are in the way.' That is the sentiment of the majority in this place today.

SPEECH.PARA: The saving grace is that there is a different voice in this place. Perhaps it is appropriate that it is a minority voice. Perhaps we can take strength from the indigenous people by saying that, minority or not, we are here, we are going to stay, and we will persist.

The government has said that it is matter of ensuring certainty of the law. For whom? It is for the miners in particular, and for some pastoral companies. Don't indigenous people deserve certainty in the law? How is it that when they get it we retrospectively take it away from them? There is no doubt that what is happening here now is racially discriminatory, and this parliament is doing it.

I hope that in some way or other it can be rectified further down the line. I say that to Senator Harradine, as well as to the other components of this majority. What is happening here is racially discriminatory. It is retrospectively taking legal entitlements from one group and giving them to another on racial lines.

The minister said that human beings are involved in this process. That was a some what revealing and unintended statement. Human beings are involved, and they are spread right across this country. They have been here for aeons, and they must be wondering about the shallowness of the behaviour of the newcomers who act in this fashion.

There is one other recourse to our own laws, rules and regulations which I want to bring up here—the standing orders of this place. The standing orders say that, in debating any matters at all, and certainly in voting on them—and I note that there is a vote to come on this because the Greens and the Democrats feel so strongly about this issue—senators should declare any relevant interest in such a situation.

I give notice to senators, some of whom I presume have an interest in pastoral companies, mining companies or other entities which are advantaged in some way or other by this vote, that they will be expected to declare that interest before they vote.

If that is defeated we would then deal with the ALP's very compromised position, and then finally deal with the government's position. I trust that that is acceptable to the committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Greens‐Democrat amendments 7 to 10 are in fact a representation of an extraordinary generosity on behalf of the National Indigenous Working Group. I would like to explain that the National Indigenous Working Group has accepted the potential to validate low impact acts and acts which fall under a limited definition of pastoral activity—as in the Northern Territory act—under this act.

SPEECH.PARA: The level of generosity now being offered is an extraordinary level of compromise; it is not, I do not think, anyone's preferred option. It does not, as has been suggested, even require or demand any full right to negotiate. What it is saying is that there should be six months in which the various parties can reach agreement. I do not think that is an unreasonable thing to ask.

Amendment 8 provides a mechanism for governments to validate certain intermediate period acts by agreement. It would be activated by the government giving notice to the representative body within three months of the commencement of the new provision. It involves negotiations for up to six months from the date of commencement of the section and it gives the government an incentive to move promptly to identify relevant acts and to seek validation by agreement.

Amendment 9 replaces the government's complex scheme under section 22B based on the current past act categories with a simple provision which states that the non‐extinguishment principle applies to any validated intermediate period acts. Amendment 7 is a consequential amendment removing the definitions of the various categories of intermediate period acts. Amendment 10 is also a consequential amendment. There is an amendment 11 but the reason that is not being moved with the other group at the moment is that, along with amendment 176 and amendment 250 and 253, they are identical to those of the ALP. We will be dealing with those subsequently.

I urge the Senate to accept this level of compromise and generosity. It seems the generosity is all one‐sided at the moment and the very least the Senate can do is accept what, for many people, is a fairly difficult decision. I know, also from the point of view of the Greens (WA), this is a very difficult compromise for us to reach.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition has a raft of amendments here. The current situation with respect to renewals and extensions is somewhat anomalous under the existing act. The renewal of validated past acts are wider in range and less beneficial to Aboriginal and native title holders, and there are narrow provisions in the future acts regime. Renewals currently arising from validated past acts are not limited, as they are for future acts, to commercial, agricultural, pastoral and residential leases. That is where we start from. Where we get to with the government's proposals is, once again, on the road to curtailment, infringement and incursion upon indigenous Australian rights.

SPEECH.PARA: I note that, with respect to a lot of the opposition amendments, Senator Harradine has moved amendments that are similar in nature, and I will note those as I go along through the list of concerns that we have before I get to the major concern we have with these proposals. In terms of the time period for renewals, regrants and extensions of leases, both Senator Harradine and the opposition oppose a capacity the government is trying to legislate for—that is, for renewals to be of a longer period and, in fact, to lead to a perpetual lease arrangement.

BREAK.PARA: A second concern we have is the government's proposals extend the date for legally enforceable rights to be created. We see this as unnecessary. It has nothing to do with Wik. Basically, it extends the validation regime further to include the relevant time for the definition of validated past acts to include rights that are legally enforceable as of 23 December 1996 rather than 1 January 1994. Basically, it tries to render inoperative for more than a two-year period—almost a three-year period—the operations of the Native Title Act with respect to this area. That is something for which there really is no justification at all.

The third concern is that the government's proposal further expands the concept of renewals, regrants and extensions of leases, licences and permits. Basically, the concept is going to be broadened under proposed section 24GB, GD, GE or HA to include acts consisting of primary production, off‐farm activities, rights to third parties on pastoral leases to remove timber, quarries, et cetera, and provisions relating to the management of water and airspace. We think that is too broad. Once again, it has nothing to do with Wik. It far outreaches the ambit of Wik. There is no need to extend it to such a broad activity.

The government also wants to allow renewals up to the level of primary production. Their qualification is, for so long as the majority of the area covered by the new pastoral and agricultural lease is still for primary production activities, the renewal can be for a range of activities as wide as that. We obviously have a concern with that.

As I said earlier, you are talking here of acquiring people's property rights in a racially discriminatory manner, and you are doing so retrospectively. If anything has been formulated to incur problems in the High Court, this particular provision will be it. It is racially discriminatory. It is retrospective. It is an acquisition of property rights. It is an acquisition for which no just terms compensation in terms of the processes required by the constitution are made available. Once again, we have the government's ambit claim to extinguish in these circumstances. There is no justification for extinguishment here.

The major concern that people should have about this particular part of the legislation is the effect that it would have to mining and lease renewals. Currently, the right to negotiate does not permit a renewal or an extension of a right to mine other than where such a right was created in the actual instrument, the lease or whatever, which created the original right to mine. That is provided for in section 26(1)(c). Section 24(1)(c) permits the renewal or extension of any right to mine by deeming it a permissible future act, removing it from the NTA protection, particularly to the right to negotiate.

Our proposal is different from the government's because we exclude mining leases from the application of section 24(1)(c), that is our amendment R79, whilst the government's proposal permits renewals of mining leases without native title holders having resort to the future act protection of the Native Title Act. This, I pretend to the Senate, is a much more damaging infringement of native title interests than the previous one. It is much more damaging and ongoing and has a lasting effect in an area which potentially could provide indigenous Australians with some degree of satisfaction by having the right to negotiate operating in an ongoing manner in real live developing situations.

For the record, let me state that this has not seemed to have got the attention that the previous proposal did. As I say, this is an ongoing concern. The right to negotiate will be removed from an area of renewals in respect of mining leases in an area which is of ongoing, critical concern to indigenous Australians. We oppose the renewal and we do so for a number of reasons.

Mining leases are in a category of their own. Whilst the area of the lease may remain the same upon renewal, no-one doubts that the activity grows, develops, extends and expands in a whole range of different ways. The activity of a renewed lease can be quite different—enormously different—from that of the original lease. This renewed lease activity may include impacts which, for instance, have a substantially greater effect upon native title. You may move from an underground mine to an open cut mine and that is quite common as high grade seams are mined out. This has a direct impact on indigenous Australians.

The mine may be substantially increased in size. It may entail the retention of a substantially larger work force and the construction of mining towns and infrastructure. There are consequential environmental and social impacts—such as liquor outlets, people visiting and desecrating sacred sites and the wholesale change in the way of life of native title holders. This is all due to the pressures created by growing work forces. As I say, mining operations grow in size and in impact and there needs to be some check, some capacity for indigenous Australians to have their rights heard in respect of renewals on mining leases. They need a right to negotiate in these activities.

There can be changes in technology and techniques, such as different methods of waste disposal. Other variables may occur over the long life of a mine. These changes all have a potentially serious implication for native title holders, yet the government wants to deny them the right to negotiate over these impacts when the renewal period eventually arises. To add insult to injury here, what is the government seeking to do? It is seeking to apply the renewal and extension provisions to mining leases that have been validated under the past and perhaps the intermediate period act regimes. As I said, the denial of the right to negotiate in respect of areas which have been upgraded by this government's legislation is the final insult to indigenous Australians.

So we say that the government is acting in a discriminatory manner. There is no fairness in this provision. There is an ongoing incursion of native title rights—much more than in the previous subject discussed in this committee, a subject which seemed to attract more interest than this one. I say to those who were concerned about that to have some real concerns for yourselves in respect of this proposal. There is no pressing need for such a further inroad into the rights of indigenous Australians.

What is happening here is that people are being given rights at the expense of native title holders in a manner which is discrimina tory. For instance, leaseholders under the existing law cannot just expand or extend their leases over private freehold land without negotiating further. Why should these interests be able to extend their leases to perpetual ones? Why should they be able to extend in respect of mining when there are so many new factors to be taken into account? Why should we allow permanent extinguishment in respect of these native title rights? The question to be asked by all of us is this: why should Australian taxpayers be asked to compensate big mining companies and major interests for something which is in no way justifiable and in no way fair? Indigenous Australians are being whacked around the ears consistently by this legislation, but the people who have to pay the compensation claim for those brutal assaults are the taxpayers in the suburbs of Sydney and the taxpayers in rural and regional Australia.

There is no justification for this. I am glad to see Senator Harradine has proposed some amendments, some of which go close enough to our position that we will support them. Some of them are identical and obviously we will support them. I do say to Senator Harradine that the renewal of mining leases is something of ongoing and critical concern and it does have serious implications.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I am speaking to the Democrat-Greens (WA) amendments. They are identical to the Labor Party's amendments, so we will be supporting those.
—You must be selling out.

—I do not think so, Senator Bolkus, but if you could explain in what way we are I would be happy to listen. We find we can vote with you on these because you are doing the right thing. That is the issue at hand.

SPEECH.PARA: In the present Native Title Act, section 235(7) was a Democrat amendment in 1993. At that time, my colleague the former Senator Sid Spindler spoke in the chamber on this and what he said is worth putting on the record again. He stated:

The removal of the provisions of the government's amendment, according to our legal advice, made it impossible legally to grant the new lease. It was therefore thought imperative to rectify this situation. Democrat amendment No. 53 has been arrived at to cure that possible danger. The amendment includes in the `permissible future act' the renewals, re‐grants and extensions of commercial, agricultural, pastoral or residential leases. This is provided the granting of the lease does not create a proprietary interest where previously the interest had been a non‐proprietary one and provided that it does not create a larger proprietary interest than was previously created by the lease.
In other words, at the time, Senator Spindler was saying that the renewal will be valid as long as it does not change the nature of the lease. He went on at that time:

In addition, the amendment ensures that where the lease contains a reservation or condition for the benefit of Aboriginals or Torres Strait Islanders, the renewed, re-granted or extended lease contains the same reservation or condition. This would probably have been the case anyway but the inclusion of that clause, which I am glad to say I took a personal interest in, makes sure of that. I believe that this amendment is important. I commend it to the coalition parties and in particular to those National Party senators who crossed the floor last time. This amendment satisfies a number of interests including those of the Aboriginal people and native titleholders concerned, as well as those of the pastoral industry.

Although we were rarely given credit for it, what this Democrat amendment in 1993 secured for these leaseholders is that presently, as the law exists today, they are able to renew their existing lease on the same terms and conditions—and I stress that—without attracting the right to negotiate. We note especially the support of the National Party in 1993 for this Democrat amendment.

During the earlier debates on this bill, I pointed out the almost total abstinence and, indeed, negligence of the coalition in dealing with the 1993 Native Title Bill. I make the point that the Labor Party, the Australian Democrats and the Australian Greens have not behaved in the same way as the coalition did four years ago. We have moved many amendments; we have worked hard and long; we have certainly not ignored the debate. In that way, I believe that we have certainly participated in a far more constructive way in this particular debate than the coalition did four years ago.

BREAK.PARA: However, I note that the crossing of the floor by Senator O'Chee, Senator Sandy Macdonald and Senator McGauran in 1993, if my memory serves me correctly, was a notable exception to the delaying and blocking tactics of the then opposition, now the government. Through the course of the present debate, I cannot help wondering whether this amendment bill which we are presently debating is what the coalition, when they were in opposition, might have moved as amendments if they had had a mind to it then. However, we will never know. I have to say that part of the scaremongering that has gone on has included the mythology that leases on existing terms cannot be renewed on the same terms and conditions. This is manifestly inaccurate, as is known by those government senators who crossed the floor when they were in opposition to vote with the Democrats in 1993.

The purpose of these amendments is to reverse the unwarranted expansion of the current renewal provisions. The existing Native Title Act is maintained by reference to a legally enforceable right created before the Native Title Act was brought into being, and a no larger proprietary interest than the original interest. However, the government's proposed amendments expand the current provisions by allowing an upgrade to a perpetual lease and, in some cases, to what is effectively freehold title.

I will very quickly run through the amendments so that they are on the record. Amendment No. 64 is a minor consequential amendment following amendment No. 65. Amendment No. 65 removes the unnecessary provision and extension of renewals provisions based on an offer, commitment, arrangement or undertaking, as opposed to a legally enforceable right. Amendment No. 66 removes the extension of the renewals provisions to cover a licence, permit or authority; that is, in addition to covering leases. Amendment No. 67 reverses the extension of the applicable date—that is, from the proposed Wik decision date of 23 December 1996—back to the current date of 1 January 1994.

Amendments Nos 68 to 77 are minor consequential amendments. Amendment No. 78 removes the upgrade to a longer term and removes the upgrade to perpetual leases. Amendment No. 79 is a minor consequential amendment. Amendment No. 80 removes the proposed extension of renewals to allow upgrade to non‐primary production activity if associated with, or incidental to, primary production. Amendment No. 81 removes the provision which ensures that upgrades to freehold under this subdivision extinguish native title. Amendments Nos 82 and 83 ensure that the non‐extinguishment principle applies to all renewals under the subdivision, including upgrades to freehold.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —These proposals by the government, under the heading of renewals and extensions, clearly are not just about providing any sort of certainty for pastoralists. In the opinion of the Greens (WA)—and this has come from discussions with the National Indigenous Working Group—they are an unwarranted expansion of the current renewal provisions.

SPEECH.PARA: We should not be looking at larger proprietary interests than exist already. The government's proposals expand the current provisions by allowing an upgrade to a perpetual lease and, in some circumstances, to freehold. This is not anything to do with the native title or concerns about existing provisions. It is a convenient excuse for a number of interests to get, by using the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 , something that they have probably wanted to get into land acts. The fact that they may or may not be in state land acts, I guess, may well be a matter of time.

I strongly support what has been said by Senator Woodley. As is indicated on the running sheet, the Greens-Democrats amendments are in fact identical to those of the opposition. We ask that the Senate support our stand that the Senate not use this bill as an excuse to change or authorise a different type of lease from that which exists already for pastoralists.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak briefly on this section relating to renew als and extensions. I will briefly describe to the committee what these provisions are designed to do. 24IA, future acts, simply makes it clear the type of future acts that the subdivision applies to. They are future acts linked in some way to rights granted in the past. They are pre‐existing rights based acts such as the exercise of a legal enforceable right giving effect to a past option and renewals which are currently provided for in sections 25 and 23(5) and (7). We are doing this here because, as has been said, renewals are covered in the validation regime in the current act. That is in section 228. They are allowed if they have been validated by the current act but, if they were always valid, then they are only partly covered by the future act regime. So again you get this problem of a distinction between valid acts and validated acts, which we regard as anomalous.

SPEECH.PARA: 24IB relates to pre‐existing right based acts. I apologise for the continuation of the most extraordinary language that this act has, but it is necessary to ensure we know what we are talking about. That section provides that certain types of future acts linked in some way to rights granted in the past are valid. First, in the exercise in the future of a legally enforceable right created before 23 December 1996, the right must have been validly granted or validated. That would include a legally enforceable right under a contract to obtain a lease from the Crown. Secondly, in giving effect to an offer, commitment, arrangement or undertaking made before the date of the Wik decision, the offer must have been made in good faith. It must have been validly made or validated and would include a good faith offer by the Crown to grant a lease. Again, it is to remove the anomalous distinction between validated and valid acts.

24IC allows for renewals of existing interests as valid future acts which, as has been said, are currently allowed in part by sections 25 and 23(5) and (7). 24IC would cover renewal, re‐grant, remaking or extension of a valid, including validated, lease, licence, permit or authority. The original lease needs to have been granted before the date of the Wik decision to itself have been a permissible lease for renewal or to have come within one of the primary production provisions. The renewal of the lease cannot confer a right of exclusive possession, a larger proprietary interest or a proprietary interest where none had existed before the date. Any reservation for Aboriginal people needs to be continued. If the original lease did not allow mining, the renewed lease cannot. But, of course, mining leases can themselves be renewed as is the case under the current act.

24ID sets out the effect of a renewal permitted by subdivision I on native title. The renewal is valid if the renewal allows the grant of a freehold estate or a lease providing exclusive possession. That will extinguish native title but that will only be possible because of a pre‐existing right based act such as where there is a legal enforceable right granted before 23 December 1996. Other than that limited class, the non‐extinguishment principle applies. There can be no extinguishment by the renewal of a pastoral lease or other non‐exclusive possession lease, and compensation is always payable. I move:
(25A) Schedule 1, item 9, page 55 (line 17), before "in giving", insert "in good faith".
(25B) Schedule 1, item 9, page 58 (after line 17), at the end of section 24ID, add:

PARA.TAB: (3) If paragraph 24IB(b) applied in relation to the future act, then, before the act is done, the person proposing to do the act must:

TAB.TAB: (a) notify, in the way determined in writing by the Commonwealth Minister, any representative Aboriginal/Torres Strait Islander bodies, registered native title bodies corporate and registered native title claimants in relation to the land or waters that will be affected by the act that the act, or acts of that class, are to be done in relation to the land or waters concerned; and
(b) give them an opportunity to comment on the act or class of acts.

SPEECH.PARA: 25A is an amendment to paragraph 24IB(b). That paragraph provides that a future act is a pre‐existing right based act if it takes place in giving effect to, or otherwise because of, an offer, commitment, arrangement or undertaking made or given in good faith on or before 23 December 1996 and of which there is written evidence created at or about the time the offer was made. The amendment proposed would require that, in addition to the offer having been given in good faith, the future act that is done in giving effect to that offer must also be done in good faith. That puts beyond doubt that this subsection only applies to future acts done in good faith.

25B is an amendment to section 24ID. It will insert certain notification requirements in relation to these kinds of future acts. The new notification requirements will apply to future acts that take place in good faith in giving effect to an offer, commitment, arrangement or undertaking given in good faith on or before the date of the Wik decision and of which there is written evidence. The notification requirements will require that, before a future act of one of these kinds is done, the person proposing to do the future act must notify in the way determined by the Commonwealth minister any relevant rep bodies, registered native title bodies corporate and registered claimants that the act or acts of that class are to be done and give them an opportunity to comment on the act or class of acts.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the opposition's view that at least one of these amendments, even if we adopt it now, will conflict with amendments of the opposition and Senator Harradine in respect of the continuing operation of 24IB(b). It might be appropriate to leave government amendments until after we have put the amendments of the opposition, Senator Harradine and the Greens. We will then come back to them to see if they are still needed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I have amendment No. 13. It is correct what Senator Bolkus says. The minister's amendments would conflict with that. I suppose the reason for that is that there have been discussions in respect of this matter and the government has seen the points that I was making. The point I was making about my proposed amendment 13 related to the definition of `pre‐existing right‐based act' being extended to included acts giving effect to an undertaking made in good faith but with an erroneous understanding, in hindsight I guess, of the law prior to Wik. Those similar expansive terms appear in the definition of a `past act' in section 228(3) of the Native Title Act.
