There is no case for repetition of such provision given that the Native Title Act has been fully operational since 1 January 1994. They are not right‐based acts but legally misconceived acts based on a gentleman's agreement.

SPEECH.PARA: The points I was making have been taken into account by the government. The government's amendments 25A and 25B, I think, cover the situation. They certainly cover that situation. I will be proceeding with amendments 14 and 15 on the sheet. I believe the government is going to agree to amendment No. 15 in any event. I seek clarification from the minister in respect of my amendment No. 15 so as to get that out of the road.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —We regard amendment 15 as a technical amendment and have no objection to that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine might be satisfied, but I have to say that from our perspective we are not. What our amendments 71 and 72 do—and they are the ones that Senator Harradine said are covered by his amendment 13—is focus on something of real concern; that is, the government's proposals extend the renewal provisions to cover offers, commitments, arrangements or undertakings. In many circumstances, they may not be legally enforceable rights. What section 228 relates to are legally binding undertakings, which I think Senator Harradine mentioned—in fact, I think it is 241 rather than 228—and what his amendment 13 relates to. What the government seeks to do is import into this a capacity to renew interest based on a feeling that there has been an offer, commitment, arrangement or undertaking.

SPEECH.PARA: If you go with your amendment, Senator Harradine, you will be allowing a whole new class of interests to be validated where there has been nothing more than maybe an arrangement, one which is not legally enforceable. I think it is important if you want certainty in this area to have the line in the sand drawn on the basis of whether a right is legally enforceable or not. It is important for certainty, but it is important also to protect existing native title rights. How nebulous an area are we now going into? If you really want to delve into the depths of uncertainty you say that people have a right to renew an interest on the basis of something that is as loose and fast as an offer, commitment, arrangement or undertaking. There is no contract involved there. There is no suggestion.

I say to you that, although the government may be happy with your amendment 13, if I were the government I would be ecstatic about it because it does not tackle the problem that has been identified here—a problem which will not only be unfair to indigenous Australians but will ensure another raft of legal cases, another raft of decisions from federal courts and so on. You really cannot, in all conscience, allow renewals of interest based on something as loose as a non-binding legal agreement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will resist the temptation to take considerable advantage of what Senator Bolkus has said and restrain myself by simply pointing out to him that the words we have used are taken entirely from the current Native Title Act, which Senator Bolkus voted for, along with the whole Labor Party, back in 1993. In the current act, subsection 228(3)(2)(ii), states:

SPEECH.PARA: in giving effect to, or otherwise because of, an offer, commitment, arrangement or undertaking made or given in good faith before 1 July 1993, and of which there is written evidence created at or about the time the offer, commitment, arrangement or undertaking is made;

We have been faithful to the current act by picking up those words exactly and putting them into these provisions. You might describe your own act as `loose and fast' but—as I say, I will resist the temptation to take this matter any further because I do not want to prolong the debate—I make the point that these words are taken entirely from your act.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine's amendment 13 does slightly amend an unacceptable provision relating to pre-existing rights. However, in my opinion, it is not the position that the Greens and Democrats have put up—that it is necessary to remove the unnecessary provision and extension of renewal provisions based on an offer, commitment, arrangement or undertaking. There are other amendments which are consequential to those which are similar, but this probably is one of the important ones of distinction. I would urge Senator Harradine to reconsider that position.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Minchin has persuaded me in respect of 71 and 72.

SPEECH.PARA: Progress reported.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 1.00 p.m. to 2.00 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. On 23 October Senator Alston refused to comply with a return to order for the ACIL consultancy documents. Will the government now comply with that return to order, and the return to order of 19 November covering other maritime consultancies, so the people of Australia can be reassured that the government is not involved in the Dubai industrial mercenaries affair via these consultancies?
—It is not true that I did a check on where Senator Alston is, I might say in opening.
—He's not in Dubai!

—He is in Korea. You are asking me for the reasons the government declined to table that consultancy and I presume it was because it was confidential information provided to the government to assist it in the development of policy. Presuming my recall of that matter is correct, I cannot see that anything has changed between then and now.
—Have you read the documents?

—No, I have not read them. I doubt whether the government would therefore see any reason to change its collective mind. I will discuss it with Senator Alston upon his return and perhaps at the next question time I might be able to give you some further information.

—I ask a supplementary question, Madam President. Minister, can you assure the Senate that the industrial mercenaries being recruited to work on the Australian waterfront are not the threat to `physical safety of persons' that Senator Alston cited as a reason for not providing the ACIL documents? I would also like to know whether the consultancy to Minter Ellison for $151,000 was used to draw up the Australian workplace agreement, or part of it at least, for this mercenary exercise in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know of any so‐called mercenary exercise, I have to say. There have been stories in recent times about—

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Faulkner interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I have read the papers. I know what is in the papers. They were talking about some labour organisation looking to train personnel overseas for heavy engineering and technical type work within the Pacific basin. That is what I read. That seems to be very different from what is being suggested in the Senate this question time. I can only suggest that there is a very creative imagination at work here, Senator, and that creative imagination has sought to dress this up in political terms to suit the benefit of the Labor Party. It is a different issue, of course, as to how we can improve the efficiency of the waterfront. That is long overdue. If that could be improved that would be for the benefit of all Australians.

—My question is to the Minister for the Environment. Minister, last year the government fulfilled its election commitment to nominate Macquarie Island and the Heard and McDonald Islands group for world heritage listing. Will you indicate the results of those nominations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a very good story. This is after some years of work by our government and the previous government to try to get Macquarie Island and the Heard and McDonald Islands group recognised as having world heritage values. I am pleased that late last night we received the word that they were to be included on the World Heritage List. Heard and McDonald Islands, as honourable senators would know, are about 4,000 kilometres south‐west of Perth. They have been listed for both their biological and geological values. Their isolation and inhospitable conditions have meant that no long‐term human activity or human‐introduced plants or animals are found on the islands and they are, therefore, almost unique in that regard. The islands also provide a haven for millions of birds and marine animals. In fact, Heard Island is the only place in the world where all six species of Antarctic seals have been recorded.

ANSWER.PARA: The Heard and McDonald Islands have also been listed because of their geological values as they contain unique physical processes, particularly relating to island formation. They are the only sub‐Antarctic islands where volcanic activity is currently taking place. Indeed, as all quiz masters know, Big Ben on Heard Island is the highest mountain of Australia.

Macquarie Island has been nominated because of its unique geological values. It is the only known place where the solid outer shell of the oceanic crust of the planet is exposed above sea level. It is also the site of continuing fault line activity and is therefore an example of ongoing geological processes.

The Macquarie Island nomination was lodged with the full cooperation and support of the Tasmanian government. I have to say how pleasing it is to see that Australian governments, federal and state, are now working cooperatively in these matters; a further signal of a different approach from the Commonwealth government, I might say. I congratulate the Tasmanian government in that regard. We are also working cooperatively with Western Australia in the hope of getting the Bungle Bungles listed, and cooperatively with the New South Wales government in the hope of getting the Blue Mountains listed eventually—very different from the old trench warfare days of the Labor Party.

BREAK.PARA: In getting these assets listed in a cooperative way, we are then better placed to put in management programs that can be implemented cooperatively. We are also better placed to engage the whole community in protecting and conserving these unique values. So this is a good news story. I acknowledge the assistance of all others who worked to get this listing, in particular, Professor Rick Varne from the University of Tasmania. We had other assistance from groups as diverse as the Wilderness Society. We appreciate it. Finally, I acknowledge the work of my officials, who did a great job. There were some difficulties, as those who are interested know, but success was achieved in the end. This is therefore good news for Australia and another thing of which we can be very proud as a government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Given that the Prime Minister has been a strong public advocate of the 15 per cent super tax, will you now confirm that Mr Howard will not be paying the tax, despite his income of over $200,000 per annum?

—I know what I have read in the press on this matter. It would suggest that to provide for certain people being exempted could add considerable cost burdens, which might therefore prove to be unwise. It may be, therefore, that Mr Howard might assist charity through his contribution.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs. The minister would be aware of claims that coated wood‐free paper is being dumped on the Australian market. What steps are being taken to protect local producers, particularly major paper manufacturers in Tasmania? Has Customs been monitoring the situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Watson for that question. Senator Watson has shown a great interest in this area through his representations and has been striving to ensure that a fair outcome is achieved for Tasmania. As Senator Watson is well aware through his extensive consultations with the Australian Paper representatives and members of the Tasmanian Paper Mills Employee Action Committee, the dumping of wood‐free coated paper has serious implications for the viability of Australia's two mills at Wesley Vale and Burnie and the future of 1,000 direct jobs and 4,000 indirect jobs which underpin the regional economy of north-west Tasmania.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Customs Service undertook an extensive dumping inquiry, with its investigation focusing on 31 overseas companies, 22 of which were investigated on-site, and 14 Australian companies. Customs has made a preliminary finding that either dumped coated wood‐free paper did occur during 1996 and that this dumping caused material injury to Australian Paper, Australia's sole producer of coated wood‐free paper. I understand that the dumping and injury were severe at this time. World prices have risen significantly this year, however, with the incidence of dumping reduced as prices increased.

Customs has made a positive dumping finding in relation to exporters from Austria, Belgium, Finland, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the Republic of Korea, the Netherlands, Switzerland and Taiwan. Exports from these countries represent 90 per cent of wood‐free coated paper imports since January 1997. Customs has imposed provisional measures against 14 companies from Austria, Finland, Germany, Japan, Korea, the Netherlands, Switzerland and Taiwan. The effect of these provisional measures is to impose securities on most exports from these countries where duty may be payable. This means that a benchmark export price has been set for each of the companies named as dumping in the preliminary finding. These companies will effectively export at those prices until the Anti‐Dumping Authority has concluded its review and the Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs has made a decision on that review.

Customs has made negative findings in relation to Sweden and South Africa. Investigations were also terminated against some companies from Belgium, France, Germany, Indonesia and Italy. I am aware that there has been some criticism of Customs' handling of the matter. The case was very complex, with Customs receiving over 100 submissions from diverse interests. The minister wishes to acknowledge the submission put in by Senator Watson.

Faced with a huge volume of information and 31 overseas companies to investigate, Customs concentrated on addressing the issues crucial to making its preliminary finding. I urge all parties to study the preliminary findings report carefully. The positive findings will now be referred to the Anti‐Dumping Authority for its examination. At the completion of the review of Customs' preliminary findings, the ADA will make recommendations to Minister Truss, who will then make a decision on future action.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Papua New Guinea: Australian Broadcasting Corporation

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Given that the PNG Prime Minister, Mr Bill Skate, has blamed the Australian Broadcasting Corporation for the current political controversy in PNG, will you now defend the Australian broadcaster from attack? Do you believe that the ABC is conspiring to generate political instability in PNG, or is Mr Skate merely copying the Australian Prime Minister, who blames the messenger for his problems, particularly the ABC?

—I do not think it would be fair to accuse the ABC in relation to the PNG Prime Minister's problems. What I was reflecting on is that the ABC has been accused of other things in South-East Asia that I have disagreed with as well. The political problems in PNG at the moment are very much the making of the politicians.

—My question is addressed to the Assistant Treasurer. Is it not the case that yesterday's economic figures, which the Treasurer is crowing about, have failed to deliver more jobs, with the number of wage and salary earners falling since June? Given that growth in the economy is being driven by private consumption, can you explain why the Treasurer wants to curb consumption and, with it, jobs growth in the retail and services sector, by changing the tax mix, with higher taxes on consumption? Given that our current economic growth is based on consumption spending and that jobs growth is virtually non‐existent, was the Treasurer wrong yesterday to argue for a tax mix change, with higher taxes on consumption, as he did?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Stott Despoja, I think you are wrong to say that the Treasurer was crowing about the national accounts figures. He was, naturally, very proud of those figures, as indeed he should be because they were absolutely sensational. The government is right to be proud of them, and we are proud of them because they are good for Australia and good for Australians. This is the sort of growth which is going to produce the jobs growth we all want and which, I might say, is a No. 1 priority of the government. The results that we received in the national accounts are particularly encouraging.

ANSWER.PARA: You mentioned the composition of the growth in the national accounts. A number of factors underpinned the very strong growth in the September quarter. There were also a number of one‐off factors. Abstracting from these factors, it is interesting to note that exports grew strongly. There was solid growth in business and dwelling investment. There was, as you indicated, strong growth in private consumption. It is this sort of growth, as I said, which the government has been seeking because it is this growth which will produce the expansion of jobs.

You then went on to the tax mix. The government believes that, as we head towards the next century, it is very important to have a taxation system which encourages people to save and to invest, and to help us build the productive base of the economy. It was interesting that Senator Murray, I think, asked me a question in relation to foreign investment. It is true that Australians have come to rely on the savings of foreigners.

We are seeking to lift the level of national savings in this country. I would have thought it was a general consensus position that it is very important that we deal with the massive problem of the savings shortfall which we inherited from the previous government. The Treasurer indicated that this government believes that it is important to have a taxation system which encourages people to save and to invest. That is one of the driving motives behind the tax reform agenda which this government has laid out.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not one country in the world has had an increase in its savings—not one!
—Your party is so confused on tax reform, Senator Conroy, I could pick out 10 people in your party, all of whom have separate views on tax reform.

—Madam President, I rise on a point of order which goes to relevance. I am not interested in the Australian Labor Party's position on tax. I am sure the minister is. I am actually interested in an answer to my question. I am glad that he answered Senator Murray's question today, but I can't wait till tomorrow, so could I have an answer now please, Minister?
—Senator Kemp, I think you allowed yourself to be distracted by an interjection.

—Indeed I did. I was receiving the customary abuse from Senator Conroy. Senator Stott Despoja, you asked me a number of questions, most of which I have replied to. The final point that you were asking me was whether it is appropriate to encourage savings in this country, and the answer is that I would have thought there was a universal view in this chamber on that. I am looking at Senator George Campbell, and he is nodding—

ANSWER.PARA: Senator George Campbell interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Sorry, Senator George Campbell is shaking his head. He does not think it is appropriate to encourage savings. We understand that, Senator. At least we have one clear position from the Labor Party, and we appreciate that.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, I did not ask about savings. I asked if the Treasurer was wrong in the argument he put forward yesterday. I understand from your answer that you agree with his idea of changing the tax mix so that there are higher taxes on consumption. I ask again: what about jobs? If you are so happy with and so proud of yesterday's statement and the figures, can you give us an unemployment target or a jobs growth target? Isn't it about time, if you are so confident, Minister? Can you assure the Senate that this government will not proceed to change the tax mix with higher indirect taxes if such a policy were to cost jobs?

—This government is about jobs. The reason that we have taken a number of difficult and tough decisions is to get the fundamentals right in this economy. By getting the fundamentals right, we are helping to take the brakes off growth, and that will produce the jobs growth which we are all seeking. I am sorry to hear that you are not interested in the tax reform program of the Labor Party. I think you are out of kilter there with most of the community. Most of the community would be fascinated to hear from the Labor Party what its tax reform agenda is.

—My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Minister, can you now confirm that the decision to abolish DAS was taken without any supporting advice or recommendations from the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, that the Department of Finance could identify no cost savings, and that the Baxter report specifically recommended against abolition, stating that there was no compelling reason for disbanding DAS? Will you now admit that the decision to abolish DAS was driven purely by misplaced Prime Ministerial vengeance following the exposure of the ineptitude of his ministers? Finally, will you acknowledge that, far from being at fault, DAS had in fact attempted to reform some of the very measures that were later the subject of controversy during the travel rorts affair?

—Unfortunately I think Senator Cook still fails to understand this matter. This decision was taken, as I have said before, as a result of the government believing that it could better administer its responsibilities in this area through the former functions of DAS being absorbed within the Department of Finance.
—Malicious.

—No. The government has a responsibility to put in place the most efficient administrative functions and structure as it can with both effectiveness in output and cost effectiveness as well, and that was the decision taken in relation to this matter. That is why the restructuring occurred.
—How much did Baxter cost?

—The Baxter inquiry was an internal matter that was looking at efficiencies within DAS, that is true. It did not have as its term of reference any suggestion of abolishing DAS. That was a decision that was separately taken. There is no relationship between the two at all.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I might comment, though, that the Department of Finance could not identify cost savings. So, if the government believes there are cost savings, it would be a miracle if you could tell us where you thought they were. My supplementary question is: will the minister now publicly acknowledge the service that the former secretary of DAS, Mr John Mellors—despite the fact that the Prime Minister instructed Mr Max Moore-Wilton not to do so at the time of his departure—has given to DAS and to the Australian taxpayer?
—I think that was acknowledged at the time of his departure. I am quite happy to recognise and reaffirm it.

—My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. My question relates to this government's historic initiative, the work for the dole scheme, which was initially opposed by the Labor Party and is still opposed by the Democrats. It commenced yesterday and is an initiative warmly received by the community and young people across Australia. How will this scheme benefit our young unemployed and how will it help them develop the sense of community that needs to be nurtured in Australia today more than ever?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, it is a very important matter and, as the honourable senator said, the work for the dole initiative was launched yesterday by my colleague in the other place, Dr Kemp. More than 300 young people aged between 18 and 24 who have been out of work for six months or more started work on 22 projects across Australia, including programs that involved beautifying beaches, upgrading various tourist attractions, documenting the life experience of early Sydney migrants and improving facilities for elderly disabled people in southern Brisbane.

ANSWER.PARA: It is true that these projects herald a new era of mutual obligation between young unemployed and their communities.

It is designed to improve the opportunities for the young looking for permanent work. It is a concept warmly embraced by Australians and will eventually benefit 10,000 participants in 179 projects in all states and territories.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's a stunt.

—It is interesting that we get the interjection that this is a stunt, because that is of course what the Labor Party said earlier in the debate. We remember Senator Faulkner in particular saying that this is nothing more than tokenism. Do honourable senators remember? He said that it was nothing more than a bandaid solution. That was before the message came in from Mr Beazley and the rug was pulled out from under his feet.

ANSWER.PARA: In fact, the Labor Party then announced that they were supporting the work for the dole. Then they changed their policy position, but they were not prepared to say it was mutual obligation; it is reciprocal obligation. You take the language of Mr Blair and try to demonstrate that you are now new Labor. But, of course, you do not really have the nerve to stand up and say that you are embracing the policies of the Howard government. That would be too awkward. Now we have Labor signed on.

Anyway, history is history and that is in the past. What is pleasing, however, is that Labor now supports the work for the dole. It is reciprocal obligation and it is a good initiative of the Howard government for the benefit of young people.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it means real training opportunities and that is very important. It is important to help young people become job ready—something that the Labor Party never understood in government and contributed to the appalling unemployment rates of young people under Labor.

ANSWER.PARA: Madam President, this complements the very successful Green Corps program of the Howard government, another successful program offering new opportunities to young people in this country. The first round of projects under the Green Corps have given opportunities to more than 240 volunteers. They have planted more than 175,000 native frees, built 40 kilometres of tracks, rehabilitated kilometres of coastline and river bank and restored more than 1,000 hectares of sand dunes, apart from other things.

These are really worthwhile environment programs on the ground giving these young people a sense of achievement and satisfaction and giving them new life skills that will help them as they move on to further employment opportunity and, in some instances I am pleased to say, employment opportunities in the environment area.

This government is dedicated to giving young people in this country a better go for the future. The work for the dole scheme and the Green Corps are but two examples of what is being done this area which gives young people greater self‐confidence, greater employment opportunities and, therefore, the chance for greater life satisfaction.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. You will be aware of Senator Herron's firm position on native title and freehold, which he set out so succinctly in the informative little booklet he released yesterday. Why is it that Senator Herron is able so convincingly to rebut the myth, as he puts it, that Aborigines can claim backyards, yet Senator Minchin and Mr Howard are unable to do so? Minister, where do you stand on this crucial issue? Does private freehold extinguish native title?

—Why don't I quote Mr Beazley? What did he say on this matter? Who listened to the interview between John Laws and Mr Beazley? Mr Beazley was asked, `Would you sign off on a provision that said that freehold extinguished native title?' Of course, he started to huff and puff, and said, `We would not think it was necessary.' Then he was asked, `No, but would you sign it?' Beazley: `But we want to look at the content of it because, you see, one of the problems . . . ' Ah, he is starting to get a bit evasive. Laws: `No, but I am saying, Kim, if the content was simply freehold extinguishes native title, would you sign it?' Answer: `If it centred on backyards, yes. But, you know, in some states, for example, there are different definitions of freehold.' Mr Beazley goes on to talk about reversion of title and the like, and basically what he is saying is, `Backyards, yes; other freehold, perhaps not.' This matter is not quite as clear‐cut as some in the Labor Party would wish to say.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Timorese Democratic Union Congress: Visa Applicants

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. Minister, I refer to the government's decision not to grant visas to seven Portuguese delegates to the Timorese Democratic Union's Congress currently being held in Perth. Is it the case that all seven delegates who were refused visas have been fully sponsored by the congress and, if so, why did the government refuse to grant visas to these delegates who comprised the entire youth and women's contingent when visas were granted to 10 other Portuguese delegates to the same conference?

—I thank Senator Bourne for the question. Senator, Australian immigration policy and entry decisions are determined by the Australian government and not by any other country, in case there is an inference of that in your question. Seventeen people did apply in Lisbon to attend the conference: two were Portuguese born; 15 were of East Timorese background. All applicants who wish to travel to Australia must meet all of the visa requirements as set out in the migration legislation. Failure to meet any of the requirements may result in an application for a visa being refused. Each of these applications was considered on its merits, and 10 of the applicants were as a consequence granted a visa. The remaining seven were refused entry on bona fide grounds. As I am advised, the decision maker had doubts whether the applicants would in fact abide by the conditions of their visa, and consequently entry was denied.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Senator, that is a very interesting answer, but it does not actually tell me anything. What I asked was: why were they not allowed in? `Because they would not abide by the conditions of their visa' is very broad. I would appreciate it if you would go back to the minister and ask what the conditions were that it was considered they would not abide by. Was it that they were considered to be possible dangerous overstayers who might want to stay in the country? And was that the case for all seven, or was it the case for only one of those people? I understand that you probably do not have that in the briefing, but if you could get back to the minister and get back to me—preferably before 2 March next year—I would appreciate it.

—Senator Bourne, I will get back to you as quickly as I can. It might not be by the end of this week, but it will certainly be before the commencement of the next hearings—and not only because of your usual charming demeanour. I look across every day and see Senator Faulkner turning his back to you and, when the cameras are not on him, hurling invective and poison over this way, like the gutless little leader that he is, because he does not want to get caught out on television saying nasty things. So I would not do it for him in a hurry, but I will for you.
—Senator Vanstone, that is out of order.

—My question is directed to Senator Hill representing the Prime Minister. Minister, is it true that prior to your government's aged care policies, all nursing home residents paid a daily care fee of $21 a day or the equivalent of 87.5 per cent of the pension? Minister, isn't it also true that, with the clumsy implementation of your annual accommodation fee, frail elderly Australians with assets, including their house, in excess of $36,000 will now pay an extra $12 a day when they enter a nursing home? And is it also a fact that from 1 March 1998 the government will introduce yet another extra daily fee for people in nursing homes which could add up to $34 a day on top of the existing care fee and the new $12 a day accommodation fee? Minister, why is your government punishing elderly Australians so relentlessly?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —As all honourable senators know, the real problem in this area was the 75 per cent cut in capital funding by the former Labor government over a period of four years. This government inherited a nursing home sector in serious disrepair—there is no doubt about that at all. In fact, the standard of nursing home care in relation to many patients was one which most Australians would believe to be inappropriate. That was what we inherited: a need for a capital input into a sector to lift the standard of care—not the nursing care, which is fine, but the physical standards—to something that is more appropriate to the level of dignity which older Australians are entitled to expect.

ANSWER.PARA: So, yes, there is a need for a contribution to help pay for the everyday running costs of nursing care. And we have said that for those who are a bit better off there is nothing wrong in principle with their making a further contribution towards that running cost. In other words, a very large sum of public money is being put in as a contribution towards nursing care. If the patients are able to contribute something as well, then they should. But beyond that, we did say that a contribution towards the capital costs is not unreasonable as well if the patient is able to make such a contribution. That has been our approach.

It is all history that we made the mistake of adopting the Labor Party precedent in relation to hostels and thought that establishing bonds might be the best way to achieve that capital contribution. On reflection, we have acknowledged that was a mistake and we have put in place an alternative system whereby nursing home patients who are able to make a capital contribution will do so in a direct way. It will provide for a significant contribution to the upgrading of the physical standard of care that is provided to nursing home patients.

I would have thought that most Australians would think that that is a reasonable way to approach a very difficult matter. Everyone agrees that the physical standards need to be improved; the only question is where you get the money from. Labor turned its back on the issue, in fact, worse: they cut money out of the sector. We have faced up to our responsibility. We are putting more money in. The other day you heard Mr Smith announce a further contribution from the Commonwealth. Yes, where patients are able to afford it, we expect a small contribution from them as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for acknowledging the mistake that his government made in respect of the accommodation bonds for nursing homes because it demonstrates what we said all along: that there is a significant difference between hostel accommodation and nursing home accommodation in terms of the choices available to elderly Australians. But, Minister, you continue to run this line with respect to funding and the state of the nursing home industry under the previous Labor government. How can you stand there and, with a straight face, run that argument when your government has in two budgets taken $500 million out of funding for nursing homes?
—What the Labor Party's own review told us, the Gregory report—this is what we inherited—was that 13 per cent of—

—Madam President, I have a point of order. There is a minute or so to answer the question. The question was with respect to the $500 million taken out of funding for nursing homes in two budgets by this government. Tell him to stop rabbiting on about the past and incorrectly describing the past and to answer the question that I asked.

—Senator, there was lot of preamble to the question before you got to that. The minister has had 10 seconds so far; he has another 50 seconds to deal with the matters you have raised. I am sure he is aware of what your question is.

—There was a false premise in the supplementary when we finally got to it. But what I am saying is that we inherited a sector where 13 per cent of nursing homes did not meet fire standards, 11 per cent of nursing homes did not meet the necessary health guidelines, 75 per cent of nursing homes did not meet the design building codes and 51 per cent of nursing home residents lived in wards of three or more beds. We faced up to the problem. We are not only contributing public funds but we have also put in place a process to allow for non‐government contribution as well. This is yet another example where we as a government have been prepared to take the hard decisions to provide long‐term benefits to the community. (Time expired)

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Department of Defence: Release of Medical Records

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Is the minister aware that past serving members of the defence forces experience significant delays in payment of their claims due to the time that it takes the Department of Defence to release the relevant medical and service records which are required to verify the claims? Why does it take individual officers within the Department of Defence up to 11 months to release past serving members' medical and service records to the DVA for that purpose? What can be done urgently to rectify this problem which is being experienced by quite a number of ex‐servicemen and ex‐servicewomen?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I have also experienced over many years in my electorate office this problem that Senator Harradine has faced. I am sure many members have. The frustration for older people, in particular, trying to get access to their service and their medical records is quite serious. I have some information here both from Mrs Bishop and Mr Bruce Scott, because it involves two departments. It also involves the Australian Archives, which complicates the matter.

ANSWER.PARA: As I am advised, the medical records of veterans are held either by Australian Archives or the Department of Veterans' Affairs. Requests from serving members for service and medical records are generally processed quickly as the member normally has the necessary information—number, rank and name—to speedily locate the records. But the processing of requests for personal records from veterans may take, as you said, up to several months. That is determined by the information provided by the veteran and the workload at the time.

The processing of requests for veterans' medical records generally takes longer as veterans' medical records are held by Australian Archives and have to be called for when a request is received. In some cases, a medical record may be held by the Department of Veterans' Affairs, in which case the service must request the record from the state office of the Department of Veterans' Affairs. Again, this process may take a few days to several months and it is determined by the number of requests received and the staff available in the medical records section of the three services. However, when it is known that a veteran has an urgent need of documents the services will provide that request with a priority.

The Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Mr Bruce Scott, has provided me with additional information, that is, that the coalition government has dramatically reduced the average time taken to process veterans' claims through the Department of Veterans' Affairs. The average time taken to process all entitlement and assessment claims—and that includes disability pension claims and war widow pension claims—has been reduced from 146 days in 1993‐94 to 77 days in 1996‐97. It is a reduction of about 50 per cent. I would applaud the improvement, although I recognise—Senator Harradine has focused attention on this—the long delays in getting the archival records to the former member or veteran and to the Department of Veterans' Affairs is still an issue which needs further resolution.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Social Security. Health and Family Services

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Minister, can you confirm that the government is lining up more punishment for Australians when they come back from their well‐earned Christmas break? We know what you have in store for elderly Australians—barring any further backflips. Is it not true that you will be hitting tens of thousands of unemployed Australians with a $250 job‐search fee when the new Employment Australia gets under way? Is it not true that families using outside‐school‐hours child care will be slugged with an extra $10 a week as from 27 April 1998? And what about your New Year present for the 2,770 families who will miss out on family payments on 1 January because of your tightening of the assets test? What about the 850,000 people who suffer from ulcers and blood pressure problems who will pay up to $5 more per script for medicine their doctors say they need? When is your government going to ease up on this systematic, cruel and relentless punishment for those who can least afford it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Where was the honourable senator when the family tax initiative started putting more money in the pockets of Australian families? Where was she when the interest rates on home mortgages dropped, so that families had more disposable income? This is a government committed to Australian families. This is a government that was elected because of the neglect of Labor towards Australian families.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Mackay, this is your question; you should listen to Senator Hill.

—We have discussed the issue of the elderly already today. The elderly now have a more secure future in a situation where their physical care conditions are going to be reasonable. Under Labor their physical care conditions were appalling.
—Order! Senators are shouting and making it impossible to hear.
—I was going to say that $4 billion is being invested in elderly care by this government.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Newman interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are far too many interjections on both sides.

—Concerning child care, it is true that there will be a better balance between public and private care facilities, that private care facilities will be more available in areas where they are needed and that the wealthy might suffer some disadvantage to the benefit of the less well off. Labor does not understand that language. Labor's policies selectively benefited the better off. The coalition's policies are directed to assist all the community—a major distinction.

ANSWER.PARA: The reforms that have been made in relation to employment facilitation—providing assistance in obtaining jobs—will, I think, be recorded as one of the great initiatives of this government. That is radical. Fancy providing someone with an incentive to produce results! Labor could not understand that. Labor could not understand that, if you reward on the basis of outcome, you might get better performance. I suspect that the bottom line will be that the new system will better help unemployed Australians get into work. Labor does not like it because it is radical and different, but the previous system has failed. That is why you were thrown out of government. You were thrown out of government because your tired old solutions had failed.

We are putting in place different approaches to important problems and the approach of employment facilitation is one of those. I think it is one reform, as I said, that has every chance of being a great success and will be applauded by future generations of Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —We'll see.

—Yes, Senator Mackay, we will see, but it will be given a chance to work. There is every reason that it will work and the benefit will be gained particularly by those who would otherwise have stayed unemployed.

—My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer and is related to the fact that Australia now has one of the world's strongest growing economies. What are the implications for jobs growth and investment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chapman has distinguished himself in this chamber by focusing on major issues. Senator Chapman, I particularly welcome that question from you.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator George Campbell interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The reality is, Senator George Campbell—you seem to be shouting again—that yesterday's national accounts figures were simply sensational with 1.5 per cent growth in the quarter. Non‐farm GDP grew by 1.8 per cent. The evidence is there: Australia is now at the top of the list of fastest growing industrial nations in the world. It is a great figure and, as I pointed out to Senator Stott Despoja—she is nodding in agreement—it is an excellent figure. The figure is interesting for a number of reasons, not least of which is that it shows that this government is on target. It also shows just how wrong the Labor Party can be. I am reminded that, as recently as 23 October 1997, Senator Cook said that the budget growth forecasts would not be met and that growth would be only three per cent. He went on to say that the government had stunned the economy and made it flat. How wrong can you get?

ANSWER.PARA: As I mentioned, the reality is that the figures for the national accounts showed extremely strong growth. The excellent growth figure comes on top of the very pleasing data on business expectations—retail trade, motor vehicle registrations and business investment expectations.
Senator Conroy interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —This would be of interest to you, Senator Conroy, seeing you persist in calling out. This comes on top of the lowest home mortgage rates since the 1960s and the lowest small business rates for 25 years. What does all this mean for the No. 1 priority of this government? The reality is that this is great news for jobs. Strong growth in the economy is the prerequisite for strong jobs growth and getting unemployment down, and we are building a strong platform for keeping strong growth going.

BREAK.PARA: Australians have turned away—this government has certainly turned away—from the old Labor approach of boom-bust. We can recall—indeed, the Australian community recalls—how your policies plunged Australia into the greatest recession for 60 years, since the 1930s. The unemployment figures which your policies produced damaged small business and damaged families, and there has never been any apology from any of the senior ministers of the Keating government who still litter the front bench of the Labor Party. We have put in the work to ensure that the economy has the fundamentals right. The fundamentals are there, and the results that we receive for the national accounts figures—(Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chapman, Sen Grant

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Has the minister's attention been drawn to the ALP platform which states:

QUESTION.PARA: Labor's first priority is to provide security for all Australians. This includes job security during our working years.
What importance does the government place on job security? What would be the implications of adopting alternative policies from those of the government?

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister should restrain himself to answering matters that are within his portfolio.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —We have seen exactly what the policies of the Labor Party produce. We have seen that the Labor Party, as I mentioned earlier, Senator Chapman, plunged the economy into the greatest recession for 60 years. A number of Labor people are smiling over there. What a great joke—those policies which you produced! Labor does not have the policies to ensure that the economy can continue to grow. Labor is going back to the past. Labor has continued to ignore the battlers in this community.

ANSWER.PARA: It is quite interesting how few questions have been asked by the Labor Party on unemployment. When you look at the statistics, you see that very few questions have come from the Labor Party on the unemployment issue. This is a No. 1 priority for this government. We have done the work. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to the support which has been expressed by the Chairman of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation, Mr Patrick Dodson, and the Deputy Chairman, Mr Ian Viner, for a national document of reconciliation to be jointly signed by the country's political and indigenous leaders. Does the government also support a national document of reconciliation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been suggestions for a document of that type debated for a long time. I can remember being part of that debate some 15 years ago when a Senate committee of which I was part—on the Labor side it included Senator Ryan, Senator Gareth Evans and Senator Tate, I recall—debated this matter at the request of the Senate. In fact, it took considerable evidence within Aboriginal communities. It then flowed into a debate on whether there should be some form, and that was then referred to as the Makarrata suggestion. I am putting it in context. I am saying that the suggestion of a treaty, a document of reconciliation or a makarrata has really been debated for some decades in this country, and it has not been a position adopted that it would necessarily achieve the objectives for which it was sought.

ANSWER.PARA: I welcome Pat Dodson's continuing contributions to this important debate because he is obviously somebody who is committed to the reconciliation process. We applaud the efforts that he has made in leading that to date. His successor, I am sure, will continue in the same spirit and achieve just as much. We, of course, support the concept of reconciliation and all the ways in which it might be effectively advanced. Whether the signing of another document, or of a document, is the best way to achieve that is something that this government has not considered, but it is on the table. It is probably a good idea that it be subject to further public debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. These are very fine sentiments, Minister, but is it not true that the Prime Minister has already rejected a proposal for a national document of reconciliation? If so, on what basis has he rejected it?

—I know there has been a rejection of the proposal for treaties in the past for reasons that I could go into, but you probably would not be interested. As I have said, we are more than happy to discuss in a serious and positive way the ways in which we as a nation can advance the process of reconciliation. That is the way in which this government is seeking to approach this very difficult area. I applaud the fact that Mr Dodson is prepared to continue to contribute to this debate, and I hope that he will do so for a long time to come.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. Minister, I draw your attention to the government's launch of the Education Network Australia—EdNA—Directory Service last week. Will the minister inform the Senate how this service works and outline the benefits to education and to the wider community?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Tierney for that question and acknowledge his longstanding interest in this area. I was pleased to open the EdNA Directory Service at Mitchelton High School in Brisbane last week. EdNA is the Education Network Australia Directory Service and is a product of a successful partnership with various state and territory governments.
—It was a Labor program, wasn't it!

—I acknowledge that this has been on the books for some time, but this government carried it forth and concluded it, Senator Carr, and it did so with the cooperation of the state and territory governments.

ANSWER.PARA: This is a one-stop shop on the Internet for educators and students right across Australia. I am pleased to advise the Senate that EdNA is designed for use by all people and has a user help guide so it is easily available to students and teachers alike. It has links to more than 5,000 core web sites and direct access to a further 20,000 sites. As such, EdNA is a world-class single entry point for on-line education. It saves time and ensures relevance but, most importantly, it offers quality. I can also say that it gives students, and especially parents, peace of mind in that EdNA sites have been assessed to ensure that their contact is appropriate.

The directory service offers curriculum and professional development resources and access to information on institutions in all sectors of Australian education and training. It offers information about courses and opportunities to participate in discussion groups and to collaborate on projects. In fact, it offers to Australian students Australia as a single classroom and this really is something of the future. I might say that the technology I saw at Mitchelton High School was most impressive, and it too offers great facilities for its students and parents. Indeed, it is a school of the future.

This government is committed to a comprehensive package of education and training initiatives which recognise and encourage lifelong learning. Using information and communications technologies effectively is vital to the success of these initiatives. These technologies are not just the latest, but they are tools to apply to improving performance. They help us keep ahead of the game and offer exciting possibilities for the way in which we learn, work and live together in our society.
Senator Lundy interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —By Senator Lundy's interjections, I take it that she is not terribly interested in technology in education. It is pleasing to see, though, that some opposition senators are listening to my answer. They are interested, but I take it Senator Lundy is not.

BREAK.PARA: As I said, the most important thing about EdNA is that it links teachers and Australian students together across the nation, and I think that is perhaps the most exciting aspect of this. This has been launched for the entire Australian education community, and I encourage all Australians to use this great facility and to participate in its growth and success.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, I thank you for the answer. What other initiatives in education and training has this government undertaken to improve the employment prospects of young people?

—I thank Senator Tierney for that supplementary question. What this government is vitally interested in is vocational education to offer students the chance to participate in the work force. Some 70 per cent of students do not go on to higher education. They are the people we need to concentrate on and we are looking at that in our new apprenticeship system. We are looking at new programs in vocational education in schools. We are providing students with the ability to participate in apprenticeships and to look to their futures. This is a very practical measure. It is something that this government is very keen on doing. We are not just going to concentrate on the 30 per cent who go on to higher education. We are very keen to look after that 70 per cent who will not go on to higher education and will need jobs when they leave school.
—Madam President, with some regret, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper , but we all look forward to next March.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Assistant Treasurer

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Hogg asked me a question on 3 December regarding the millennium bug. I now have an answer from the Minister for Finance and Administration and I seek leave to incorporate that answer in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

BREAK.PARA: The answer read as follows—

Senator Hogg —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Finance and Administration. Minister, has your attention been drawn to a survey conducted by Coopers & Lybrand which found that Commonwealth and local government agencies were lagging as much as six to 12 months behind the private sector in the race to safeguard computer systems in the lead up to the new millennium? Is it fact that Coopers & Lybrand partner, Mr Mike Bridge, stated: While most organisations in `high risk' areas, such as communications, banking and insurance, appear to be getting on top of the problem, the exception is Commonwealth and local government. Are you aware that Mr Bridge has also stated that `there is a severe risk of disruption to government agencies and the public services' key recipients'? Given that a third of companies surveyed are already experiencing problems with the millennium bug, including issuing expiry dates for licences, credit cards and medication, what action is the Government taking to address this issue?
Senator Kemp —The Minister for Finance has provided the following answer:

The survey results for the Government sector include local governments. More detailed information will be required to identify the number of Commonwealth agencies that have responded to the survey and what proportion of the Government sector these Commonwealth agencies represent in the survey results.
The concern of risk to continuity of service delivery by Commonwealth agencies is very real and I am monitoring the situation very closely.

The Government has established a Year 2000 Project Office in OGIT to support Commonwealth agencies in meeting their Year 2000 responsibilities. As part of its activities, the Year 2000 Project Office has established a whole‐of‐government monitoring framework for agencies to report quarterly on Year 2000 progress and can undertake audits of selected agencies of their progress towards achieving Year 2000 compliance.
The first report is due in December 1997. It will show how many business critical systems are at risk across the Commonwealth and their progress towards compliance.
The ANAO audit on Year 2000 at the end of this year will also give the government a clearer picture of where the Commonwealth agencies stand on this issue.

We are also implementing a national strategy in conjunction with State governments. This is to ensure that small to medium enterprises are made aware of the seriousness of the issue, with the overall objective to have Australia Year 2000 compliant. $5.43m has been set aside for this.

The cost to Australian government and business has not been determined. The figure of $3 billion often quoted in the press, is derived from the Gartner Group figure of resolving the Year 2000 problem world wide, estimated to be between $US300—$US600 billion. Australia represents 1% of the global market place, therefore 1% of the lower figure gives $3 billion.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Disabled Persons: Sales Tax on Motor Vehicle Parts Disability Services

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —In question time yesterday, I took questions on notice from Senators Bartlett and Allison in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Family Services. I would first point out that Senator Bartlett's question related to sales tax and probably should have been directed to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp, my esteemed colleague. However, the Treasurer has provided me with a response to that question. I now seek leave to have the responses to both questions incorporated in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The answers read as follows—
Response to question taken on notice by Senator Herron from Senator Bartlett on 3 December 1997
Response from Senator Herron on advice from the Treasurer

PARA.TAB: A sales tax exemption is available for goods used to modify a motor vehicle solely for the purpose of adapting the vehicle to enable a person suffering from a physical impairment to drive the vehicle. This exemption also extends to goods used to adapt the vehicle to allow for the transporting of persons suffering from physical impairment. The exemption only extends to the parts used to modify the vehicle, it does not cover the whole vehicle.
There has been no change to this sales tax exemption and it applies equally to privately owned vehicles or vehicles used for public transportation, such as taxis.

In February this year the ATO issued a ruling withdrawing sales tax exemption from manufacturers for whole vehicles that were designed and manufactured expressly for use by persons who suffer from sickness, disease or disablement. The manufacturers were modifying vehicles to enable them to be used for transporting physically disabled persons prior to original sale. However, the majority of the vehicles were for use as taxi cabs in the general transportation of all persons, not just physically disabled persons.
The ATO ruled that these vehicles did not qualify for exemption and were taxable at the general sales tax rate of 22%.
There are certain other sales tax exemptions that apply to vehicles for use by disabled persons namely:

TAB.TAB: Exemption from sales tax is available for motor vehicles for a person's personal transportation to and from gainful employment if that person has been certified by Health Services Australia that she or he has lost the use of one or more limbs to the extent that they are unable to use public transport.
Certain defence force veterans who have lost the use of one or more limbs can also obtain vehicles free of sales tax.

PARA.TAB: There is also an exemption for goods that are designed and manufactured expressly for use by persons suffering from sickness disease or disablement. These goods cannot be of a kind ordinarily used by persons who do not suffer from sickness, disease or disablement.

SPEECH.PARA: SENATOR ALLISON—Disability SERVICES
3 DECEMBER 1997

SENATOR ALLISON—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Family Services. Minister, in your review of the Commonwealth-state disability agreement it was noted that between $324 million and $917 million is required to need the huge unmet demand for disability services. When will your government meet the needs of 13,500 people in critical need of accommodation, support or respite services? When will your government address the needs of 7,700 people whose carers are over 65? When will your government provide funds for the 70,000 people who need access to day and recreation activities?

In response to Senator Allison's question, I can provide the following information. The Senator refers to the review of the first Commonwealth State Disability Agreement conducted in 1995 and 1996. The Commonwealth/State Disability Agreement is an Agreement between the States and the Commonwealth which sets out the roles and responsibilities of governments in relation to disability services and provides for funding assistance to deliver those services. Under the Agreement, the State and Territory governments have responsibility for accommodation, respite and day services, and the Commonwealth has responsibility for employment services.

States have always had primary responsibility for welfare services for people with disabilities. However, under the Agreement both the Common wealth and the States contribute funds for the provision of disability services. At the start of the first Commonwealth/State Disability Agreement the States contributed around 80% of funding for disability services and the Commonwealth around 20%. The share contributed by the Commonwealth has steadily increased and is now at around—21.6%

As part of the review of the first Agreement, the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare looked at the demand for disability services. Its report, published in 1996, found considerable unmet demand for services, particularly in the areas of accommodation, respite care and day services, which are managed by State governments. Further work commissioned by the Commonwealth/State and Territory governments this year, will give States better local information on demand for accommodation support and day services and provide more accurate estimates of costs. The results so far indicate that the costs of addressing unmet demand is not as great as originally thought. Latest estimates indicate that the cost of meeting the unmet demand could be about $293 million.

The needs of ageing carers are an emerging problem for all governments. Work by the Institute showed that in 1993, there were 7,700 parents, 65 years or over, caring for a person with a disability. It is estimated that this figure will rise to 9,000 by the year 2003. Many of these families are looking for the kinds of support which will assure security and certainty about their futures. Clearly, further work is required to examine the exact nature of unmet needs at a local level and how governments might most effectively respond to these.

A new Agreement is currently under negotiation. The Commonwealth government is keen to work with the States that join in the next Agreement, to examine how the issues facing people with disabilities and their carers can best be addressed.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been told that I misunderstood a question asked to me by Senator Conroy, which will teach me to listen more carefully in future. I thought his question related to the savings rebate. An article appeared in the press in relation to the savings rebate, but the question concerned an article that appeared in the press in relation to the super surcharge. The answer to that is that, contrary to the impression created by the article in the Australian today, the Prime Minister and other long serving ministers will be subjected to the surcharge in respect of the additional superannuation benefits that they are incurring as ministers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill), to a question without notice asked by Senator O'Brien today, relating to a consultancy contract for waterfront reform awarded to ACIL Economics.

I have the terms of reference provided by the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Vaile) and the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith) to ACIL consultants. Point (c) in those terms of reference required ACIL to provide the government with `detailed plans to handle any contingencies which may arise in the implementation of a maritime reform strategy'. Unless the government is prepared to give this parliament details of the plans that have been formulated under that consultancy in relation to any contingencies, this parliament can come to no other conclusion than that the plans provided by ACIL are the basis of the Dubai initiative that is being discussed in the media and that we raised in my question here today. How else can we interpret the government's refusal to release any details of those contingency plans on the basis that personal safety would be put at risk?

Point (a) in those terms of reference talks about options which can be pursued by the government to improve the reliability and productivity of the waterfront and to reduce prices. In relation to the consultancies which were revealed at the last estimates—that is, the consultancies to Dr Webster, Dr Davies, Minter Ellison, Corrs Chamber Westgarth, the National Institute of Labour Studies and others, worth over $481,000—only two of those reports were provided in relation to the return to order that this centre carried. They were the reports from Corrs Chamber Westgarth and the National Institute of Labour Studies. Both of those reports just happen to refer, I would say fairly directly, to term (a) in the terms of reference in relation to reliability, productivity and reduced prices. They deal with the safety aspects on the waterfront, and they deal with the wage relativities of wharfies with regard to their rates of pay compared with those of other workers. The other two terms, (b) and (c), talk about the key recommendations of the Shipping Reform Group in the context of developing a comprehensive maritime reform strategy.

When you look at the consultancies, the first ACIL consultancy was for $60,000, which blew out to over $80,000. The second consultancy cost so far is, as far as we know, $283,972. That includes $42,000 to Mark Textor, who is pretty infamous in terms of his association with the Liberal Party, and a consultancy to Jonathon Gaul. They are apparently great experts on the maritime industry. We then have $481,000 in consultancies to Dr Davies and Dr Webster—both previous Liberal staffers. There is $151,375 so far to Minter Ellison. They are supposed to be reporting on maritime reform.

If you look at this Dubai exercise, what we do know is that there is an Australian workplace agreement being drafted by someone. What we would like to know is: did Minter Ellison draft that? The government can clearly tell us that by supplying the legal advice that Minter Ellison have prepared, for a sum of $151,000‐odd so far. The government can also tell us what Dr Davies and Dr Webster have been advising the government on. This really leads us to the potential conclusion that these people are really conduits for government money to fund this sort of exercise.

How does the Australian public know that this is not the case? The government says, `This is to supply the government with information, with advice on policy.' Yet we know that they have sought advice on detailed plans to handle any contingencies which may arise in the implementation of maritime reform strategy. Clearly, these sorts of arrangements are being put in place with the engagement of these people to go and learn how to operate on the waterfront in Dubai and then to come back to Australia and operate in the major ports around Australia. What else can these people be being prepared for but a significant exercise which, as every thinking person will know, will be provocative and designed to promote disharmony, dispute and problems on the Australian waterfront?

The minister in the other place is talking about this being, perhaps, some impetus to reform on the waterfront, but there is a way of achieving reform which is not provocative. There is a way of achieving reform which is Australian; there is a way of achieving reform which is unAustralian. Putting these people onto the waterfront and probably, I would say, paying them out of Commonwealth money, setting up this program, preparing legal advice—(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran, Sen Julian

TALK.START.PARA: —Anyone who just heard Senator O'Brien then would have heard him say that this leads us to a potential conclusion. He was not even sure about his own conclusion on the matter. All he did was to crawl over the terms of reference of a report in a desperate attempt to squeeze out some conspiracy that simply is not there.

SPEECH.PARA: I can quite understand how the opposition got very excited about today's reports in the newspapers, particularly the Age newspaper, recognising that there was probably some chance of a terrific political beat‐up here. It is for them, of course, to traditionally jump to the defence of the waterside workers and their beloved MUA. The truth of the matter is that the government has rejected out of hand any knowledge or any connection with the company involved. More so, the director of the company involved, Fynwest, says that they have a consortium to recruit port workers for wharves in the Pacific region, not Australia.

Senator O'Brien, you are not going to listen to that. Like the member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner), you believe that the waterfront reforms that occurred are sufficient. They have been minute. They have been of no value at all under your government. Why don't you join us in bringing about real and effective reform on the waterfront? The point of the matter is that you are in denial mode. When it comes to the waterfront, you go straight into denial mode, full of conspiracies and full of hope that nothing will ever change. We are determined to bring about real reform on the waterfront. We know where the problem lies. It lies with the opposition and their continual defence of the Maritime Union of Australia.

The problems on the waterfront are, and always have been, the crane rates, the strike rates, the overmanning, the overpaying and the, at times, outright extortion. When it comes to crane rates, the rural sector, the farming sector and the primary industries sector suffer the most. That flows on to not only jobs but also the wealth of the nation. The wool industry uses more containers than any other export industry in Australia. But wool producers have to contend with hopeless strike rates on the waterfront. They have a delivery time of two weeks, otherwise they pay penalty rates. As if the wool industry has not had enough trouble over the years without being able to get its product off the wharves.

Listen to this for a strike rate on Australia's waterfront. The level of industrial action on the waterfront is unacceptably high. In 1996 there were 1,250 working days lost per thousand employees compared with an all industry average of 131 per thousand. I repeat that on the waterfront there are 1,250 working days lost per 1,000 employees whereas the all industries average in Australia is 131 per thousand. That is a ratio of one to 10. Australia, with two per cent of the world's shipping trade, has the highest level of industrial unrest with 23 per cent of days lost. We are the worst in the world for strikes.

Our crane lifting rates per hour are well below that of our competitors. We have a five port average of 18.3. We are competing with equivalent ports which have rates of around 28 to 30. If we could get ours up to 25 containers per hour—a modest rise close to our competitors—it would make an enormous difference to efficiencies on the waterfront. That is not too much to ask. Our minister has entered into negotiations, which I do not have any or much hope for, with the union to achieve that benchmark.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mackay, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —I can do no better but to start off my contribution by quoting from today's Australian , not the Age . The Australian says:

SPEECH.PARA: Initially, it just all seemed too bizarre, too Monty Pythonesque. Former and present army personnel, possibly from the SAS, being trained as stevedores in a Middle Eastern country . . .
Not only is it Monty Pythonesque but there is a bit of Tom Clancy chucked in there as well.

In relation to Senator McGauran's response, in which he said that the government knew absolutely nothing about it, let me tell you what the Prime Minister, John Howard, said yesterday. When asked whether there was any financial involvement with regard to the government, he would not answer the question. He dodged it. Today the Prime Minister was again asked whether there was any financial involvement with regard to the government. He was asked to assure the Australian people that there were no government funds involved at all. What did he do? He dodged it. He did not answer the question. Instead, he raved on about the same stuff as you did, which is waterfront reform. He would not answer the question.

Then we have Minister Reith. He was asked whether any of his staff knew anything about this issue. He dodged it and would not answer the question. The shadow minister for industrial relations asked a supplementary question. He asked the same question again—`Will you confirm or deny whether any of your staff knew about this issue?' He dodged the issue again.

What we want to know is: was there any government money involved with regard to this? We want to know. We want an assurance that that was not the case. We want to have a look, and the Australian people want to have a look, at the documentation to see if there is anything involved. We want to know whether the Prime Minister, the Prime Minister's office, the minister for industrial relations or his staff or the department knew about this. That is what we want to know. There are government senators here who have obviously been briefed in relation to this taking note, Senator Ferguson, so I would really appreciate an assurance from you as to whether or not the situation is correct.

How on earth could this outrageous situation come about? I will tell you something: under the Labor Party's industrial relations system, this could not have happened. The reason this is possible is because of Australian workplace agreements. Australian workplace agreements are secret. Our industrial relations system was transparent. Under the previous industrial relations system it would have been blatantly obvious whether the government, the department, Minister Reith or his staff did not know anything about this, because that system was transparent. The difficulty we have here is that AWAs are secret. We do not know what is going on and, if Peter Reith is to be believed, neither did he. Isn't that extraordinary.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Reith to you.

—Mr Reith to me—thank you. Isn't that extraordinary. The minister for workplace relations did not know anything about this. That in itself is an outrage. I heard him on AM this morning and I have to say that he sounded pretty rattled to me. I was not sure whether he was rattled because he did know something about it and, whoops, it had been disclosed before the appropriate time—I would suggest once parliament got up—or because he thought, `I should've known about that and I wasn't told.' I am not sure which one it is. But we still do not have an answer to that question. He still would not answer that question in the House of Representatives.
