The Prime Minister still would not answer the question with regard to government funds being involved in this. We still do not have an answer. We deserve an answer and the Australian people deserve an answer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Sen Alan

TALK.START.PARA: —What a pathetic effort by members opposite to try to raise the issue of the Australian waterfront when they ought to be apologising for their efforts in regard to that issue. I had the misfortune to chair the estimates committee when Senator O'Brien painstakingly—and I use the word advisedly—asked questions to do with the maritime unions in regard to consultancies. It is not as though the former Labor government did not offer consultancies.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the efforts that have been made on the Australian waterfront over the last number of years, the Labor Party and this opposition ought to be ashamed of themselves. When it comes to the waterfront and the continuing problems that dog Australia's waterfront and hinder our trade—they are: the poor productivity levels, the poor safety records and the poor reliability and they have been raised continually—no amount of defence by those opposite will ever deny the fact that the Australian waterfront is so far behind its competitors around the rest of the world.

In September, the Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics figures revealed a provisional five port average of a crane rate of 18.3 containers an hour. That is really something to be proud of, Senator O'Brien, particularly when the bureau conservatively estimates that the five port average could be 25 containers per hour. They estimate that a 43 per cent increase in productivity is achievable. This industry, and in particular the unions, must set themselves some goals for productivity improvements to try to achieve those goals. Not only the bureau but also the government believes that 25 containers per hour is quite achievable.

In the area of safety record, the incidence of fatalities on the waterfront per 10,000 employees is twice that of the mining industry and seven times the national average. The average cost of workers compensation is $1,450 per annum compared with an all industry average of $244. In 1996, the number of days lost, which my colleague Senator McGauran pointed out in his speech earlier, remains almost 10 times the national average.

Members opposite have said that jobs is their main platform that they want to run with at the next election. They say that their first priority is providing security for all Australians and that includes job security. Yet did you know that in question time in 1997 less than four per cent of Labor's questions have been related to jobs? Out of a total of 583 questions a mere 21 questions were related to jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many?

—Only 21 questions out of 583 were related to jobs. Did you know that since the beginning of the spring session on 25 August there have been just seven questions from the Labor Party relating to jobs? These are the people who have said that job security is going to be the most important platform of their election. As a matter of fact, if you look at the three particular shadow ministers, Senator Bolkus, who is the shadow minister for employment, has asked three questions this year on jobs and not one question in this session.

SPEECH.PARA: The shadow minister for employment does not think jobs are important enough to even ask one question on unemployment for the whole of this session. Senator Cook has asked two questions for the year. I must admit he has asked one this session. Senator Cook has managed to ask one. The Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Faulkner, who is part of this great push to make jobs and job security a platform at the next election, has asked four questions this year as leader.

TALK.START.PARA: —This year?

—Yes. But how many since August? None—not one question from the Leader of the Opposition. So the next time the Labor Party talks about jobs—jobs on the waterfront and jobs for young Australians—Australians might do well to remember that the issue of jobs as far as the Labor Party is concerned rates very low on their list of priorities in this Senate chamber. I think all Australians would do well to take note of the fact that we will get plenty of rhetoric about jobs from the Labor Party opposite, but they are not concerned about jobs at all. Otherwise, they would have raised the issue at appropriate times and asked question of ministers, but they could not do that even once. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop, Sen Mark

TALK.START.PARA: —In opening my comments on this discussion I should note an interjection of Senator Chapman just for the record. He said words to the effect, `I make this stuff up as I go along.'
—Don't you dare misrepresent what I said.

—That appears to be the reaction of the government to this very important issue. As we look over the horizon we see a developing cloud appearing, a stench—that of a dead cat. If it were not so potentially serious it would be regarded as something out of a fantasy land cartoon of Walt Disney.

SPEECH.PARA: What are the issues floating around in this debate? There is waterfront reform. Then there is ongoing industrial relations reform in the maritime industries. There is policy advice via a range of consultancies costing well over $1 million to date. We have a series of former Liberal Party staffers and policy advisers to former premiers and leaders of government. We have a refusal by the government to table documents relating to those consultancies, despite orders of the Senate to do so. We have former soldiers undergoing training in the Middle East in the use of mechanical equipment and they have an expectation of work in four Australian ports—in Perth, Melbourne, Sydney and Brisbane.

The agenda of the current government is quite clear. The Workplace Relations Act, passed with great fanfare less than 12 months ago, is not working as hoped. The current government are unable to address and achieve any worthwhile reform that improves productivity and reduces costs on the waterfront and in the broader maritime industries. Their solution is not one of dialogue, not one of consultation, not one of agreed progress. Instead, what do we hear? What do we know from Senate estimates? They ring up a few old mates. They go through a dubious tender process where government at highest levels invites six or seven firms or individuals to tender to develop strategies for waterfront reform. They allocate hundreds of thousands of dollars over a 12‐month period to pay for those consultancies.

What is the result? The result is the most predictable that anyone with any experience could anticipate. What is the recommendation from those consultancies that cost hundreds of thousands of dollars? What do they say? They say, `Blame the Maritime Union of Australia for all the ills and all the evils on the waterfront.' They say, `Plan to provoke a major strike in key industry. Prepare to dismiss some or all of the current work force in select ports around Australia. Prepare, most importantly, for that outcome by having a contingency plan involving replacement of the current labour force by ex‐army personnel recently trained in the use of mechanical and operational equipment on wharves.' They paid for that sound advice to the tune of $600,000.

The use of army personnel and their having to go to the Middle East is at least intriguing. Really, when one thinks about it, it is amazing. Once upon a time every tin‐pot terrorist group in the world would send their recruits to Libya, Iran and Iraq to train as mercenaries and soldiers to blow people up, cause mayhem and hijack planes. What does the Australian government have to say? At best, Minister Reith, speaking yesterday, was reported in today's press as giving a nod and wink to former soldiers to head off to the Middle East to be trained. Trained for what? To operate forklifts and cranes. We have hundreds of firms across Australia that cannot train people to do that sort of work? We have hundreds of firms that are not offering that sort of thing? No, you have to go off to the Middle East to be trained to operate a forklift. What an absurdity!

What is the situation in Australia? Do we have ongoing strikes on the waterfront? Is there chaos? Is there wildcat action? No. It is as quiet as it has been for years and years. We have a peaceful group of workers going about their labour every day and engaging in normal home and community activities. What is the reaction of the Australian government and Minister Reith? He permits and encourages $2 companies to hire ex‐soldiers to train in the Middle East as part of a contingency plan to break the union on the waterfront. What a disgraceful effort that is. What a terrible position for any government to be in. What have the government's proposals been on waterfront reform? (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman, Sen Grant

TALK.START.PARA: —What a disgraceful performance from Senator Bishop, that he would sink so low as to misrepresent an interjection that I made on Senator Mackay. Senator Mackay in her remarks was claiming that Senator Ferguson and the rest of us on the government side had been briefed on this issue of training of waterfront workers in Dubai. I responded that that was not true and that in fact I was developing my remarks in relation to this debate as the debate was going along, not that I was not making it up as I was going along, as Senator Bishop falsely claimed. In fact, I was carefully listening to the debate and developing my response on the basis of my own knowledge and not any briefing that had not been given to us by anyone else.

SPEECH.PARA: What this issue highlights is the monumental failure of the previous Labor government to achieve anything with regard to Australia's much needed waterfront reform. They spent millions and millions of dollars when they were in government and gave the retiring wharfies golden handshakes of $100,000 and more.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, $600,000 even, Senator Bishop interjects. Yet all they achieved was a very temporary improvement in the performance of the waterfront, which was soon lost and the performance slipped back to its previous unsatisfactory level. Not only did the waterfront performance, after a year or two of improvement, slip back to its previous level with regard to Australian performance, but it slipped further and further behind other ports across the world, because those ports were continually improving in their performance as we fell further and further behind.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason is that the waterfront is the scene of the greatest workplace rorts in Australia: we have crib time, smokos, ghost employees and all the rest of the workplace rorts evident on the waterfront. When it came to waterfront reform, the previous Labor government was on one long smoko. I well remember the wharfies—

TALK.START.PARA: —What about your office! What about the overtime rorts in your staff?

—Not only the overtime rorts. I well remember the wharfie called `judge' because he was always sitting on a case. The wealth and job creation for this country are absolutely dependent on increasing the export sales of goods produced in this country and to achieve that we must be competitive. Australia's waterfront inefficiencies and costs reduce the competitiveness of this country and of our goods on international markets significantly. We simply cannot afford the inefficiency in costs of the Australian waterfront.
—Why aren't you doing something about it? You've had 18 months.

—This government is doing something about it and it is determined to ensure, Senator Bishop, that waterfront reform occurs, unlike the previous Labor government which achieved absolutely nothing in 13 years in government. Of course, when we set out to achieve reform, apologists for the waterfront unions cry foul. They say, `You cannot make comparisons between Australian ports and some overseas ports because they are larger' or `they have better facilities' or whatever. That certainly is not the case.

SPEECH.PARA: But if we want to answer that complaint, let us have a look at a country that we can certainly compare ourselves with in history and culture and every other thing—New Zealand. Ten years ago New Zealand embarked on significant waterfront reform. At that time, their basic working conditions and the structure of their waterfront was virtually identical with Australia. Their workplace culture was virtually identical with Australia. Yet they set about reform in a dedicated way and now they simply leave us for dead in terms of the efficiency of their ports because they applied themselves in a disciplined way to waterfront reform and we have ignored that task.

Of course, what is now happening is that New Zealand exporters, in particular, but indeed the whole New Zealand economy and the New Zealand people, are benefiting from that greater efficiency on their waterfront. Australia desperately needs that sort of reform on our waterfront. This country, above all, is an exporting nation and if we are going to grow jobs and grow our economy we have to lift the income that we earn from exports. We simply cannot do that with the current level of efficiency in our ports, both in terms of container ports and general ports. We need the reform program in place and we do not need it frustrated by union activity. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for the debate has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make this personal explanation because of numerous media reports. I will name one in particular, but there are a number of others. In today's Daily Telegraph newspaper, there is an article by Piers Akerman headed `Hidden gender opens cleavage in sports ranks', where I and a number of my colleagues on the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee are named with regard to a report that we presented to this Senate two days ago. We were also named in a series of articles that appeared in, for example, the Hobart Mercury yesterday under the heading `Sport may be mixed bag for women.'; yesterday in the Daily Telegraph under the heading `Boys will be girls in sports events'; yesterday in the Adelaide Advertiser under the heading `Senate committee recommends rights for transsexuals: men in women's sport'; and yesterday in the Melbourne Herald-Sun under the heading `Sex swap sport move'. All of the latter named articles were by Matthew Horan.

SPEECH.PARA: In order to give this explanation, I have to quote a few facts. I do not have any problem with quoting facts as substance with regard to this. In the tabling statement that I presented to the Senate on Tuesday, I made this very brief statement:

The report makes no recommendations about sport—The evidence did not demonstrate that there was much interest in competitive sport by transgender persons and the Committee considers this issue can be dealt with by the relevant sporting organisations on a case by case basis.

The report itself is over 300 pages long with all the appendices in it. Sport was rated so highly in that 300-page report that it warranted six paragraphs. That is just over one page out of a 300-page report.

BREAK.PARA: I will not read each and every media article I have mentioned, but the reportage has it that the majority of the committee—that is, the Labor members of the committee together with the Democrat representatives—recommended that transsexual persons be allowed to compete in women's sports events. The committee made 33 recommendations. None of those recommendations made any comment whatsoever about transgendered persons participating in competitive sport.

It was an 18-month inquiry. The committee heard evidence from a wide range of people. Participation in sport was not one of the big issues in the committee's deliberations, but it was raised by some submissions. For example, Ms Heather Reid, the executive officer from Womensport Australia, who appeared at the Canberra hearings, had this to say:
Womensport Australia has worked quite closely with the Women and Sport Unit on this particular issue. We would like to basically support the proposed bill—
we were investigating a bill—
and the comments and recommendations made by the Women and Sport Unit . . .
Ms Debbie Simms is the manager of the Women and Sport Unit in the Participation Division of the Australian Sports Commission. She had this to say at that very same hearing:

Basically, I suppose, the commission's point of view is that we support the legislation—the basic philosophy behind it. We have a few concerns, however, about its relation to sport and specifically to competitive sport.
She went on in a different part of the same paragraph:

In terms of the competitive sport aspect, there are two points of view and at this stage the Australian Sports Commission feels that we cannot provide advice as to which way this Senate committee should go. We feel basically that some research needs to be conducted before an informed decision can be made.
The committee heard this evidence and certainly took it into account in developing the report.

I take this opportunity to commend a number of other journalists, including Jody Brough from the Sydney Morning Herald and Rebecca Rose from the West Australian newspaper. Ms Brough and Ms Rose did read the report. Unfortunately, Mr Akerman and Mr Horan did not. They did not even take the time to read the tabling statement and the one paragraph in the tabling statement that referred to this issue in this report. There is no recommendation about this issue in the report, and there was never going to be.

What has happened with Mr Horan and Mr Akerman reflects personally on them. Importantly, it reflects on the profession they represent that they should so mislead merely for a sensational headline on this issue, which is a very emotional one, particularly for transgendered persons and their families. I hope that my short explanation here this afternoon will clear the matter. If the journalists named want to check the matter further, I invite them to call me. My extension number is 3416. They can ring me at any time. I always return telephone calls.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Food Labelling
PETITION.PARA: We, the undersigned citizens and residents of Australia, call on all Senators to support implementation of the following:

PARA.TAB: a requirement to label with the production process, all foods from genetic engineering technologies or containing their products;
real public participation in decisions on whether to allow commercialisation of foods, additives and processing agents produced by gene technologies;
premarket human trials and strict safety rules on these foods, to assess production processes as well as the end products.

PETITION.PARA: Precedents which support our petition include several examples of foods already labelled with the processes of production; irradiated foods (internationally); certified organic foods; and many conventional foods (pasteurised; salt‐reduced; free‐range; vitamin‐enriched; to name only a few).
We ask you all to accord a high priority to supporting and implementing our petition.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: Brown, Sen Bob; Lees, Sen Meg
PETITION.TITLE: Logging and Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
For permanent protection of old‐growth forests and all other areas of high conservation value, and for the implementation of tree plantation strategies.

This petition from the undersigned respectfully points out that: there is an increasing and urgent demand from the people, to protect all remaining high conservation value forests which support flora and fauna unique to Australia, thus complying with the United Nations Biodiversity Convention to which Australia is a signatory. We have a responsibility to future and present generations, and the necessary reasons, knowledge and technology to act now on the following achievable solutions.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate legislate to:

PARA.TAB: immediately stop all logging and woodchipping activities in high conservation value native forests;

ensure intergenerational equity by planning for the rights of future generations, and protecting in perpetuity all biologically diverse old‐growth forests, wilderness, rainforests and critical habitats of endangered species;

facilitate rapid transition of the timber industry from harvesting high conservation value native forests, to establishing mixed‐species farm forestry on existing cleared and degraded lands, using non‐toxic methods to protect ecological sustainability;

maximise use of readily‐available plantation timber for industry needs, using appropriate forestry techniques and progressive minimal‐waste processing methods, such as radial sawing, and wherever possible, reuse and recycle wood and paper products;

support incentives for nationwide employment in composting, soil remineralisation programs, and the planting programs of trees and annual fibre crops, inter‐grown with appropriate fruit and nut trees and medicinal plants;

encourage sensitively‐managed, environmental education tourism in appropriate forest areas, with full respect for natural ecosystems, Aboriginal cultural heritage, sacred sites and other sites of significance; and

progressively utilise technological expertise and resources transferred from the military sector, to help implement these tree planting solutions; and to motivate the international community to follow this example.

PETITION.PARA: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Brown(from 1,339 citizens)and Senator Lees(from 3,044 citizens)

PETITION.TITLE: Native Title
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.

The Petition of the undersigned requests that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples of this country are treated justly and fairly. It is in the interest of all to build this nation in a spirit of reconciliation and cooperation with Australians of diverse racial and ethnic backgrounds.

We call on you to ensure that regional agreements with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples are pursued in good faith, so as to determine their rights to their land in a spirit of reconciliation.

The co‐existence of Native Title and Pastoral Leases on Crown Land is supported by legal principle and historic fact, upheld by the High Court. The people and Governments of Australia have a moral responsibility to give this fact real and just effect.
We call on members of the Senate to ensure that legislation regarding Native Title
(i) complies with internationally recognised principles of non‐discrimination; and
(ii) promoted Reconciliation with Australia's first peoples.

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee is considering group 7, renewals and extensions on running sheet 15, and amendments 25A and 25B moved by Senator Minchin. The question is that amendments 25A and 25B moved by Senator Minchin be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two reasons for me standing up at this stage. One is to allow other members of the committee with an interest in this matter to come back into the chamber and the other reason is to make some comments in respect of these amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: We do not have a major concern with these amendments. As I said earlier, some may need to await further deliberation and some may need to wait until we move either opposition amendments, Senator Harradine's amendments or Greens‐Democrat amendments. In the meantime, I ask Senator Minchin—given that the running sheet does not list his amendments in renewals and extensions—whether he can briefly explain to us what they are.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will restate the nature of these amendments which the government proposes on renewals and extensions. We have been persuaded that there should be a double good faith provision in respect of offers and undertakings et cetera made before 26 December 1996. We think that it is an appropriate amendment, because it is the government's view that these matters should be valid only on the basis that they are done in good faith. It is certainly not the government's intention that there be any way to subvert these provisions. As I said before lunch, they are consistent with the wording used in the current Native Title Act.

SPEECH.PARA: With regard to 25B, we have made some amendments in other areas relating to notification. In a spirit of consensus and goodwill we have taken on board suggestions put to us from a variety of sources, including the Senate committee, that while we have been faithful to the notification arrangements in the current act the processes could be improved by additional notification procedures in a variety of areas. So we have included an additional notification provision here at the end of section 24ID to require notice to the relevant representative bodies, registered native title bodies and corporate and registered claimants who will be affected by the act and to give them an opportunity to comment on the act or class of acts. I commend those amendments to the committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —At this stage I indicate that just before lunch I withdrew amendments 71 and 72. I think the same should be done in respect of amendments 73, 77, 78, 80, 81 and 82. These also go to the same area of discussion we had before lunch, which was the extension and renewals provision to cover a licensed permit authority going beyond legally enforceable instruments. For the convenience of the committee, I indicate those withdrawals at this stage. Maybe we could proceed to the next item on the agenda, which is R79.
—Can I just clarify that you have withdrawn 71 and 72, and you are seeking to withdraw 73, 77, 78, 80, 81 and 82?

—Yes. The next item is revised 79 from the opposition. That goes to the issue of whether there should be a right of renewal and extension in respect of mining. We had this debate just before lunch, and I take this opportunity to explain what 79 is about. Since the amendment has been circulated, albeit briefly, I indicate that what we are doing with R79 is adding at the end of subsection (1) of schedule 1 item 9 that the original lease does not create a right to mine. By doing that we excise a capacity to renew a right to mine and then of course leave it open to normal processes, given the uncontrollable nature of mining.
—First of all, I have Senator Minchin's amendments 25A and 25B, which have been moved.
—I want to indicate that I will be moving my amendments 14 and 15 at some stage.
—Senator Minchin has moved 25A and 25B. I am endeavouring to clear the decks of those.
—I do not want to chuck a wobbly again. Those amendments that we just passed were not even on my running sheet.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Amendments 25A and 25B were moved prior to lunch. They do not appear on the running sheet but they were circulated.

INTERJECT.PARA: (79) Schedule 1, item 9, page 56 (after line 27), at the end of subsection (1), add:

TAB.TAB: ; and (f) the original lease does not create a right to mine; and
(g) the renewed, re‐granted, re‐made or extended lease is subject to the heritage protection requirements (see section 238A).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I can see what the opposition is doing in this, but I would have thought that there is a problem. I will ask Senator Minchin about it. If the original lease enabled the right to mine, what happens with the renewal of that lease? The amendment says:

SPEECH.PARA: and . . . the original lease does not create a right to mine;

I know what you are getting at. It is really to trigger a right to negotiate. We are going to have that debate in the next bracket, and I certainly am of the strong view that there should be a right to negotiate in respect of a mining lease on a pastoral lease. The government has another view. I certainly am firmly of an opposite view to the government on that matter. I think that the issue of right to negotiate ought to be dealt with in the next bracket and not inferentially here.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not mind taking that proposal on board. We can, in fact, leave it for discussion in respect of the right to negotiate. It is probably a constructive idea, so why don't we defer it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —What I am saying is that we ought to be right up front and deal with the whole issue then. This is, in my view, not the area. You could have a situation where there is a mining lease on a pastoral lease and the operators of the mine are happily going on with their job. I wonder whether your amendments would require certain other steps to be taken before the pastoral lease is renewed, which may affect the continuance of the mining operation on that pastoral lease. My own view is that I am inclined to vote against amendment R79, and then let us face the whole issue head‐on in the next bracket. I will speak to my amendment now.
—I will respond to Senator Harradine after he speaks to his amendment, but I find the timing between quite useful.

—My amendment 14 seeks to omit clause 241C(4)(b) and (c). I must say that the reason I am doing it is pretty obvious. Future acts that are permissible leases, et cetera should not include renewed leases or authorities which are for longer terms than the original lease or authority. Certainly no compelling case has been made for renewing leases for longer terms, let alone for making Western Australian pastoral leases perpetual.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that there is an argument, discussion, going on in Western Australia, but my amendment ensures that pastoralists have certainty and that, with certainty, they can renew their leases on identical terms and conditions as their previous lease without the need to negotiate. That is the point: they can get their renewal on the same conditions without the need to negotiate. I think that it is reasonable, though, that if there are going to be enhanced conditions in the terms and conditions of the renewed lease, then the persons affected, namely, the native title holders, should have some say in the matter. At least they should be consulted and there should be a right to negotiation. Any more than that would, I believe, be an overreach which could be used for long‐term suppression of surviving native title. That is what concerns me. It would be a bit by bit approach which would have the same long‐term effect.

It has been put to me that perhaps one should support the idea of perpetual lease because under the Wik judgment perpetual lease means perpetual coexistence. If you look at the bottom line of Wik, native title rights can coexist with pastoral leaseholders' rights. But, to be serious about the matter, I think the principles of my amendment are desirable, that is to say, if there is to be a renewal let it be on the same terms and conditions or otherwise let those other persons who are affected, like native title holders, have the right to be consulted about the additional terms and conditions.

My amendment 15, section 241C(4)(d)(2) relating to future acts that are permissible lease renewals, allows a diversification of activity. It ought to be a legal requirement and not simply a likely outcome that the majority of the area remain for primary production activities. There would be no problem in policing this particular requirement. If they are pastoral leases, they are pastoral leases. I think it is only fair that there should be a legal requirement for primary production activities to be the majority activity. I understand that is acceptable around the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN

TALK.START.PARA: —The government has no objection to Senator Harradine's amendment 15, but we are not in a position to support amendment 14 which would have the effect of removing the capacity to renew a lease for a longer term than the original lease and renewals, and involves a perpetual lease being granted. There is some misunderstanding in rural circles on this. Longer term or perpetual only goes to the term of the lease; it does not pertain to the rights granted under the lease. The coexistence of rights is a function of the rights granted under the lease and the interrelationship with any surviving native title rights.

SPEECH.PARA: We believe that the Commonwealth parliament should not interfere with the states' rights to grant perpetual leases. What we do interfere with, obviously through these provisions, is their capacity to change the rights granted under the lease, and that is part of our package. But when it comes to the term—which has, as I say, nothing to do with the rights granted under lease, what can actually be done on the land—we think that is an undue interference. After all, the provisions would otherwise allow the terms to be renewed on and on anyway. It seems that it makes no difference to allow a perpetual lease and we do think pastoralists who want security of tenure should be entitled to seek a perpetual lease, given that we are not talking about the rights and therefore we are not talking about the interrelationship with any coexisting native title.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the point that is made by the minister. The essential point is, I suppose, one of public appreciation of the issue. In other words, if there is a substantial change in the conditions of the lease, then obviously that is in a different category and I apologise to the committee. What I am getting at is: if you get a situation whereby the actual term of the lease is extended to a time or a term beyond that of the original lease, particularly if you are looking at the term being extended in perpetuity, you create an atmosphere, an impression that the rights of the native title holders are thereby diminished.

SPEECH.PARA: What about, for example—we have not looked at this question; we will be looking at it later—if the leaseholder does not want to retain the lease at some stage after the term expires? Does the land then revert to the Crown? What occurs at that particular time? I do not think that we are looking at that very deeply, although we will come to it shortly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition is supporting an amendment identical to Senator Harradine's. I take this opportunity to put that on the record and also to indicate that one of the problems with this debate has been that we actually address issues in isolation of their overall impact. At this stage, we are talking about a capacity to go from one term to maybe a longer term and even to a perpetual lease. That in itself creates problems because it goes further than the common law. Also, if you were to recognise this capacity to extend into a perpetual arrangement combined with the capacity under the legislation to move from a pastoral lease to a primary production lease, the combined impact of both those provisions of this bill will involve, basically, an upgrade to a perpetual, all‐embracing provision which pastoralists did not have before this legislation. The consequent effect on native title could be quite damaging. I keep on saying in this debate that the discriminatory nature of such extinguishment is also something to be considered further down the track.

SPEECH.PARA: As I say, the combined effect is something that we should look at here. You could get a situation where, because of the impact of this legislation, a lease rightly renewed but renewed under this provision into a perpetual lease, together with the permissible greater level of activity, could basically be a de facto upgrade to long‐term freehold, and that is something that we should be concerned about. It may not technically be freehold, but the long‐term impact of what we would be doing here would be something that Wik, for a start, did not anticipate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am struggling with a couple of issues. I note that Senator Bolkus withdrew 71, 72 and some other amendments. The Democrats‐Greens (WA) amendments were identical to those. We have not withdrawn those and would, perhaps, want them put. I know there was an exchange between Senator Bolkus and Senator Minchin before lunch but I am afraid it was not sufficiently clear to me what the exchange was about. It was obviously the basis for withdrawing these and, if I could hear again perhaps from Senator Bolkus the reason for withdrawing, we would be clearer. I guess it would be simpler if we put our amendments. I know what will happen to them if we do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —The reason why we did withdraw those amendments was the quite compelling argument from the government that the amendments were basically picking up the language of the existing act. Our advice was that the amendments that we were moving were intended to ensure only legally enforceable arrangements were able to be renewed but, as Senator Harradine said before lunch, if you were to look at section 238A of the legislation, you would find already this provision for a similar range of instruments. For that reason, we thought the concerns that were held were held in a way that probably we could not sustain in the course of the debate.

(76) Schedule 1, item 9, page 56 (lines 6 to 10), omit subparagraph (iii).

Opposition amendment 88 and Democrat‐Green amendment 80 are identical, and Senator Harradine's goes to the same point. There is a distinction between them. The opposition and Democrat‐Green amendment basically wants to retain a situation where the benchmark test is as to pastoral activities whereas Senator Harradine's amendment allows for an essential upgrade to primary production but puts in a strip test to ensure there are some controls with respect to what is included in primary production. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —This issue before us now is the right to negotiate. As I think most of us will accept, native title is nothing unless you have the right to negotiate it. What we are concerned about here is that the government provisions reduce the right to negotiate to some six to eight per cent of Australia. We are dealing here with the main provisions to do this—the main one being item 9 on page 6 of the bill.
—Do you think we'll get another map?

—Yes, you would probably just retain the size of Tasmania in terms of that map, but I am sure we are not just talking about retaining the right to negotiate for only Tasmania in this debate. We are talking about a particular provision—division 3, part 2—which replaces the old right to negotiate provisions with a new regime. As I said, the total effect of the government's provisions would reduce the right to negotiate to apply only to some six to eight per cent of the landmass in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Minchin might say that is meaningless but, as Senator Woodley quite appropriately interjected, the map that has been shown to Australia already suggests that 79 per cent of this country is currently accessible to the right to negotiate. We dispute that figure, but I do not think the government can run away from the fact that, by removing the right to negotiate on pastoral leases, we would be reducing the coverable area enormously—as I said, to the extent of some six to eight per cent of Australia only. The right to negotiate is important. Native title is meaningless without some mechanism to protect it against arbitrary impairment or disruption.

The Labor Party position here is that the right to negotiate should continue to apply. What are we talking about? We are not talking about a right of veto; we are talking about a right that provides protection of native title as well as a fair process for resource development in Australia. The basis of the right is a fair balance of interest between the need to protect native title and the culture that underlies that title, and to provide for compensation and the needs of resource developers. It is restricted in its application to mining—that includes mining and exploration activity that affects native title—and to compulsory acquisition of native title for the purposes of granting an interest in land to a non-government party.

The current focus of our amendments is that the right to negotiate should continue in the context of mining and exploration. There is some confusion as to how it operates. It is straightforward. It is directed by a state or territory government issuing a notice that it intends to deal with land in a section 29 notice. That notice then follows with a requirement for native title holders to register their interests in the land by lodging and satisfying the registrar of the tribunal, or a similar state or territory body, of the bona fides of their claim. There is then provision for a short period for good faith in negotiations—and I stress good faith in negotiations—between the native title holders, the resource developers and the relevant government. Then there is a process of independent arbitration. If an agreement is not reached within four months in terms of exploration or six months in terms of mining, then acquisition. Then there is a capacity at that stage for the relevant state minister to override the decision of the arbitrator.

Our proposals as embodied and reflected by the 1993 legislation are an alternative to the common law. They provide a certain process and they provide certain outcomes. In return for that, they also provide certainty and security for all titles and grants. So what we are saying is that, fundamentally, the right to negotiate process is a fair one. It does balance instruments and it is a basis for development and improvement rather than abolition, as the government is doing.

The government has made some fundamental misunderstandings in terms of what it wants to do here. The right to negotiate lies very much at the core of the Native Title Act. It ensures that the NTA conforms with the Racial Discrimination Act and, importantly, the just term requirements of the constitution. The right to negotiate is—and we should place this on the record—part of the 1993 Native Title Act package through which indigenous people did give much, the past act regime, for instance. What the government is doing here by its removal of the right to negotiate in these areas is leaving this particu lar bill—if not the act—open to constitutional challenge and, as a consequence, exposing state and territory land administration to ongoing uncertainty. The other thing is that, if you act in a manner contrary to the convention on the elimination of racial discrimination and the RDA, it does have international ramifications for Australia. This area is one of those areas mentioned by the Chief General Counsel as an area of concern in terms of breaching that convention and the Racial Discrimination Act.

We do have concerns with the government's proposal and this is another misunderstanding the government has. The government's proposal goes very much to the question of physical impact. It disregards the cultural nature of native title and the spiritual attachment of native title holders to land. It is based on, we believe, long discredited theories of assimilation. For example, proposed section 43A of the legislation removes, as I said earlier, the right to negotiate from much of the Australian continent. Even for major mining projects where land is subject to a pastoral lease, this government's legislation allows states and territories to replace the right to negotiate procedures with procedures under state mining legislation. Those procedures do not take into account the concept of native title; they take into account a much more limited range of factors. As I said, this is borne out of a real misunderstanding of the concept of Native Title.

We should also remember when we are approaching this area that indigenous Australians do have alternatives. They got these rights through the common law—through Mabo and latterly through Wik. The system has to take native title into account. It has not as yet. Two hundred years of non-recognition means that much of our legislation dealing with land has to factor this concept of native title into it. We in this place have to factor in important considerations flowing from the just terms provisions of the constitution, the racist power of the constitution, the RDA and, above all of those legalistic requirements, a sense of morality with which we approach discussion on this issue. If you want uncertainty, then you do what the government is doing. By doing what you are doing, we will finish up back in the court, and we will finish up with some major constitutional problems.

I will move to the improvements. Through the debate on this particular legislation we have, in fact, adopted a new registration test and procedures. We have adopted new processes for claims and so on. We have adopted a new regime for registration. I think those new procedures were of importance to an enormous range of stakeholders. Those stakeholders, at the end of the day, can quite reasonably say that they have got out of this process much more than they would have expected.

At this stage, I will talk about how we anticipate the right to negotiate should operate. I will come back later on during the debate to the once-off or twice-available right to negotiate. The right to negotiate in respect of mining can best be demonstrated by greenfield arrangements. Under the Labor Party proposals, with not only the capacity for a one-off right to negotiate but also the capacity to have that right both at exploration and at mining, the following would be the situation. If you are talking about a greenfield operation, an exploration licence would be obtained, in the case of high impact exploration, through a right to negotiate. In the case of low impact exploration, you would find that the expedited procedures are likely to apply. In those circumstances, the right to negotiate is bypassed.

We think it is important for the right to negotiate to apply to exploration because, quite often, there could be impacts on native title at that stage—not always, but quite often. We believe that processes provided by the act at the moment—through which an agreement must be reached within four months in terms of an exploration permit, after which the matter can go to arbitration—are not unreasonable. In terms of developing a proposal to mine, four months can be factored into long-term arrangements, into arrangements for raising capital and into all sorts of other requirement processes that people have to go through. This should not mean an extra delay. However, what it does mean is that indigenous Australians can have some reasonable notice through which they can protect their interests.

Our proposal allows for arbitration. It also allows for conjunctive agreements. Future mining, for instance, can be agreed to under the right to negotiate provisions at the exploration stage or through an ILUA. Of course, this would suit those who have petroleum and diamond projects, which have a high cost, up-front intensive activity level. Later on down the track you do not have any real growth in the activity. These conjunctive arrangements may not be suitable to large and small scale mining. In those circumstances, exploration licences usually cover extensive areas and numbers of native title groups at the start. The mining that then follows is usually over relatively small prospective areas and is unlikely to involve, for instance, all of the groups involved in the exploration agreement.

So with greenfield arrangements, we need to recognise that the capacity to have that right to negotiate at the exploration stage is important. They should not be cumbersome, particularly now that we have new procedures and registration tests in place. With brownfield arrangements, if there is a mining lease, it would be valid.

So I say to the Senate that we are concerned we protect the right to negotiate. We are also concerned that the Senate focus on a capacity for that right to be a bit more flexible than what the government is providing. That flexibility should be able to be triggered at the exploration stage, but such triggering should have the capacity to cover, where the parties agree, the mining stage as well.

I think it is very hard for us to put in place a regime which does not accommodate the exploration stage, particularly when some parts of industry would prefer to have it there and when other parts of industry would like to have it at the other end. It is also hard, particularly when indigenous Australians state quite clearly that it is important for them to have it at the early stages for a number of reasons: firstly, it is necessary to protect heritage sites; and, secondly, fundamental to any mining project, it would give an opportunity at the start of the process to develop a relationship between the miners and indigen ous Australians. They have to live with each other long after the exploration process. Having that capacity to bring people together at the early stage is quite important.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —At the start of this debate I would like to make some remarks about the right to negotiate. It is obviously a very sensitive issue, and it is one that is at the top of the political agenda with regard to the question of native title.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the key issues that had to be addressed when the Mabo decision was made and legislation was being framed to incorporate native title into our land law system was: what procedural rights should attach to the common law right to native title? Obviously the Mabo judgment was silent on that. It could have been left to the common law. The response could have been not to do anything but to leave it entirely to the common law.

The parliament's approach was to frame the Native Title Act and to take it as the base measuring stick for dealing with native title—on the presumption that native title could survive on vacant crown land and Aboriginal land—to equate it to freehold for the purposes of a legislative framework. Therefore, the appropriate procedural rights that would attach to common law native title, prima facie, were then regarded as the rights of freeholders. Whatever procedural rights freeholders had in Australia—that is, the rest of us who own freehold—they would attach to common law native title.

The parliament went one step further and, in a few respects, attached a greater right than would normally attach to freehold and described it as `the right to negotiate'. That was specifically set as a right which would attach to mining on land on which native title may have survived and compulsory acquisitions for third parties. Those were the two things. This extra right, on top of the freehold right, was prescribed by the parliament.

I think those facts are important because there is a lot of misunderstanding in the community. I am not accusing anybody of misleading anybody, but there is obviously a misunderstanding in the community about what it is, what it applies to and what the nature of it is. It is a statutory right provided in those two circumstances—mining and compulsory acquisition—which goes beyond the standard of freehold procedural rights in relation to native title claimants. Of course, it does attach to claimants as well as holders of native title.

If you read the second reading speech by Mr Keating, it was originally envisaged, and this is set down in the current act, that a mechanism would be found to ensure that, by and large, exploration would be excluded from the right to negotiate. But that has proved unworkable for a variety of reasons involving various court cases. The former government's original intention that, in most circumstances, the right to negotiate would not apply to exploration has not proved true and has not worked.

I must say that when our government came in—and I think we picked up on the experience which the previous government had had—there were, as you would expect, teething problems in the way in which the right to negotiate was operating, essentially flowing from the breakdown in the registration test. It meant that basically anyone could make a claim and anyone could then be party to the right to negotiate process. The whole thing was breaking down badly.

It was certainly put to me very strongly in all the discussions I had that the most critical thing was an effective registration test or otherwise the right to negotiate process could never work properly because of the extraordinary number of competing claims and because an agreement can only be reached if you get everybody to agree. You only need one person to stand out of 18 or 20 separate claims and there is no agreement. Therefore, you are into arbitration or someone goes to court to appeal against the negotiation process.

I would have to say as an aside that the parliament's refusal to accept our registration test is a great pity because this is not going to solve some of the obvious problems that exist for Aboriginal people in the operation of the right to negotiate. The way the right to negotiate is currently operating is no more abun dantly made clear than in the letter which I know you are all aware of from former Labor leader Bill Hayden who got caught up in the Century issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a massive case of sour grapes on Bill's part.

—It may well have been, Senator Collins. I am sorry you feel so badly about your former leader, but I thought he spoke honestly about the process in that case. We sat with the Waanyi elders who described to us their heartbreak. The proposition they put to us, which we have not taken up, was that, in the right to negotiate process, you should be able to have a situation where, if a majority of parties can come to an agreement, the agreement should be signed. They said to us that the problem was if you had just one person who refused to participate or join in the process of reaching agreement, the whole thing broke down very badly. We have not adopted that particular proposition put to us by the Waanyi elders.

SPEECH.PARA: It was also put to us quite widely that one of the real social issues with the right to negotiate is the fact that it is a procedural right attaching only to native title and not available to any other Australians. People have asked, `Why don't you just do what the parliament originally should have done, and that is say that the procedural rights attaching to native title shall be the procedural rights attaching to freeholders,' which, I think, speaking objectively, would have been a fair approach. We have not done that.

We have retained the right to negotiate for mining and compulsory acquisitions for third parties in most respects on vacant crown land. We are not abolishing or removing the right to negotiate. It remains for Aboriginal land and vacant crown land in relation to mining and compulsory acquisitions for third parties—its original intention.

The most sensitive issue has been, of course, what do you do now about pastoral leases because, by definition, it was never contemplated by the former government that the right to negotiate process would operate on pastoral leases because the act was never intended to apply on pastoral leases. It was a process envisaged as applying, in relation to native title claims, to the land on which native title was thought to have survived—Aboriginal land or vacant crown land; about 37 per cent of Australia.

We in government then faced a new situation, a situation that did not face the former government: what do you do about the procedural rights attaching to native title claims made over land on which there is a pastoral lease and there is a coexisting title holder? I hope the Senate would treat the government with some respect on the basis that we have approached this matter as one of equity. We have said that the only way we think we can deal with this issue of what procedural rights should attach to native title claimants and holders on pastoral leases is to have equality of procedural right—that is, that the native title holders should be granted by law the same procedural rights as their coexisting title holder.

Some, not us, could argue, `Hang on a minute. The High Court said that the pastoral rights are statutory rights and are a superior bundle of rights and prevail over the native title rights. So why this approach?' We have said no. In the two issues in which the right to negotiate is triggered—that is, mining and compulsory acquisition—we think the fair, equitable and sensible approach is to say that the appropriate procedural rights to attach to native title claimants and holders are the procedural rights attaching to the pastoral family that have the lease over the land. That means that, when mining or a compulsory acquisition for a third party is proposed on land on which there is a lessee and a coexisting native title holder, they are treated equally. They both join in the process that determines whether or not the development proceeds and on what basis. We think as a matter of fundamental principle that there is no other fair or equitable approach.

I would also say on this issue that the fact that the native title rights on a pastoral lease cannot, by definition, be the same as native title rights on vacant crown land or Aboriginal land is a matter that we must consider and that the government has considered and has acted accordingly. By definition, native title on Aboriginal land or vacant crown land can be up to exclusive possession. Therefore, at least the freeholders' rights should attach to activity development on land, but there is this additional right to negotiate which we are essentially leaving on vacant crown land and Aboriginal land.

But on pastoral lease land the native title rights, by definition, are only what rights survive after you take account of the rights granted to the pastoralist based on the Wik judgment. Any surviving native title rights are subject to the rights of the pastoralists. Therefore, the native title on a pastoral lease cannot amount to the same bundle of rights as it can on vacant crown land or Aboriginal land. Therefore, a different approach to the procedural rights issue is appropriate. On that score of the nature of the native title on a pastoral lease compared with vacant crown land or Aboriginal land and the fact that you have a situation where other Australians are sharing the land, we do believe—and we do hold this view from the basis of a fundamental philosophical position—that the procedural rights should be the same.

I appreciate that this is the most sensitive issue. We have tried to approach it honestly, fairly and from a position of equity. No doubt later in this debate the government will be abused, hounded and called racist scum, et cetera—I am saying it for everybody else before they can say it to me. We have tried to approach this very difficult issue from that perspective. We have tried to balance the critical importance to this nation for all Australians and for Aboriginal Australians of a mining industry which we have said repeatedly in this place offers the greatest hope for development of jobs, income and business skills for Aboriginal Australians living outside our towns and cities. The mining industry is absolutely critical to their opportunities in life.

So you have to get this balance between appropriate procedural processes with respect to native title holders and the question of mining and, at the same time, not act in such a way that you are actually deterring that mining activity, which is so important to the future of Aboriginal people. It can generate jobs, security, income and business skills and things that I think are so important for the long-term security and livelihood of Aboriginal Australians.

How do you get that balance right? We may never agree on where the balance should be, but I hope the Senate would pay some respect to the fact that we have tried to get the balance right. We do encourage the mining industry to do its utmost to involve Aboriginal people in mining developments. I think it is true that the mining industry has become much more enlightened. Some of the things the mining industry is doing in developing Aboriginal businesses in association with mining developments is tremendous. That has to be encouraged and supported.

It is the case that increasingly mining companies are seeking overseas opportunities for exploration and investment. They are finding the climate in Australia very difficult. The way the right to negotiate process is operating at the moment—there are enormous backlogs, delays and opportunities to put in place enormous costs in delays in having mining leases granted—is acting as a considerable disincentive to an industry which, frankly, offers such enormous opportunity for Aboriginal Australians and, of course, is vital to our national welfare and our capacity to look after those in need by generating the jobs and the export income for us.

That is the basis of the government's approach to this issue. We do believe that the package we put together on this issue, after much thought, is a fair and sensible one. I have a number of government amendments that I will formally move at a later stage in the debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —If terra nullius was not a lie, then I guess the use of the word `fair' by the minister, which we have just heard now and on a number of other occasions, would actually have some credibility. The right to negotiate effectively recognises the unique spiritual nature of and provides an essential minimum level of protection for native title. A number of my remarks will actually be sourced from the submission made by the National Indigenous Working Group to the Joint Native Title Committee. I thought they were particularly relevant at this stage.

BREAK.PARA: As it was agreed in 1993, the right to negotiate deals with resource development and native title by striking a finely tuned balance between the rights and interests of native title holders and those of resource developers. That balance already favours resource developers, governments and pastoralists. There is a minimum level of protection provided by the right to negotiate which takes account of the spiritual relationship between native title holders and their traditional lands. In particular, it provides the basis for the protection of areas and sites of significance, the protection and promotion of indigenous culture and community living, and maintains the ability of native title holders to enjoy and utilise the natural environment. It provides no right of veto over any development.

Any alteration of the right to negotiate against the interests of native title holders will place it and its processes below the necessary minimum level for the protection of native title. This is a denial of native title holders' substantive equality protected under the Racial Discrimination Act 1995 and the constitution and it is not supported by the races power in the constitution.

Given that it is acknowledged there was a trade-off in 1993, the right to negotiate was, if you like, traded off against the so-called certainty of just about every other land holder and land title in the country. Given that is now under threat, that also threatens, as we have heard from a number of learned opinions to the legal and constitutional committee, the constitutional basis of the original 1993 act.

In relation to certainty of outcome, in the case of exploration, the right to negotiate provides for certainty of outcome within two months if the expedited procedure applies. There is scope for the current right to negotiate for all parties to resolve any matters subject to the right to negotiate by negotiation prior to an arbitrated outcome. However, should the parties involved fail to agree, the right to negotiate provides for absolute certainty through arbitrated outcomes for exploration in eight months even in the exploration interferes with community life and sacred sites and involves a major disturbance to the land and waters, with mining and land acquisition for grant to a third party in 12 months.

The removal or diminution of the right to negotiate is such that it no longer contains the minimum level of protection for native title and will create uncertainty by forcing native title holders outside the Native Title Act and into the courts to challenge legislation that impairs or removes native title rights and/or to seek injunctions to protect their common law rights. These litigious, costly and uncertain scenarios are not in the interests of native title holders or governments or resource developers.

The right to negotiate deals with the backlog in the determination of the native title. It is as a result of the failure of Australian governments to protect indigenous rights in the past that there is a backlog in the determination of native title throughout the country, such determinations being the prescribed means of acknowledgment of existing common law or native title rights. The right to negotiate addresses this problem in a balanced way by providing for the interests of resource developers and those of as yet undetermined native title holders who can only access the right to negotiate after lodging a claim and passing a reasonable threshold test.

The expedited procedure is the existing procedure. Activities such as exploration can bypass the right to negotiate through an expedited procedure which removes the right to negotiate if the activity does not directly interfere with community life, areas or sites of particular significance, or involve a major disturbance to any land or waters. In its 1996 review of the Native Title Act, the Industry Commission reported that, due to policy differences between the states, the expedited procedure had only been used extensively in Western Australia, where the procedure had resulted in the grant of 94 per cent of applications for prospecting and exploration licences in minimum time. Other states and territories chose to ignore the Native Title Act.

The right to negotiate already favours resource developers because the right to negotiate procedure cannot be used as a veto on resource development. To the contrary, it favours resource development. Quite frequent ly, we have heard in this debate that somehow or other an agreement with a time limit is somehow a veto. Of course, it is not. The time frames for negotiation are unreasonably short for native title holders, particularly as the time used in preparing, lodging and gaining the National Native Title Tribunal's acceptance of the native title application—two months—counts against the negotiating period. If native title holders are unable to reach agreement with government and the explorer, miner or developer, the matter can go to arbitration four months after receipt of notice of the government's intention to grant the interest in exploration, and six months after receipt of the notice of mining and the acquisition of native title. As access to the right to negotiate does not arise until the claim is accepted—probably close to two months after receipt of the notice—the periods for negotiation are really two and four months respectively.

Native title holders are effectively forced to accept whatever proposal is put to them in relation to compensation in the negotiation phase, due to the limitations placed on the terms of compensation if the matter is arbitrated. This has been identified by the Commonwealth as a disincentive to constructive right to negotiate negotiations, but this observation has been ignored by the proposed amendments. There is provision for the minister to override the ruling of the arbiter in the national interest, or in the interest of the relevant state or territory. The exclusion of the right to negotiate on pastoral leases is part of the Commonwealth's acknowledgment in 1993 that native title may coexist with the grant of a pastoral lease. It excluded the right to negotiate from the renewal of pastoral leases which are granted on the same terms and conditions as the original pastoral lease. The right to negotiate offers opportunities to shift native title holders from welfare dependence to self‐reliance. For example, the right to negotiate over mining offers the opportunity to native title holders to negotiate over jobs while providing miners with a local work force in remote areas.

Negotiations over mining to date have covered such matters as restrictions on em ployees shooting wildlife or disrupting social life in nearby indigenous communities, the protection of sacred sites, job opportunities for local indigenous people, and other benefits in cash and kind. The potential effect of these provisions in operating costs ranges from negligible to the equivalent of a small increase in royalties. What is wrong with that?

The mining industry claims that native title has adversely affected mineral exploration in Australia and we believe that these claims are exaggerated. Exploration continues in Australia at near record levels despite the fact that a high proportion of the country has been explored for surface deposits using modern methods. Largely, the country has been explored in lots of ways. Given that this has occurred, and the government's promotion of offshore exploration, it is only logical that there has been a slight trend for exploration, particularly by multinational companies, to move offshore to countries that remain largely unexplored. It is a matter of falling off the end of the country to a certain extent, in terms of exploration.

Claims that native title has brought about an increase in brown fields exploration can equally be explained by the increasing proportions of middle‐aged mines in Australia. This factor has provided the economic rationale for exploration in the immediate vicinity of an existing mine in order to extend the life of mine, plant and equipment, and hence the profitability of the initial capital investment which has already been installed. I would like to remind honourable senators here that, from the sourced map that I have produced, 93 per cent of Australia's landmass is actually available for mining claims.

Against this background, it is clear that the right to negotiate provisions were intended to have at least two areas of operation. In relation to persons whose native title has been subject to determination, the right to negotiate should appropriately be seen as a recognition of the importance to native title holders of the power to control access to and activities on their land. Consistent with this approach, the right to negotiate will not necessarily apply in relation to a future act done in accordance with a registered indigenous land use agree ment. In addition, the right to negotiate reflects a second purpose, namely to permit those who may be native title holders to negotiate the terms of access to land before the opportunity to determine their claims has been fulfilled.

The National Indigenous Working Group considered that a proper interpretation of the Racial Discrimination Act convention and the Racial Discrimination Act requires that native title holders be accorded substantive or effective equality rather than formal equality. On the basis of that test, the right to negotiate may be a necessary element of legislation recognising native title, if that legislation is not to be inconsistent with the principles underpinning the Racial Discrimination Act. So I remind the Senate that all this mention of equality by the minister is based on the mistaken doctrine of terra nullius. If, on the other hand, formal equality is sufficient, both elements of the right to negotiate will nevertheless be seen as special measures justified by a past refusal to recognise native title rights and interests.

In considering whether the right to negotiate, if amended as proposed, would provide substantive equality, the government should test the legislation by a standard of strict scrutiny. In other words, given the absolute inappropriateness of discrimination on the basis of race, the government should not be allowed a wide discretion in determining what protection is necessary for native title holders. Similarly, if the legislation is to be justified as a `special measure', the government has limited room to amend the act, given the historical treatment of native title and given the fact that the Native Title Act itself constitutes a balance between the recognition of native title and the validation of past intrusions upon that title. It is against this background of these principles of racial discrimination that the proposed amendments need to be judged.

This government is excluding the right to negotiate for upgrades to full primary production on pastoral leases. This government is excluding the right to negotiate for off-farm activities connected to full primary production. This government is excluding the right to negotiate when third parties are granted the right to remove forest and quarry for sand, soil and rocks on pastoral leases. This government is excluding the right to negotiate with regard to the management and regulation of water and airspace. This government is excluding the right to negotiate in offshore places. This government is excluding the right to negotiate in towns and cities.

This government is excluding the right to negotiate with regard to certain lease renewals, extensions and upgrades. This government is excluding the right to negotiate in relation to reservations. This government is excluding the right to negotiate in the provision of facilities for services to the public. This government is excluding the right to negotiate for mining exploration, for gold and tin mining, for opal and gem mining, for the renewal of valid mining leases and for the right to negotiate on the intertidal zone. This government is effectively excluding the right to negotiate on pastoral leases and other leased or reserved areas by allowing state and territory bodies to provide cursory alternative provisions.

I can provide all the sections in the bill, and I am sure that we can circulate them if anyone me wants to. Sadly, quite a few of these rights to negotiate have already been removed by this chamber. Unfortunately, I am not sure whether Senator Harradine has seen the connection between the permissible future act provisions in this bill related to offshore places, mining renewals, reservations and management and the regulation of waters, which he has voted for, and the removal of the right to negotiate, which he has stated that he wishes to protect.

Nevertheless, consideration of subdivision P represents the most serious attack on the right to negotiate. I would like to inform the chamber that we intend to defend the right to negotiate clause by clause. To do otherwise would be to stand by and watch a form of cultural genocide take place, and I am not prepared to do that without putting up a fight. I suggest that, when we get to them, we deal with the amendments in the form in which they have been presented rather than simply take a whole column at a time. I think it is important that we do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I begin to speak, in accordance with an agreement that I have had from the government, I seek leave to table statements to the Senate from more than 1,000 Aboriginal tribal elders and community members from Arnhem Land urging the parliament to reject the government's Native Title Amendment Bill as unjust, unfair and racially discriminatory.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The right to negotiate is the core issue of this entire debate; there is no question about that. I wish to address my remarks to the comments made by Senator Minchin when he spoke a few moments ago about jobs and security being the problem and the end of life as we know it in terms of our economy. That is old rhetoric, as far as I am concerned. I have heard it a lot before and over a very long time. I also want to address the question of pastoral leases.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Margetts said correctly—I will not go over the same ground again—the question of what may be on the surface anomalous in terms of common law rights that Aboriginal people may or may not enjoy on pastoral leases and the rights of the pastoral lessee has been, since 1993, openly conceded as being a trade-off in terms of significant losses, as Aboriginal people see it, in all the other provisions of this legislation that are being considered in the cause of certainty. Validation is an example. There is no question that valuable rights that Aboriginal people may have had under that process are going to be lost. It is being done because, in my view, it would be unreasonable not to do so. This is a trade-off.

I was ploughing through some old High Court judgments on land tax, of all things. I was fascinated to discover just how long ago the High Court found that the actual conditions of pastoral leases—in this case, in Queensland—were not all that brilliant. I found an old High Court case from 1929 known as Clark Tait and Co v Federal Com missioner of Land Tax at 43 CLR. Pages 11 and 12 contain the appropriate passages.

This case involved whether the Land Tax Commissioner could prospectively levy land tax on a pastoral lease in Queensland rather than retrospectively levy it. The High Court found on appeal that he could not. What was one of the reasons why he could not? I will just quote it. There is some amazing stuff buried in law reports. Every condition known to mankind is buried in law reports somewhere. I will start at page 11:

This refers to the fact that the Land Court's assessment of rent if made after the commencement of the period in respect of which it was made related back to that commencement. A corresponding provision occurs in the lease for crediting the lessees should the Land Court's determination be of a less rent than they have in fact paid. Sec. 43 of the Queensland Lands Act as now consolidated from 1910 to 1924 provides that every pastoral lease shall be subject to the following conditions: (1) that the lease shall during the term pay an annual rent at the rate for the time being prescribed; (2) that the rent payable for the second and every succeeding period if any shall be determined by the Court.
That is the Land Court. It continues:

The Court's power to determine the rent may be exercised more than once. Under sec. 44 a power of resumption without compensation is preserved in the case of leases of which this is one.
