The power was exercisable at certain intervals and in respect of maximum proportions of the total area of the land contained in the lease. These provisions, in our opinion, coupled with the provisions of the lease itself show that on any relevant 30th June it could not be known what the future annual payments of rent were, nor what was the future duration of a tenant's right to enjoy any specific part of the land or of his right to enjoy any area of land other than a minimum area unidentified except by the fact that it must be contained in the total area originally granted. It follows from this that the lease does not fall within sec. 28(3) as we have interpreted it.

Thus the High Court found in 1929, in respect of a land tax case, that the rights of pastoral lessees in Queensland were so limited that the Land Tax Commissioner could not reasonably legally assess land tax one year ahead because those rights were not certain from one year to another.

Senator Minchin raised the point that a right to negotiate will involve damage to jobs, growth and all the rest of it. Yesterday, I read into the parliamentary record a letter to the editor of the Northern Territory News from a Territorian called Creed Lovegrove. I read that letter out because Creed Lovegrove, as I told the house yesterday, is a fourth generation non‐Aboriginal Territorian—there is still a rather small percentage of people in the Northern Territory with that pedigree. His great‐grandmother arrived in Darwin on the first passenger ship that ever came to Darwin.

Creed Lovegrove spent decades as a distinguished Northern Territory public servant, first for the Department of Welfare and then as the officer in charge of what was then the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. He is an officer who has extensive experience in these issues in the Northern Territory and is respected by people on all sides of politics. He is a conservative—and I do not think he would object to my calling him that—and he was a prominent participant in the recent campaign against euthanasia in the Northern Territory.

Senator Minchin, the rhetoric that you delivered here today might be new to you, but it is old to me; I heard people 20 and 30 years ago predicting the end of the world in the Northern Territory. I remind the Senate that Creed Lovegrove said:

As a churchgoer I don't intend to boycott church. I am able to accept the teachings of churches in matters in which they are expert and reserve my position on the personal and often biased comment of some church people on matters which I believe I am at least as well informed as they are. Perhaps the Prime Minister feels the same.

I believe there is a lot of brouhaha in the Wik debate. The Territory has had the equivalent of Wik for most of this century. It was called section 23 of the Crown Lands Ordinance and appeared on all titles to pastoral leases.

It gave Aborigines a right of entry on to, and occupation of, pastoral land for traditional purposes. Generally the pastoralists and the Aborigines concerned handled this situation fairly amicably. These reservations in the interests of Aborigines were greatly strengthened in 1976 by the Federal Government's Aboriginal Land Rights (NT) Act. They were further strengthened in 1978 by complementary NT legislation, especially the one relating to Aboriginal Sacred Sites.
Going on the NT experience, perhaps if the federal Act had applied throughout Australia we would have got over Wik by now.
Although many Territorians suffered trauma at the time—
and they did—
the situation by and large is accepted these days. There will always be those who are rabidly opposed to it but there is a lot of goodwill now on both sides by fair and reasonable Territorians.

That is what Creed Lovegrove had to say. Are his conclusions correct that the Territory got on with it despite land rights? Let me remind senators what I am talking about. I am not talking about a right to negotiate. I am talking about a part of Australia where almost 50 per cent is owned by Aboriginal people who have a right of veto—a real veto—to stop mining. Have they stopped mining? Not according to Northern Territory politicians, who always like to have it both ways. Speaking in this house in September this year, Senator Grant Tambling said:

Let me inform the Senate of the exceptional growth of the Northern Territory economy and the growth in employment that people are enjoying there. The Territory has the lowest unemployment rate: 4.8 per cent, compared with 8.2 per cent nationally. Territory employment grew 2.7 per cent last year, which is well above the national average of 0.9 per cent. Average weekly earnings increased by 4.5 per cent in the Northern Territory compared with 3.6 per cent nationally, giving territorians Australia's third highest average salaries after the ACT and New South Wales.

The Northern Territory economy continues to grow at an exceptional rate. BIS Schrapnel recently predicted a staggering economic growth of the Territory of around eight per cent, helped by three oil and gas projects worth $2.5 billion, which are expected to come on line in five to eight years. The Northern Territory government forecasts of about five per cent growth would still be the envy of other states . . .
Today, in the Northern Territory parliament, the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory said that the Northern Territory is:
. . . enjoying a rate of economic growth and prosperity which is second to none and which continues to attract high levels of interest in investment in all sectors of the Territory economy . . .
Minister, you do not have to talk theory about this—how about talking reality? You do not have to speculate about what might happen. There is an example in Australia of what did happen.

In the Northern Territory, for decades Aboriginal people have had a real veto—not the false veto that the Prime Minister of this country, I regret to say, displayed on national television. As a matter of interest, I am told that the map that the Prime Minister flashed around on television was provided to him by the National Farmers Federation, which was given it by the Bureau of Mineral Resources—at no cost, I am told.

In the entire debate on this core issue—and it is the core issue—of the right to negotiate, the performance by the leader of our country on national television, in which he said that a veto applied under the Native Title Act which would stop development on 78 per cent of Australia, is the most contemptible point the debate has reached so far. It is pretty rich coming from a person who has castigated church leaders in this country and said that they are allowed the right of free speech, but it has to be informed and constructive. Apparently, that applies to everyone except him.

The cold hard facts are that, despite the fact that almost half of the landmass of the Northern Territory is owned by Aboriginal people, and despite the fact that they have an absolute right of veto that can only be disturbed by federal action—that is, a declaration of the Governor‐General in the national interest, which has never been exercised—not only has the Northern Territory not suffered; it has prospered.

We currently have, and have had for a long time, the highest growth rate of any place in Australia. Mining is alive and well and thriving on Aboriginal land. Regrettably, the Mount Todd Gold Mine recently closed down and 250 people were sacked. That was appalling. But did that have anything to do with Aboriginal land rights? No; it was the price of gold that did that. The reason I mention that particular project is that that mine is on Aboriginal land and it was negotiated with the full agreement and cooperation of the Aboriginal people in an agreement which was praised by all sides, including the mining company.

BREAK.PARA: So, Minister, can I say to you with the greatest respect—as someone who is coming late to this debate, and you are a reasonable person, I know—speaking as someone who has been living with this for 30 years, and who listened to the same predictions from you here today as I heard from politicians 20 years ago—that it was going to be the end of life as we know it in the Northern Territory to exercise a veto over mining—the facts are that the Territory is doing better now than it has ever done in the past.

I must say that I do get a little angry about politicians who, on the one hand call leaders of the Aboriginal community in the Northern Territory `whingeing, whining blacks', who carp on about how appalling a result it would be if the right to negotiate went through this parliament, and on the other hand stand up in the Territory parliament—and they do it every second day—and boast about just how well we are doing in the Northern Territory.

Minister, I say to you with some confidence that a right to negotiate which falls so far short of a veto it is not funny, which simply gives Aboriginal people, if they can sustain some native title rights in a piece of property—and it won't be easy—the right to talk to a mining company for six months, then forces them to arbitration and then, at the end of the day, subjects them to action by a state minister, not a federal minister, who says that the mine can go ahead anyway, is not in my experience likely to damage this country at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind those people in the gallery that making a noise is disorderly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —Through you, Mr Chairman, I would like to respond to the minister and particularly his invitation to call him `racist scum'. I would never do that. As I understand it, scum is something you have left over after you boil water, for example, and I do not think he is a leftover. I suspect at the end of this debate he may be feeling like he has been boiled, and I guess all of us will. So I will not accept your invitation, Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps of all aspects of native title, the right to negotiate is instrumental. It is note worthy that the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 expands the right to negotiate provisions from a little over 10 pages in the current act to a little over 70 pages. This is an illustration of the vast expansion taken up by the detailed provisions limiting the scope of the right to negotiate.

In 1993 the right to negotiate became the prime bargaining element between the Keating Labor government, the Australian Democrats, the Greens, indigenous groups and others when it was conceded that, in return for the validation of the 1975 to 1994 acts, a strong and meaningful right to negotiate would be in place. The right to negotiate is a recognition of the special attachment that indigenous people have to their land. The Native Title Act provides that, for government acts authorising mining and the compulsory acquisition of native title for the purpose of making a grant to a third party, registered native title holders and claimants will have a right to negotiate for a limited period before such acts can take place.

The right to negotiate is not a veto. Thank you, Senator Bob Collins, I think you proved that point. It is not a veto, and it was never intended to be. It is merely a mechanism to include indigenous people. I have to say to you: they are Australians, which seems to be a point that is lost to some people.

As I pointed out in my speech in the second reading debate, the essence of native title, and indeed the future act regime in the Native Title Act 1993, is this principle of inclusiveness. It is worth again citing the wisdom of Justice Brennan in the Mabo decision when he said:

As the Governments of the Australian Colonies and, latterly, the Governments of the Commonwealth, States and Territories have alienated or appropriated to their own purposes most of the land in this country during the last 200 years, the Australian Aboriginal peoples have been substantially dispossessed of their traditional lands. They were dispossessed by the Crown's exercise of its sovereign powers to grant land to whom it chose and to appropriate to itself the beneficial ownership of parcels of land for the Crown's purposes. Aboriginal rights and interests were not stripped away by operation of the common law on first settlement by British colonists, but by the exercise of sovereign authority over land exercised recur rently by governments. To treat the dispossession of the Australian Aborigines as the working out of the Crown's acquisition of ownership of all land on first settlement is contrary to history.

So we are not talking about something that happened 209 years ago; it is something that governments have been involved in right up to the present day. And in fact today, 4 December 1997, we are still engaged in the act of taking away native title rights. Justice Brennan further said:
Aborigines were dispossessed of their land parcel by parcel, to make way for expanding colonial settlement. Their dispossession underwrote the development of this nation.
I think we ought to say that as often as we can. Justice Brennan continues:

But, if this be the consequence in law of colonial settlement, is there any occasion now to overturn the cases which held the Crown to have become the absolute beneficial owner of land when British colonists first settled here? Does it make any difference whether native title failed to survive British colonisation or was subsequently extinguished by government action? In this case, the difference is critical: except for certain transactions next to be mentioned, nothing has been done to extinguish native title in the Murray Islands.
This was, of course, the Mabo case.

There, the Crown has alienated only part of the land and has not acquired for itself the beneficial ownership of any substantial area. And there may be other areas of Australia where native title has not been extinguished and where an Aboriginal people, maintaining their identity and their customs, are entitled to enjoy their native title. Even if there be no such areas, it is appropriate to identify the events which resulted in the dispossession of the indigenous inhabitants of Australia, in order to dispel the misconception that it is the common law rather than the actions of governments which made many of the indigenous people of this country trespassers on their own land.
Well said, Justice Brennan. What Justice Brennan has pointed out to us in this excerpt from the Mabo decision is that historically we have excluded indigenous people.

With the validation provisions passing through this place this morning—that is my reference to the fact that we continue to do what governments have done for 209 years; we did it again today—this Senate, regrettably with the support of Senator Harradine, has said that between 1 January 1994 and 23 December 1996 that exclusion is now fair and just. How can it be? Intermediate period act validation is about further dispossession. It can never be just or fair.

The Australian Democrats affirm our consistent position on the right to negotiate. We see it as being essential to native title and assert that native title, without it, is just window dressing for pseudo‐reconciliation. In his explanatory memorandum, Senator Harradine says that the right to negotiate is not a native title right. That has certainly been the position of the government. I suggest respectfully that it is a well‐established point in law that rights which cannot be asserted are not rights at all.

If native title is going to be meaningful and—dare I say it—more certain, it will depend on a meaningful right to negotiate. If mining companies think that the right to negotiate makes it difficult to navigate around their developments, then they are in for a very rude shock when they encounter common law injunctions—once again, rights with enforceability. At common law, the preservation of the subject matter of litigation is well established. Injunctions do not have time limits—except in so far as they are limited by the courts—and there are no ministerial overrides either. Mining companies and people who wish to bypass the right to negotiate should be well warned that the alternative is for them much more intrusive that what they presently deal with. That is unless the National Farmers Federation position of extinguishing common law native title claims—through a sunset clause—is adopted. That certainly would be poisoning the last waterhole.

It is clear that the government's position is to water down and emasculate the right to negotiate. The Democrats-Greens amendments aim to restore the coverage of the current right to negotiate and improve its facilitation. The amendments will also tighten up requirements for ministerial approval of state‐territory exploration schemes. I commend the amendments to the Senate that will be moved on behalf of the National Indigenous Working Group.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Following Senator Woodley, I indicate that in stating that the right to negotiation as enshrined in the Native Title Act 1993 is not a native title right, I was simply stating a fact.
—That's correct.

—Exactly. It is a statutory right achieved as a consequence of—as those of us who were there would know—negotiations on the Native Title Bill in 1993. The right to negotiate applies to development proposals of future acts such as mining activities that may affect native title, and to the compulsory acquisition of native title for the purpose of granting an interest in land to a non‐government party. The right to negotiate is intended to protect native title wherever it exists.

SPEECH.PARA: I earlier quoted the National Indigenous Working Group as rightly pointing out that `the recognition of native title is meaningless without some mechanism to protect it against arbitrary impairment or destruction.' The right to negotiate on pastoral leases is very significant for Aboriginal people because of the vast land areas involved and their continuing association and attachment to that land. In the past they have been excluded from having much say at all in what happens to that land.

Native title has been recognised as a common law right. It is title based on prior possession and ownership. It is not just another leasehold. It therefore follows that to treat Aboriginal people as equivalent to miners or pastoralists is to effectively downgrade them and their property rights. If a right to negotiate with a mining company is to be enjoyed by native title holders whose country is vacant crown land, that right should not be taken away from native title holders who suffer the added disadvantage of having their land subject to a pastoral lease without their consent. I ask the government to look at it from that point of view, that justice point of view.

The Commonwealth parliament is required to set an appropriate bottom line for relationships between native title holders and miners. It is a matter for the states to determine the relationship between miners and pastoral leaseholders. We cannot do that. We have not got the power to do that. The right to negotiate encourages Aborigines and miners to talk together and to work together from the beginning. I know that the government is saying, `All right, they should have the same rights as pastoral leaseholders when it comes to negotiating with mining companies.' Clearly that is a furphy, as I indicated before, because the native title holders have the right to negotiate when it comes to mining on crown land. But you are suggesting that they be denied a similar right when it is on a pastoral lease; a pastoral lease which has been granted without their consent.

If you say there is one set of rights, it is up to the states to deal with the matter in relation to the rights of pastoral leaseholders. The Commonwealth parliament has no power to make laws for the rights exercisable by pastoral lessees under state titles. The veto, negotiation and compensation rights of farmers affected by mining is, I repeat, a state matter. It is not for us to deal with, so why make the comparison? For example, some farmers in Western Australia whose lands are cultivated and enclosed have a veto on mining development. At the other end of the scale are those pastoralists who have only a right to compensation for disturbance to the land.

The Commonwealth has the power and the responsibility to set the bottom line for the relationships between native title holders and miners, and we should do so. In fact, we have done so. Justice Woodward, in his 1974 royal commission report on Aboriginal land rights, considered:
Of all the questions I had to consider, that of mineral rights has probably caused me the most difficulty and concern.
He concluded with these words:
I believe that to deny aborigines the right to prevent mining on their land is to deny the reality of their land rights.

Of course, in the Native Title Act we are not talking about veto, but bear in mind what Justice Woodward said. He reached his conclusion after setting out the mining industry's submission in some detail:
. . . because while accepting many of the points made, I am unable to accept the main result contended for.
I do believe that there has been a shift in the mining viewpoint and policy since that particular submission was made to the Woodward inquiry; a shift for the better, I might say.

Despite the key Woodward recommendation on the control of mining, the Native Title Act 1993 grants only a twofold right to negotiate at the exploration and development stages. If after six months native title holders do not reach agreement with the miner, there is recourse to independent arbitration. Should the arbitral body agree with the Aboriginal demand that mining not proceed, the state minister has the power to override that decision. The government's own explanatory memorandum for the amendment bill is clear. It says:
The right to negotiate was not a veto.

The Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 proposes to cut back the right to negotiate to a once‐only right. It also proposes to allow state parliaments to take away the right completely, provided only that the native title holders have the same right in relation to mining as the holder of any state title on the same land.

This is, as has been indicated, the crunch issue. As far as I am concerned, my amendments, as honourable senators would have seen them, uphold the right of native title holders to negotiate. It is, I believe, an extremely important matter. I intend to protect the rights of native title holders in that regard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —It surprised me that the two Nicks from South Australia, if I can put it that way, have conducted this debate very pleasantly, to the amazement of many people. I think Senator Minchin put the case against the extension of the right to negotiate lucidly. He is correct in saying that the right to negotiate in this particular context is a procedural right and that that procedural right is not available to other people with interests in freeholder land, for example. Any action has available to it the right to negotiate and the success any party to that negotiation is going to have will depend upon the strength of his rights. You cannot negotiate if you do not have a right or the colour of a right, and the less colour you have in the right, the less chance you have of success.

SPEECH.PARA: Those cases where you get an offer and knock it back, and then the jury says no, are very sobering experiences. The right to negotiate, being a procedural right, is not a right over the land. It is not as if we—if we legislate here today—are going to give the indigenous people a right that they did not have; what we are talking about is procedure. That is important to understand. Various speakers around the chamber have said that. I want to make it clear that negotiation is not, as it were, going to get you anywhere unless you have a right to negotiate. If your opponent offers you anything, it is because your opponent considers you have a right in that offer.

Concerning the procedural business of the right to negotiate, it was said that a freeholder has not got the right to negotiate in the sense that it is set out here procedurally in the act. On the other hand, a freeholder has available to him, her or it a procedure that is not available to the native title holder. It is not available to the native title holder because of the doctrine of terra nullius. If I could explain it: possession of land in Australia is proved either by a Torrens system—which was developed in the minister's state where the title to your land is lodged in an office and that title proves that you do or do not hold the land—or there is a general law title which means you have to show a chain. In each case, the person who holds those titles has had a chance to build up that evidence over 200 years in Australia; whereas the doctrine of terra nullius has denied the native title holder the evidence that is available to the freeholder or, for that matter, to the leaseholder.

The doctrine of terra nullius is a very big disadvantage that has been visited upon indigenous people in Australia. We ignored their rights and now we say, `You prove those rights.' Had those who settled Australia and those of our forebears who worked out the Torrens system understood that native title existed, they could have put those rights on the title there and then. Then we would not have had the need to now go through these threshold tests. When we say that this is a procedural right which other land‐holders might not have, the other land‐holders have a big advantage over native title holders because over that period of 200 years they have had time to build up documentation which proves their title.

I think Senator Margetts said that, when you are looking at whether or not there is inequality between the groups, you do not look at each discrete right; you look at the general bundle of rights and see whether they measure off in an equal way. If you take into account the fact that you have had the Torrens system or the general law system that has enabled people to prove their title to land simply by producing a document, and measure that against what a native title claimant has to go through—and we have been through that over the last couple of days—there is a very big difference. So the leaseholder or the freehold titleholder simply produces the document.

The native title holder has to go through all the hoops that we presented to him or her in this legislation. That having been the position, I think it is incorrect and unfair to say that we will ignore all that—we will ignore the different procedures you have to go through to get to the point of proof—and simply say, `Look, you, the native title holder, have a procedural advantage over a non‐native title holder on this particular land.' As we often do here—and as people often do—that measures fairness in a particular compass: `Give a narrow range to what we are going to be fair about, instead of the broader range of issues that we should take into account.' If we take into account that system of proof, then the right to negotiate can be seen as an evener‐up to that process and it becomes a much fairer system than some people present it. I think that system ought to be available to all the land over which a native title claimant might make a claim.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell, Sen Ronald

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is one of the crucial issues that face the debate today. It impacts on mining and on the pastoral industry. It is something that has concerned me for some time. In 1993, we were told that there was no native title on pastoral leases. The Wik decision altered that and we now have to come to terms with that and provide some sort of legislation that is going to drive Australia forward and provide jobs. I listened very carefully to Senator Bob Collins, for whom I have a high regard, and he seemed to be saying that everything goes well up in the Northern Territory and that there are no delays on native title land.

SPEECH.PARA: Since 1976, only two new mines have opened through normal processes—one was in the Tanami Desert. The veto provisions are used often to delay negotiations for mineral applications. Exploration permits on non-Aboriginal land are six times greater than Aboriginal land over a period. Both Mount Todd and McArthur River had to have special legislation under the Keating government to get those mines off the ground. So one could say that mining where the Aboriginal people have a total veto in the Northern Territory is not as rosy a picture as Senator Collins made out.

I would also like to have a look at how the act has performed since we put it together in 1993. No negotiations have been completed in Australia within a statutory time period. Numerous, multiple, overlapping claims—up to 18 in some mining applications—hinder negotiations. Only two mining title applications have reached the determination process, both after years of negotiation, and both have been appealed to the Federal Court and returned to the tribunal and remain unresolved.

Nearly 2,000 mining title applications remain queued up in the statutory rights negotiation process for nearly three years, and only 158 voluntary agreements have cleared for grant in Western Australia, resulting in 48 actual projects. This compares with between 600 and 800 mining leases granted each year in Western Australia alone before the Native Title Act. So, Senator Collins, the picture that you have painted is not as rosy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I promised Senator Bolkus I won't speak again, otherwise I would respond.

—Then I will stop trying to provoke you. Also, Senator Dee Margetts was a little wide of the mark in her description of Western Australia, so I will just give her the actual figures. In Western Australia, where the native title right to negotiate procedure has been applied, the number of mineral leases granted has fallen significantly. The trend emphasises a major concern for the future of the industry and Australia because of the issues. I will just go through some of the numbers. In 1993‐94, 805 leases were granted; 1994-95, 611; 1995‐96, 368 and 1996-97, 159.
—They are running out of land. There is no more land left that you would make leasehold. That's all I was trying to say. There's got to be a limit to what you put leases on.

—The positive investment in figures that Senator Woodley brought forward today recognises that the areas of exploration that have been carried out in the previous 10 to 15 years are actually sites that have been under exploration and have been worked up, and they were there prior to the 1993 act. But the expenditure going overseas by Australian companies has increased. The Minerals Council's figures have shown that Australian companies going overseas have grown twice as fast as within Australia from 1993 to 1996. So they are spending twice as much money overseas to explore. The exploration expenditure on production leases on existing operations increased compared to new developments.

SPEECH.PARA: So everyone is concentrating on spending their money on their worked up leases, and they are going for where their leases have been found and where their leases have been granted, but their expenditure into exploration is very much down. It is costing 20 per cent of the exploration budget just to gain access. It cost $200 million last year to gain access. That is the real picture of what is happening to mining in Australia.

At the risk of provoking Senator Collins, and I will try not to, there are many jobs that are provided to Aboriginal people in the mining industry. In fact, my experience in the mining industry is that they really want to have Aboriginal participation in their mining companies and in their mining industries. They go out of their way to encourage Aboriginal people to come in and become involved in the process.

TALK.START.PARA: —They do. That's why it is not a problem.
—The figures that I quoted do show that it is a problem.
—Are you arguing for or against?
—He's on your side, Senator Collins.
—No, I am not on Senator Collins's side. The picture that Senator Collins painted was really gilding the lily.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to come to the problem that does face primary industry inasmuch as the negotiation process is concerned. Throughout Australia there has been a natural progression. Firstly, the Kidmans and the Tysons owned the leases, those leases were cut back to big leases and then those leases were cut back to what was considered livable areas. From those livable areas, farms developed. They were cut off into sugar growing areas or into wine growing areas, but they were excised off pastoral leases.

This process of negotiation has to happen every time a farmer wants to upgrade his lease, grow a different product or go from a pastoral lease to growing wine grapes, sugarcane or wheat. Every time he has to go through a negotiation process with an Aboriginal native title claimant, it slows the process right down.

I just want to point out some of the jobs that have been provided. For example, our wine industry has gone from virtually nothing to $800 million in the last 15 years, and much of that land would be on pastoral leases. I have an example at the back of Ayr‐Home Hill where pastoral leases have been cut into 400‐acre sugarcane farms. Once they raised 30 or 40 head of cattle on 400 acres of land; that same 400 acres of land is now producing 12,000 tonnes of sugarcane and that is providing many jobs right throughout the process—in the sugar industry, the refining industry and the cartage industry.

BREAK.PARA: If at every stage a farmer has to go to the right to negotiate before he can move into some other area, it is going to slow our primary production right down. This has already been shown in the western leases of New South Wales where many of them are going into different crops like cotton, which is a very high earning commodity in Australia. But if they are stymied every time by a long, protracted negotiating process where compensation has to be paid to native title claimants or holders, that is going to slow the whole economy down.

I have listened very carefully to Senator Harradine and I have never doubted his integrity or his motives—no‐one can do that; he is a man who has stood up for his principles and paid a very high price for them from time to time—but I am concerned because I know Senator Harradine shares the same concerns for blue-collar workers as I do. I instance Golden Circle Cannery that produces pineapples for Australian export. We have this big bank of land out there which is basically held in pastoral leases and, if those sugar farms or pineapple farms cannot be excised, we will not have any downstream processing. The largest employer of blue-collar workers in Brisbane is the Golden Circle Cannery. They employ something like 1,300 to 1,500 people in season. They provide many jobs in the downstream food processing industries.

Our manufacturing sector in Australia has been very much downgraded. We only have to get off a plane at Mascot and go through Alexandria into Sydney to see the many factories that have been pulled down for housing, indoor cricket pitches and all those sorts of things. Once those factories provided jobs for many people, but now they are not there any longer. The jobs will be in the downstream mining process and the downstream food processing industry. If people cannot move with the times—if they are going to be frozen in agriculture in 1997 and in 30 to 50 years time they are not going to be able to upgrade their lease and move from growing cattle to growing sugar, cotton or pineapples—then we are not going to advance as a nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —And destroy the environment along the way, though.

—I do not want to bring the environment into this debate, Senator Margetts. It is complicated enough. I do want to point out the negotiating process and how it will affect primary producers and miners.
—They're Aboriginal people.

—I am very concerned for Aboriginal people, but I am also concerned for the 98 per cent of the other Australians who were not the first Australians. I want them to have the ability to get jobs so their families can exist and have a prosperous future, where they are able to achieve jobs in downstream processing, mining industries and in the mines themselves.

BREAK.PARA: Today, I was challenged by Senator Brown to declare an interest and I took a wild shot. I do have a significant interest in an abattoir. I took a wild shot because I believed I had seen Aboriginal people there working. I rang up and checked to see if that abattoir was employing Aboriginal workers and I was told there were five Aboriginal workers in Kilcoy abattoirs. I also want to say that the Aboriginal workers work in Kilcoy, live in Kilcoy and play a very significant role in the community in Kilcoy. I want to see all Australians have jobs. I want to see Aboriginal workers have jobs. I want to see those in the communities have jobs, and I know they have jobs. They work alongside all Australians in the abattoirs, in the mining industry—

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, they are Australians.

—Of course they are. They are not only Australians; they were the first Australians. I recognise that, but I want them to have the same prosperity as every other Australian. I want every Australian to be able to get a job and that is why I am frightened of this negotiating process. It does concern me because I think it cuts away the farmer's ability to move with the times.

BREAK.PARA: Senator Collins was a cotton farmer at one stage. He probably got in about 20 years too early. He would have been rolling in money now if he had stuck with it because that industry has moved on. When he went into it, he was a pioneer, but the cotton industry now has been excised to pastoral leases and so has the sugar industry. I just want to say that today, because I do not want to see agriculture frozen in 1997. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a very important debate that we are engaged in. One only has to fly across the centre or north of Australia and see the mineral exploration on the land to know that it does have a very real impact on the form and nature of the landscape. The first thing to be said about the government's position here is that it would exclude Aboriginal people from a right to negotiate on that impact on the land. If you can see the impact it has from that great height as you fly across the country, then you can feel it to a great degree when you are living with the country.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to respond to Senator Boswell's comment, which I know was a heartfelt one, by creating a picture. I would imagine that an Aboriginal person who has a time‐honoured link to the land, which includes freehold pastoral holdings, would see things vastly differently. What the government is saying here is that the leasehold land that is involved can be changed enormously in the future, and the Aboriginal people have no say. In other words, `This is the land of your past, but not your future, particularly as far as your cultural and traditional and spiritual connection is concerned.'

I will give an example. Under this legislation, as the government would have it, you may have a vast leaseholding which is for the purpose of cattle grazing. Aboriginal people have coexisted there for a long period of time; that is, throughout the total duration of that lease and that cattle grazing and for a long time before that. Under this legislation, the leaseholder will be able to change up to half of that leasehold.

Senator Boswell mentioned cotton growing. I will use that as an example. If they put down some half of it to cotton growing, the Aboriginal people will have no right to negotiate on that. That is the government's intention. If cotton is to be grown, the land will need to be cleared and prepared first. They can do that. The savanna woodlands can be logged, if necessary, and the native vegetation can be cleared. It can be woodchipped, if that is what they want. Half of this vast leaseholding upon which the Aboriginal people live—they have traditional movement and spiritual attachment to it—can be cut down. They have no right to negotiate under the government's formula. It is their time‐honoured land, their universe, but they will have no right to negotiate.

Cotton crops need a lot of water. If the local stream is required to be dammed for the purposes of irrigation—notwithstanding the fact that it is a stream where the fishing is good and there is special significance, including spiritual significance, to not only the current traditional owners but also their ancestors—that can be done, but the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people have no right to negotiate. That is the government's prescription. If to get the water from the stream to this vast new cotton crop—which essentially extinguishes all the traditional activities of the Aboriginal people—there needs to be a canal built and, for the process of that, there needs to be large amounts of soil dug up off the other part of the property, that can go ahead. Under the government's formula, the Aboriginal people will have no right to negotiate.

On the other half of the land, the miners might come along and want to mine. It might involve the foreshore, say the leaseholding on the gulf. The traditional owners move to and fro in the intertidal area and use the beaches, but mineral exploration—say for mineral sands—requires major changes to the topography. There will be other laws that have to be considered here, but the traditional owners have no right to negotiate about that.

Let us say that the mineral product needs to be exported and a jetty or a breakwater needs to be run out into the ocean. In the components of this legislation already passed here today, because we are now talking about offshore areas, the traditional owners have no right to negotiate. The traditional owners may have a cultural attachment as far as the seas are concerned. Moreover, they may depend upon in part, or whole, on the largess of the ocean so that they can exist. If a fishing licence is offered to some corporation that wants to move in and reap the harvest for profit of that area, then the traditional owners will have no right to negotiate.

I can go on and on, but the point that has to be made here is this is de facto extinguishment. Sure you have the theory of a continuing ability for the traditional owners to enjoy the land, as they did in the past, but this is an erosion of future rights and that access with not even a say. Everybody in here has said, and I agree with them, that negotiating rights are not veto rights. So we have established that. The traditional owners cannot stop what is happening, but here is the government saying that the traditional owners cannot even have an input into what is happening.

I do not believe that is consonant with the Racial Discrimination Act, for starters. I doubt very much that it is even consistent with the constitution because I think it derogates very much from the interests and benefits and rights of the traditional owners of this country. Yes, we are at the heart of the matter; yes, we are at bucket loads of extinguishment; yes, we are at taking away from the traditional owners; and yes, we are going to affect that for decades, for centuries, for millennia to come unless there is some rectification in the future.

There are other interests here, and they have to be taken into account. But the loudest and strongest argument I have heard is that those other interests have to slow down. We cannot slow down the rights of miners or pastoral corporations to allow the Aboriginal people, far short of a veto, to have a say. That is what we are down to here. Once again, I feel ashamed that we should have a government which has brought this legislation into this parliament. I have no doubt that the majority of Australians would likewise feel ashamed if they knew the sting for Aboriginal and traditional owners in this country that is involved in what is being put before this committee at the moment and what sailed through the House of Representatives because the government has the numbers.

BREAK.PARA: Of course, the Greens and Democrats have strong amendments to stand up to this. What we should be looking at, if you ask me, is an expansion, not a diminution, of the rights of traditional owners to somewhere back—you cannot go all the way back because you cannot turn back history—to the full and untrammelled rights they once had. Short of that, we have to find a middle ground, but the middle ground is not to take away everything in terms of the real interest of the indigenous people. What the government is doing here is taking away everything. Sure, the substance of existence is left, but the heart and the ability to affect what happens to their land—that spiritual attachment, as well as the physical connection with the land—will be serially eroded forever into the future if this right to negotiate is knocked out, as the government would have it.

We will be standing strongly by the Greens‐Democrats amendments. We are going to vote against the government's measures. I have heard with some pleasure what the opposition and Senator Harradine have had to say in this section. It has been a constructive recognition at least that we are dealing with the very real interests of the indigenous people and their right to have a say. I am sad it is not much stronger. I am sad we cannot do something to turn around the erosion of their rights in the past, but I am not going to be party to the interminable and creeping erosion of the rights of all future generations of traditional Australians right across this country which is involved in what the government has brought before this Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —This will be my last contribution to the committee stage of the debate and it is going to be a brief one. I want to point out to the minister in closing that, if you are going to vote against a right to negotiate for Aboriginal people, it will be in conflict with your government's policy, the government policy that was released in June this year by the minister for Aboriginal affairs. I have your advisers very perplexed at the moment, but I will explain.

SPEECH.PARA: Yesterday I pointed out in the Senate that the office of the minister for Aboriginal affairs produced a booklet which described the claim that Aboriginal claims can be made on backyards as a myth. I would also like to draw to the Senate's attention a joint policy release made this year by the minister for Aboriginal affairs and John Anderson. It was the launch on 4 June this year of the indigenous rural industry strategy. It was done with a great deal of fanfare. Indeed, I applauded it and put out a press statement saying I thought it was a great idea. This indigenous rural strategy, among other things, said this:
The rural strategy promotes cooperation between indigenous communities and government and/or industry in, for example, developing co‐management agreements about the economic use of resources.
The strategy promotes negotiations taking place, in a spirit of cooperation, respect and mutual benefit, between indigenous people and government and/or industry.
For example, where mining companies and indigenous people negotiate over access to mineral resources a positive outcome can lead to beneficial economic opportunities for both parties.
Can I say to the minister with respect that, if you take away the Aborigine's right to negotiate, you do not get to first base in implementing this policy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not be provoked but I will just say we are not taking away the right to negotiate. The right to negotiate remains on vacant crown land and Aboriginal land for most mining titles and most compulsory acquisitions for third parties. I appreciate you do not agree with our policy, but it would not be true to say we are `taking away the right to negotiate'.

SPEECH.PARA: I indicate at this stage procedurally that, in relation to amendments, the government is prepared to accept opposition amendments Nos 112, 131, 141 and 175. I move:

These amendments amend section 26C. Section 26C removes certain opal and gem mining acts from the right to negotiate if they relate to land or waters wholly within an approved opal or gem mining area. This is something that is of considerable concern to the New South Wales Labor government. Those amendments have been prepared in consultation with the New South Wales Labor government.

The Commonwealth minister may determine in writing that an area is an approved opal or gem mining area if the three conditions set out in subsections 26C(3) to (5) are satisfied. Amendment 37A will impose a further condition that must be satisfied before the Commonwealth minister may make a determination that an area is an approved opal or gem mining area. The new condition is that the Commonwealth minister is satisfied that mining for opals or gems is currently being carried out in the whole or a substantial part of the area. The new condition will be inserted as subsection 26C(5)(a). Government amendments 36A and 37B are minor consequential amendments to 26B that insert references to new subsection 26C(5)(a). It was our intention that approved opal or gem mining areas would be areas where opal or gem mining is currently being carried on.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Temporary Chairman, on a point of order: I am wondering if during the debate we could actually do what people are asking to do—that is, deal with this big section section by section. The minister is now suggesting we move and vote on a whole line of things.
—No, I'm not.

—Yes. They are not in the first section we are dealing with. They are in subsequent sections. I am wondering if you could help the debate by doing that. What we are trying to do is understand what it is we are voting on and deal with it section by section as it is marked on the running sheet.

—I am happy with that procedure. I was formally moving our amend ments, which is required, and drawing your attention to those additional amendments. I am happy to speak to them again but they are our amendments. In formally moving government amendments I particularly wanted to draw attention to the three additional government amendments. I am sorry if you found that confusing.
—Minister, if you agree to that, perhaps what the committee needs is a motion to set these aside and deal with the amendments on the sheet as listed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

I suspect that other parties have no problem with all the other amendments other than the ones with respect to opal and gem mining. So they can be moved and dealt with very quickly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to standing order 81 Senator Woodley, by letter dated 4 December 1997, has raised a matter of privilege and asked that I give precedence to a motion to refer the matter to the Privileges Committee in accordance with that standing order. The matter he raises is the suggestion that the Queensland Criminal Justice Commission may have misled a Senate select committee.

SPEECH.PARA: This matter was raised in correspondence I had with the Parliamentary Criminal Justice Committee of the Legislative Assembly of Queensland and which I tabled in the Senate on 25 August 1997. That committee made a request that the Senate investigate the matter. The committee indicated that its attempts to investigate the matter itself were frustrated because the evidence in question was the subject of federal parliamentary privilege and therefore could not be investigated by a state parliamentary committee. The Criminal Justice Commission declined to answer questions on this basis. I indicated when I tabled the correspondence that it was for the Senate to consider whether it should accede to the request of the Queensland committee to investigate the matter. Since that time, no action has been taken by any senator to initiate an inquiry by the Senate.

Senator Woodley indicates that he is now seeking the concurrence of the Senate for a Privileges Committee investigation because he believes that additional evidence has come to light in recent weeks. I am required to determine whether a motion relating to the matter should have precedence, having regard to the following criteria:

(a) the principle that the Senate's power to adjudge and deal with contempts should be used only where it is necessary to provide reasonable protection for the Senate and its committees and for senators against improper acts tending substantially to obstruct them in the performance of their functions, and should not be used in respect of matters which appear to be of a trivial nature or unworthy of the attention of the Senate; and
(b) the existence of any remedy other than that power for any act which may be held to be a contempt.

Past presidential determinations have indicated that allegations that false or misleading evidence has been given to a Senate committee are always regarded as very serious matters and as meeting criterion (a). In this case, statements to a Senate committee are alleged to conflict with statements made elsewhere and other available information. The statements in question were made in response to questions put in the course of proceedings of the Senate select committee. Only the Senate can investigate the truth of those statements.

I consider that the matter clearly meets the criteria I am required to consider. I therefore determine that a motion to refer the matter to the Privileges Committee may have precedence. It is for the Senate to determine whether the Privileges Committee should inquire into the matter. I table correspondence from Senator Woodley. Senator Woodley may now give a notice of motion. If it transpires that this is the last day of sitting of the Senate in this period of sittings, in accordance with standing order 81(7) the motion may be moved later during the sitting.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion No. 1 standing in the name of the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Hill), I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Ian Campbell moving a motion to provide for the consideration of a matter, namely a motion relating to the days and hours of meeting and routine of business.

I will not delay the Senate for too long. It is quite clear from where we are in the consideration of the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 that there will be a need to make an alteration to the hours. At this stage the Senate is only authorised to sit until 10.30 p.m. this evening. We know that we have eight blocks of votes or thereabouts to consider and that that will not take place prior to 10.30 p.m.

So the motion which I would seek to move, if the motion to suspend standing orders is successful, will be to the effect that the Senate will sit no later than midnight tonight; will commence at 9.30 a.m. tomorrow; hold a lunch break, if that is necessary; and, if consideration of the Native Title Amendment Bill is not finished by 6.30 p.m., to have a dinner break between 6.30 p.m. and 7.30 p.m. The adjournment will be contingent upon the completion of the Native Title Amendment Bill , which the government hopes will be concluded during tomorrow. I seek the support of the Senate to suspend standing orders to allow me to move that motion.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CARR
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Opposition Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition supports the suspension of standing orders. It is our understanding that there is agreement on the variation to the hours of sitting that the Manager of Government Business has proposed and therefore we believe that it should be dealt with immediately.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I would concur with the need for us to change the hours so that we can carry this debate to a better state of completion before the end of the day. However, twice yesterday, when I rose to ask a question in this place, I was refused leave by members of the government. The second time that refusal was by the National Party whip. I do not intend to delay the Senate greatly tonight because I recognise that there are more people than those who refused me leave yesterday who want to get on with it. But I do want to make a few comments about the outcome of that incident.

SPEECH.PARA: It is very easy to abuse power in this place. That is not what the forms of the Senate are about. They are about giving everybody a fair and an equal go. I have never seen anybody refused leave to ask a question, although that form is unusual, in my 12 years in parliament. I think it is a very serious matter when a senator is refused the opportunity to ask a question, on this occasion of a chair of a Senate committee about a report which had just appeared before the Senate. It is tantamount to removing a senator's opportunity to gain information. On this occasion it was also effectively a mechanism for not allowing the chair of that committee to respond to my request, which was to do with the deliberations of the committee into the matter of sexuality discrimination.

BREAK.PARA: I think it was most regrettable behaviour by Senator O'Chee and other senators that they used that mechanism to prevent me from having a say. We, that is, the Greens, the Democrats and the Independents in here, have to rely on the forms of this place to ensure that we are not shut out. I want to inform government senators that those forms are very powerful. They have been developed over a long period of time and they are to ensure that senators, elected by voters who have every right to see their senators here, get a say and are not silenced by the sort of behaviour that we saw yesterday. The outcome of refusing me the opportunity to ask a question is simply an unnecessary delay. It has come from those few senators on the other side and not from me. I would not be responding in this way otherwise. So there is an end to the matter. I have now had an opportunity to speak.

Using other methods, we have heard from the chair of the committee, Senator McKiernan, earlier in the day. But I want to put on notice Senator O'Chee and others that, if they wish to use and, I think, abuse the procedures of the Senate, I will not just accept it. That is not what I am here for. I will use the procedures of this place fairly and with good will, but if they are going to be abused in the way they were yesterday, then I will respond.

I thank those senators who have been supportive in this matter. That is very encouraging. I think it is a pity that the people who abused the forms of the procedure yesterday did not seek wiser counsel. That having been said, I, like everybody else, want to see us get back to the matter of substance and carry on with the debate. I thank the Senate for its forbearance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened to what Senator Brown said. I seek leave to withdraw the motion to suspend the standing orders and to move a motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Ian Campbell) agreed to:
That the order of the Senate of 28 November 1997, relating to the hours of meeting and routine of business for 4 December 1997, be modified as follows—
(1) That the question for the adjournment of the Senate shall not be proposed at 10.30 p.m.
(2) That, if the Senate is sitting at midnight, the sitting of the Senate be suspended till Friday, 5 December 1997 at 9.30 a.m.
(3) That on Friday, 5 December 1997, at 1 p.m. matters of public interest may be discussed till 2 p.m., and the sitting of the Senate be suspended from 6.30 p.m. till 7.30 p.m.

(4) That the question for the adjournment of the Senate shall not be proposed till after the Senate has finally considered the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997, including on any occasion on which the bill is returned by the House of Representatives, or a motion for the adjournment is moved by a minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to comment very briefly on the comments made earlier in this debate by the Northern Territory Labor senator, Senator Bob Collins. SPEECH.PARA: However, I refer to my comments on the second reading, when I said that, in the 20 years this provision has been active, only one new mine and the expansion of another have occurred on Aboriginal land in the Northern Territory. That is an appalling lack of development in some of the most resource rich areas of Australia. Once again, the main casualties are Aboriginal people, most of whom recognise the important links between economic and social self-determination, and the broader Australian community, which has development held to ransom.

I think it is very important to put on the record the exploration licence record under the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act since its inception. In fact, there are 327 issues still under consideration, despite the 19‐ or 20-year life of the land councils. That is 327 opportunities lost that can contribute to the economic advancement and social development of Aboriginal people.
