SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I put a question to the mover of these amendments, Senator Bolkus. Are you attempting here to in fact retain the situation as it is in effect in the Native Title Act when it comes to the right to negotiate at the exploration stage? I understand the argument that is being used. That is, very often, if that right to negotiate at that stage is availed of, then the relationships between the native title holders and the miners are in fact enhanced if the exploration stage is successful, particularly when it comes to negotiating on the second stage, that is to say, at the development stage.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that the government's view is that there should be only one occasion when there could be a right to negotiate. But I am now convinced, heaving heard the discussion, having read a little bit more about the matter, that it would be desirable to maintain what is currently the situation under the NTA. If that is the purpose of these amendments, I would be supporting them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the one modification to the existing regime is that we stress that there is a capacity for the parties at that early stage, the exploration stage, to come to an agreement that would cover both the exploration and the mining if the parties so determine. It is important for us that there be a capacity for a right to negotiate at the exploration stage. It lays the foundation for an ongoing relationship and for future interaction.

SPEECH.PARA: We recognise exploration can be a very invasive and broad ranging activity, and we recognise that for some industries—for instance, the petroleum and diamond industries with the high density up‐front activities involved—it is important to have it at that particular stage. But we do say that there should be a capacity for the parties to get together and agree at the exploration stage what will happen at the mining stage. What we are putting up is a regime based substan tially on the existing Native Title Act, but with encouragement for parties, where they deem it desirable, to basically set up a two‐stage structure where they can agree as to what would happen on exploration and as to what the arrangements will be or what the structure will be to determine the arrangements for the subsequent mining regime. In essence, we are talking about the Native Title Act but with a capacity to encourage parties where there is a need or where there is a good relationship to build on that at that particular stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a few remarks on this matter. I am resisting the temptation to debate every amendment, but I do think it is important to state that the full‐blown right to negotiate process is, generally speaking, inappropriate for exploration per se. That was recognised by the Keating government. They had a mechanism by which exploration could be excluded from the right to negotiate. Indeed, Mr Keating, in his second reading speech, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Moreover, classes of grants can be excluded from the negotiation process altogether where they would have minimal effect on any native title. Certain prospecting and exploration permits would be likely to fall within this category.
It clearly was contemplated then that the right to negotiate process simply would not work with the thousands upon thousands of exploration titles issued very year.

The facts are that about one in a hundred of every exploration licences issued in the country results in a mine, so there is nothing in that sense to negotiate about in terms of jobs and benefits to Aboriginal people. We have approached this from the other end saying, `Why don't we put in place a sensible procedure for dealing with exploration per se so that the matters affecting native title in respect of exploration are dealt with on their merits in a particular procedure?'

Exploration is so different from the question of a full‐scale multimillion dollar mine. As I said the other day in this chamber, exploration in many respects amounts to the 84‐year‐old Jack Otways of the world, exploring on their own with no money and no resources over a five‐hectare lease area. The right to negotiate as applied to them means, in the case of Jack Otway, receiving a 70‐page list of demands from some lawyers in another capital city. Mr Keating recognised this was not going to work for the thousands upon thousands of exploration leases issued every year.

We have put together in 26A what we believe is a very good mechanism for ensuring that a proper procedure is put in place to deal with exploration permits. It is workable and deals with issues that should be dealt with at the exploration stage. To approve a process for exploration, the minister has to be satisfied that there is a right to be notified that the act is to be done; that such persons or bodies will have a right to be heard by an independent person or body about whether the act is to be done and about any matter relating to the doing of the act; that there will be a legal obligation to consult appropriately any person or body covered; that procedures will be in place under which such consultation will be required for the purpose of minimising the impact of the act; that any area or site of particular significance to the persons holding the native title will be protected; and that there is access to the land or waters which the native title rights and interests relate to.

We have gone to great lengths to ensure that the issues that really need to be dealt with at the exploration stage are dealt with in a purpose‐built procedural mechanism. That is a much more appropriate way to deal with exploration which is very different from a Roxby Downs mine or something like that. It often involves ordinary single Australians out there exploring, seeing what they can find. As I say, the success rate, the strike rate, is about one in 100. We would be disappointed if the Senate would not recognise the benefit and the attraction of what we have put together here in terms of a proper procedure for dealing with exploration on land on which native title may have survived. We think it is a much more sensible and productive way.

At the moment, because of the way in which the right to negotiate process is structured, it does not, in fact, apply to exploration. Exploration licences are being issued without a proper mechanism and without regard to native title issues because of the huge volume of things we are dealing with and the incapacity of the right to negotiate process to handle that.

In fact, in practice, the right to negotiate protections are not working for the issue of exploration. That is the reason you get these high statistics in relation to exploration not being caught up in the right to negotiate—there is not any way of dealing with it. This is a much more satisfactory procedure, which the states are supporting. It makes a lot of sense to adopt it and I commend it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand Senator Minchin's concerns, but it should be stated that the existing 237 provisions of the act, the expedited procedures provisions, in fact have accommodated some 80 per cent of applications for explorations which have been determined over the last 2½ years. That is an important statistic to keep on the record.

SPEECH.PARA: Sure, exploration can be a non‐intrusive thing but it can go from surface sampling to seismic surveys, to digging pits, trenches, holes, bores and tunnels. It can be quite invasive. It can divert water from springs and so on. It can take a fair degree of sampling and testing. We say that there needs to be a degree of flexibility, especially also when you include quarrying which would have a substantially greater effect as well.

Current arrangements do provide an expedited procedure which has been used, as I say, in something like 80 per cent of concluded cases. Industry also, it should be acknowledged, wants some degree of flexibility, especially diamond and petroleum exporters. Also, I cannot imagine rep bodies wasting their time on this particular stage of the process, unless there is a real need to do so. The evidence of the operation of the act so far would indicate that they have kept out, unless there have been some impacts that are of concern.

I understand your concern about an expedited procedure for the non‐intrusive acts. That procedure is there at the moment, with a capacity, of course, to appeal if the procedure is not applied properly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would make the point that, yes, they are at the moment mostly going through the expedited procedures simply because of the volume of exploration titles and the incapacity of native title representative bodies, et cetera, to handle the volume. The fact is that under the expedited procedure you get basically no rights. So there is no flexibility because it is either the right to negotiate, which most people agree is simply inappropriate for exploration, or the expedited procedure, where you get no rights at all. What we are putting in place is a purpose‐built, much more sensible procedure for dealing with the quite specialist and different issues that arise in exploration as opposed to mining per se.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to remind the minister that there are considerable impacts on land through exploration. The mining industry likes to talk about satellite surveys and non‐intrusive means of exploration but, as I said earlier, one only has to fly across Central Australia to see the enormously pervasive mineral exploration lines that have been cut and roads that have been put through vast areas in the name of exploration to see that there is a huge impact on the country from traditional exploration methods. When you are on the ground, this impact is very considerable in terms of the traditional owners and their relationship with the land. It cannot be dismissed as not being a matter of significance.

SPEECH.PARA: Exploration very often involves vehicles, the movement of numbers of people and exploration camps and a very big change to the nature of country and small isolated populations and their culture and environment. It cannot be dismissed as not being of significance. There needs to be an opportunity for people to negotiate about the impact of exploration, if it is to take place. The point of difference between the government and us on this matter is not whether exploration should take place; it is about the negotiated terms which lead to exploration.

There is debate in here about whether the exploration is in some way or other slowed down or diminished because of the right to negotiate but the reality is that the right to negotiate of traditional owners should not be expunged simply to enable schedules to be kept by exploration entities. We are not just talking about an explorer here and an explorer there. We have already heard today about some 18,000 to 20,000 leases for mining being issued over the last three years or so. So it is a very active and, for localities which have not seen the intrusion of mining camps, a potentially very intrusive matter.

The people ought to have a right to negotiate. They ought be able to negotiate on the basis of information. You also have to be aware that exploration is not done for the heck of it; it has the intention of mining to follow. Right at the outset there ought to be the opportunity for indigenous people to be fully informed, to be aware of the impact of exploration and mining and to be able to negotiate at both critical stages, minimum, remembering that they have no right of veto, but that they have the right to negotiate because it is their world, it is their life, it is their culture, it is their attachment to the land, and that is infringed by both exploration and by mining.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think Senator Brown has read 26A which acknowledges all of that and which says that approved exploration acts can only be determined if all the conditions set down there in 26A are met and they involve the requirements that there be a right of notification, a right to be heard, a right to be consulted, procedures in place for consultation, protection of sites of significance and access to the land, et cetera.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem at the moment is that, with all the good intentions in the world about this, if you have just the right to negotiate or an expedited procedure, the full‐blown right to negotiate for most exploration is simply an inappropriate procedure. What is appropriate is set down in section 26A. Because there are thousands of these going through every year, the native title claimants and holders simply are not in a position to be able to respond to every exploration proposal that is proposed for the expedited procedure. So about 80 per cent of these are being put to the expedited procedure which means they get no rights at all; the exploration licences are just issued.

The irony of the situation, the paradox, is that you are saying, `With all the good intentions in the world, these things should happen.' The fact is that in relation to exploration, because of the volume, because you only have a choice between an expedited procedure and a full‐blown right to negotiate, it is not happening. This puts in place a mechanism to ensure that in relation to exploration all the things you just said will happen, and they are not at the moment. That is the irony of the proposition you put to us. I wish you had read section 26A before you entered the debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I was going to suggest that, for the benefit of miners, it would obviously be much better if the negotiation was done at an early stage before too much money is committed and they are advised at some later stage—not just other people being advised and having to take some sort of legal action but actually being in discussion with those indigenous traditional owners whom the mining project affects—what areas are of concern to them and what areas are not of concern. These areas can be dealt with at an early stage.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to remind honourable senators that, if you have states like Western Australia, we have often been told by governments of all sorts, `Don't worry because exploration really is a teeny‐weeny little thing.' First of all, you sometimes have kilometres on kilometres of very wide swaths cut through bushland to get to the stage where you make your exploration. So in fact exploration is not always a minimum impact activity. There might be the odd 87-year-old or 90‐year‐old fossicking, but there are also some quite substantial activities going under the guise of exploration, even perhaps trial crushing and so on that goes on for uranium. In reality, if there are no problems, obviously the right to negotiate is not going to be a problem either. But, if there are going to be problems, surely it is better for a company to be fully advised at that stage rather than commit large amounts of money.

I am not entirely sure about the mining acts of other states but in Western Australia, once a company has an exploration permit, it is extremely difficult for the mining per se not to go ahead. So, in reality, once exploration has gone ahead and minerals approved, it is almost a fait accompli. So in that case maybe we are dealing with a sort of automatic compensation if there are real problems. I do not think that is particularly wise. I think it is going to be better for industry if the right to negotiate can be done at an early stage.

Whilst I am on my feet, I would like to check something. I had written down on my sheet that opposition amendment 119 was passed. Could I just check whether that was in fact the case, or am I incorrect there?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Margetts, it was negatived.
—I would just indicate that at the time I did not push amendment 109 because I was somehow under the impression that it did actually pass.
—So was I.
—Senator Woodley was obviously under the same impression.
—I am sorry, Senator Margetts. I called it for the noes.

—No, that is all right. I am sorry, but that was the impression I got and I have been alerted otherwise. I indicate that at some stage I would like to move amendment 109 because we almost had no debate on that section. It is very important, so at some stage I would like to return to amendment 109 and deal with that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —Very briefly, I want to support Senator Margetts in this. The problem is that, unless you have negotiation at an early stage, it really then becomes impossible. One of the classic illustrations which is raised often in this chamber as proving the failure of the Native Title Act is the Century mine. I visited the Century mine three years ago and spent a day and a half talking to the miners and visiting Lawn Hill Gorge, which is next door.

SPEECH.PARA: Although that was beyond the exploration stage, it certainly was not at the approval stage and there had been massive works carried out—a gigantic dam, which was the result of the dewatering of the area, massive road works, massive quarrying, massive storage. I am not saying that is inappropriate. That is obviously what should happen, but I am making the appeal that we have negotiations early enough so that we do not get halfway through a project and end up with the disaster we had in terms of negotiation with the Century mine. That is just another part of the story.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —Just for the record, can I say that the figure that Senator Minchin used of 80 per cent is one that I used. It is a figure that pertains to low impact acts. There are obviously low impact exploration acts. What we are concerned about, though, is that there be a capacity when it is more than a low impact act for there to be a right to negotiate at that particular part of the process. That is important. If 80 per cent are low impact, obviously a balance is struck in that, where there is low impact, the particular project of exploration can go ahead. We do not think that is unreasonable.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a mechanism there to protect against acts of some substantial impact and it is important to keep that flexibility in the legislation. It is important for some sectors. As I said earlier, the petroleum and diamond industries are concerned that they have a capacity to negotiate up-front at the exploration stage. They are industries that do have a significant impact at the exploration stage.

So we say, okay, 80 per cent go through to the keeper, but if someone disagrees with the definition of the act as a low impact act, there is still the capacity for that act to be further assessed, and that is an important part of the existing arrangements. The protection is there and matters do not necessarily get consigned to expedited procedures, but there is a capacity to protect. As I said earlier, rep bodies obviously will not waste their time and resources to frustrate people with so many of these acts being involved.

Though Senator Minchin might say there is potential for all these matters to be addressed, we still endorse the government's proposal, which I think is 24LA—the low impact future acts section. That has an impact in respect of low impact future acts and they just go ahead with no right to negotiate. As well as that, the provisions in 26A provide for ministers to be able to determine at their own discretion to exclude certain classes of exploration acts from the right to negotiate at the exploration stage. That is something of concern, especially when you look at the fact that the bill states:
(3) The second condition is that the Minister considers that the act or acts are unlikely to have a significant impact on the particular land or waters concerned.

And proposed subsection (4) says that, in terms of satisfying that condition, acts authorising drilling, for instance, are not to be taken as acts of significant impact on the particular land or waters concerned.

So we maintain that, with the capacity to protect in cases of more than low impact acts and with the capacity to ensure that the definition of those acts can be adjudged if it is seen to be unfair, those provisions are much fairer in that particular part of the process to the native title claimant. At the same time, to the extent that they have been used so far, it shows that they are working to satisfy the required balance for industry concerns.

I think Senator Minchin would acknowledge those arguments, together with the fact that it is important that we do not seek to amend your proposed section 24LA in respect of low impact future acts. It basically strikes an appropriate balance. For instance, we are concerned under the government's proposal that you may finish up digging holes the size of public swimming pools, and that still may fall under the category of 26A, approved scheme acts. There needs to be a balance and, at the moment, no case has been put forward to say that the current provisions really frustrate. It is a difficult area but I think it is fair to judge that, to the extent that it has been allowed to operate over recent years, it is not operating all that badly.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that the amendments moved by Senator Bolkus be agreed to.
—Madam Chair, this happened before, I believe. The question should be, `That schedule 1, item 9, section 26A stand as printed.' If you do not ask the question that way, the answer becomes different.

—That is very likely, Senator Woodley, but I understand that we are actually dealing at the moment with amendments R115, 115A, R197, 197A, R202 and 202A moved by Senator Bolkus on sheet 835 of the opposition amendments. I am advised that we should put the question that the amendments moved by Senator Bolkus be agreed to.

—I am sorry to ask it again, but in relation to amendments 297 and 299, I believe the question was, `That the amendments be agreed to,' and the answer was, `The noes have it.' Again, if you put it that way and if the noes have it, it is negating that schedule 2, items 94 and 101 stand as printed. I am concerned that we may have put the wrong question and got the wrong answer.
—I am advised that items 94 and 101 were agreed to. Are you right now, Senator Woodley?
—I hope I am. I am prepared to accept your explanation. I just want to make sure the committee gets it right. That is all. I apologise if I am holding you up.
—Not at all, Senator Woodley. We appreciate what you have said. If there is anything this committee needs to do, it needs to know what it is voting on.

—I was just going to assist and suggest that the next item we vote on should be item 121 of opposition amendments or 111 of Greens‐Democrat amendments. I think they are identical. They are in conflict with the government's amendments. They relate to gold and tin mining, and we discussed them before dinner.
—The question is that section 26B be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Did we actually put the question that schedule 1, item 9, section 26A stand as printed?
—I understand from the advice I am receiving that that has not been put yet.
—I suggest we put it now then. It is the same topic.
—The question is that section 26A be agreed to.
—I would like to hear from both Senator Bolkus and Senator Minchin as to their views on this particular matter.

—Basically, in respect of gold and tin mining, Labor's recent amendment to oppose the government's amendment, which removes the right to negotiate from gold and tin mining acts where those minerals are extracted from surface alluvium by the washing or erasion process—
—We have voted on this.

—No. We voted on one part of it, Senator Minchin. My understanding—and I might be wrong—is that we are now dealing with schedule 1, item 9, section 26B. This is one that the Greens and the Democrats also have. Maybe Senator Margetts can handle this one.
—I think you have actually moved on to 26B.
—No. Senator Margetts, we have put section 26B. We are now back to 26A.

—Yes, I know. Senator Bolkus is now describing something which relates to 26B. I think it might be helpful if I were to explain that amendment No. 120 has largely been debated in relation to exploration acts and so on. The removal of section 26A actually relates to the removal of provisions relating to approved exploration acts and so on. So we have actually had that debate already in relation to amendment No. 120.
—I thank Senator Minchin for asking me to revisit it, and I am silly enough to have done so.
—Senator Harradine wanted a comment from you, Senator Minchin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought we had just voted against section 26B standing as printed.
—We have. We are now considering 26A.
—That is what I thought was going on.
—I thought we had actually done 26A and had moved on to 26B.
—No, we have not. The motion you moved, Senator Bolkus, referred us to opposition amendment No. 121, which referred to section 26B. We have now gone back to opposition amendment No. 120, section 26A.
—I am not sure whether Senator Harradine wanted our comments on 26A or 26B. I have spoken at length about 26A, which is a fantastic part of the bill.
—It might assist the committee if I then put that opposition amendment No. 120 is to be moved as: that section 26A be agreed to. Senator Harradine, are you satisfied to vote?
—No, I am not.

—My understanding of 26A is that it does relate to the right to negotiate at the exploration stage. That is the debate we have just had. That is the debate to which I moved that raft of amendments which were prepared during the dinner break—No. 115 and so on, which are on sheet No. 835. Whether there is a need to make any consequential changes to section 26A as a consequence of those amendments that we voted on earlier is something that I obviously would like some advice on. The raft of amendments that we voted on related to this question of the right to negotiate at exploration. I moved those as an alternative to amendment No. 120, which was the 26A provision. With the assistance of the clerk and others, we may be able to determine whether there is a need to proceed with opposition amendment No. 120, having handled opposition amendments R115 and so on.
—I want to clarify something in relation to 26B. When we did a very quick vote without a debate, did that section stand or did it get—
—No, it went down.
—The section was negatived.
—That means the amendment was passed.

—I think the understanding is that, having passed those amendments in respect of the right of exploration, what we are now left with is a consequential amendment in respect of section 26A. That is covered by amendment No. 120. Senator Minchin, I think you would probably agree with us that, having dealt with the substantive issue in terms of the right to negotiate at exploration stage, amendment No. 120 is part of that debate, and this is essentially consequential to the decision we have already taken.
—Senator Bolkus, are you suggesting that we do not now proceed to vote on the—
—No, I am not. I am suggesting that, having had the substantive debate, we now need to delete 26A from the bill, and 26A is basically the government's regime to deny the right to explore.
—It's a consequential amendment to what we have just done.
—That is right, yes.
—So the question before the committee is that section 26A stand as printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I was somewhat concerned because I was under the impression—and it was obviously the wrong impression—that opposition amendment No. 119 was passed. Given that I am advised that it is not, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (109) Schedule 1, item 9, page 75 (lines 15 to 20), omit subsection (3), substitute:

PARA.TAB: (3) If an act is covered by, or falls within a class of acts covered by, an alternative procedure agreement (see Subdivision D of Division 2C) that modifies, but does not exclude in full, the operation of this Subdivision, this Subdivision continues to apply to the extent and in the manner provided for in the agreement but not otherwise.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is true to say that the committee did not get much information in order to make the vote. So I will try to provide a little more and hope that this one will actually get support. There are two aspects to the Democrats-Greens amendment No. 109, as supported by the National Indigenous Working Group. That is, on page 75 of the bill there is an area excluded from negotiation. It states:

(3) This Subdivision only applies to the act to the extent that the act relates to a place that is on the landward side of the mean high‐water mark of the sea. A reference to an act to which this Subdivision applies is to be read as referring to the act to that extent only.

It does replace that section with a section that ensures that indigenous land use agreements can incorporate right to negotiate procedures, but it is extremely important for those people on island communities that there is the right to negotiate in relation to mining in the intertidal zone.

I would urge support from the committee. It is considered to be absolutely vital to many communities throughout Australia that someone does not have the ability to just come in and develop on their intertidal zone without them being able to negotiate in relation to that area. I would urge very strongly that the committee supports Democrats-Greens amendment No. 109.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Temporary Chairman, I understand that these amendments relate to the intertidal zone, which was Labor amendments 119, 297 and 299, which have been defeated.

—I am advised that 109 is not identical and that it is reasonable, as Senator Margetts has spelt out, to put it as an amendment. I will do that now. The question before the chair is that Democrats‐Greens amendment No. 109 be agreed to.

—Is it the wish of the committee to proceed to opposition amendments Nos 122 and 123 or is it appropriate to go back to Senator Minchin's amendments? Senator Minchin, you moved a large number of amendments before and they were set aside. Do you wish to come back to them now?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Temporary Chairman, the committee supported all government amendments except government amendments 36A, 37A and 37B, which are amendments to section 26C. Perhaps it would be better to see what the attitude of the committee is to section 26C before we move to our amendments to 26C.
—I am advised we should call Senator Margetts.
—We all have varying amendments here. I think we are all in conflict with each other. Senator Margetts can go first and I will follow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —It probably would be wise if I was to move my amendments first. I note that they appear to be identical to those of Senator Harradine—that is, to oppose 26C. I am not sure what the opposition is likely to do, but I must check to find out whether, if these are both defeated, the opposition would agree to that as well. Perhaps if we find at the end of the vote that there is an unclarity about the position, we might be able to seek leave to return to that vote.

SPEECH.PARA: The removal of 26C would remove the provisions regarding opal and gem mining. All relevant representative bodies have agreed to negotiate indigenous land use agreements. I was under the impression that there was some movement in relation to the ALP on these issues. I hope there is the ability to have some movement, especially as it is clear that Senator Harradine is prepared to support us on this issue. I cannot see why there should not be a right to negotiate in relation to gem and opal mining.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Temporary Chair, there is a difference. I would suggest that we put the Democrat-Green and Harradine amendments first, then the Labor amendments and then the government amendments. Our policy is that we do not think it is possible to restore native title where there has been and where there are current opal and gem mining—or mining basically. We believe that the right to negotiate should apply to new areas. As a consequence, we have proposed an additional subsection 5A to limit the exclusory effect of 26C. I think this it is somewhat close to the government's, but I am told that there are some differences of emphasis. That is about as far as it goes.

SPEECH.PARA: The position that we have taken is that, in respect of those areas which are currently being mined—the specific areas of mining as opposed to the broader areas of a permit—we should acknowledge that in those cases it is hard to restore native title but, in terms of new areas, we should have the right to negotiate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to indicate to the committee that I have been advised along the lines of what Senator Bolkus has just mentioned to the committee. Having regard to that advice and the difficulty that has been identified by him, I had not intended to take the step that I had indicated on my amendment sheet. I have had a good look at the government's amendment. As Senator Bolkus said, it does not vary far from the opposition's amendment. I am prepared to support the move by the government which is currently before us.

—I just want to endorse the amendment here by the Greens and Democrats that gem and opal mining not be excluded from the right to negotiate for indigenous people. The argument put forward does not stand up. We do not know which areas are likely to be excluded from the right to negotiate over the next 100 years. We do not know where the next gem or opal fields are going to be. Here we do believe that the indigenous people ought to have a right to negotiate because it is going to affect their rights to the land. It is going to affect their neighbourhood. It is going to affect the configuration of their relationship with the land. Therefore, they ought to have that right. Quite clearly, we are not going to be able to win. We do not have the numbers here. Nevertheless, I wanted to make it clear that I support this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I just make the point that this set of amendments is strongly supported by the New South Wales Labor government because they essentially relate to the practicality of opal mining which is conducted at Lightning Ridge and in my state at Andamooka and Coober Pedy. The right to negotiate process is simply and utterly impractical in those circumstances. That is why we have set down a particular regime to deal with opal mining.

SPEECH.PARA: Our amendment makes it absolutely clear that we are talking about areas currently being used for opal and gem mining. This is not about opening up new areas. Opal miners, many of whom you would know—many of them single operators, many of them eastern and European migrants and others trying to make a living in the toughest and hardest conditions in Australia—have to get licences re‐issued on a regular basis. The right to negotiate them is simply and utterly impractical. The New South Wales Labor government recognises that. That is why they strongly support these amendments. We are clarifying our amendments that this is only in relation to areas where opal and gem mining is currently being carried out.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question before the committee is that schedule 1, item 9, section 26C stand as printed.
—Senator Bolkus, do you wish to proceed, in light of discussion, with opposition amendments Nos 122 and 123?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (122) Schedule 1, item 9, page 81 (line 25), omit "(5)", substitute "(5A)".
(123) Schedule 1, item 9, page 82 (after line 30), after subsection (5), insert:

PARA.TAB: (5A) The fourth condition is that the area in relation to which a determination is sought does not extend beyond the area in which opal or gem mining was permitted on 26 December 1996 under valid mining leases or licences.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I be a little bit enlightened by Senator Bolkus on precisely what these mean?

—They substantially mean the same as the government's. The advice I have is that the language is a bit tighter in that it covers the specific area of mining. I am sure the government may have different advice to that. The advice I have is that we focus on the actual mine and directly surrounding areas, whereas the government's position might be a bit broader.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —The ALP amendment refers to the date of 26 December 1996, whereas our amendment will provide that `the Commonwealth Minister is satisfied that mining for opals or gems is currently being carried on in the whole or a substantial part of the area'. There is really not much difference. We would not be prepared to accept the ALP amendment, but I do not think it is materially different.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the importance in terms of date is that the date goes very close to the date of the Wik judgment, which is being used as a benchmark for many amendments of the government in this particular debate. We say that what was going on then is fair enough but if you want to give an exclusion to acts of opal and gem mining on an ongoing basis then that should not happen. We do draw the line in terms of 26 December, whereas the government does not have such a line.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments 122 and 123 not agreed to.
Amendments 36, 36A, 37, 37A and 37B agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (116) Schedule 1, item 9, page 75 (lines 7 and 8), omit "renewals of valid mining leases etc.", substitute "a right to mine following a right to explore or prospect".

Just in case we have forgotten what it was we were moving, this is the amendment that goes to the question of whether there should be a right to negotiate in respect of renewals of mining leases. TALK.START.PARA: —It is my understanding that amendment No. 117 deals with the right to negotiate in towns and cities. Opposition amendment No. 116 and amendment No. 116 for the Democrats-Greens (WA) are minor consequential amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —Amendment No. 116 is to omit renewals of valid mining leases et cetera. It substitutes the right to mine following a right to explore or prospect. It does not go to towns and cities; it goes to the right to negotiate on renewal and the right to mine. It has been a long night and we have probably forgotten the debate. It was a rather strenuous one just before dinner.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment not agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

BREAK.PARA: (23) Schedule 1, item 9, page 75 (lines 10 and 11), omit paragraph (f).

This is the towns and cities amendment. These are the exclusions. The right to negotiate is excluded specifically. The subdivision does not apply to the extent that the act is an act relating solely to land or waters wholly within a town or a city. This measure as it stands is highly discriminatory to those native title holders who have that area as their title. It is discriminatory, I believe, for people who are living in the bush. I hope that I will have the support of the National Party and the government senators from the country in proposing this measure. What the government is doing in paragraph (f) is excluding on crown land native title holders from the right to negotiate. It is the very right that is given within the legislation to native title holders in the bush. That is an extraordinary situation.

I am suggesting to the committee that we delete 26(2)(f) so to as allow the right to negotiate to operate in cities and towns. The government explanatory memorandum refers to a example of native title being compulsorily acquired for the construction of a shopping centre for residential development. The right to negotiate should operate in these circumstances because otherwise, with such an acquisition, the freehold test is racially discriminatory. The freehold test obviously should apply when it comes to the right to negotiate by native title holders.

We are talking about crown land. Let us not get carried away with this: we are only talking about crown land. We are not talking about freehold title, we are talking about the right to negotiate for a mining lease, for example, on crown land. The committee should know that this is a very crucial situation. Let nobody in this chamber think that it is about the right to negotiate over a children's playground which is on crown land, for example. We are talking about mining leases and the like.

Of course, the crown has a right of compulsory acquisition. This was the case in the example that was given in the explanatory memorandum. However, as I say, is it not important for native title holders to have some say about that? Three miles down the road, they do have a say about it. Why, within a town boundary, is there so much difference? I think it is a discriminatory situation, and it does not only affect Aboriginal persons whose native title happens to be within city or town boundaries.

Just because you have native title does not mean you have a right to negotiate, because that is a statutory right. The ludicrous situation is that those people are placed in a different circumstance to people three or four miles down the road out of the town boundary on particular crown land which may, for example, be a parking spot off a highway. I repeat—and I look forward to support from country senators—that it is also discriminatory against people in country areas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Discrimination lies in the eyes of the beholder. Essentially, in towns and cities the issue that arises is almost overwhelmingly a matter of compulsorily acquisition. Compulsorily acquisition of areas for developments within towns and cities happens all the time, and government policy is that people in towns and cities should be treated equally.

SPEECH.PARA: Any native title claimants or holders on any VCL within a town or city are guaranteed the procedural rights of a freeholder. They generally are, at least, the right to be notified, to be consulted, to object and to be heard. It is not as though they do not have a say; they do. We strongly believe in non‐discrimination in relation to those Australians in towns and cities subject to compulsorily acquisition for the purposes that often occur in relation to towns and cities.

If an area is being compulsorily acquired for a purpose—and it may well involve native title holders or claimants on vacant crown land, as well as freeholders right alongside the bit of vacant crown land—then we believe, as a matter of principle, that there should be no discrimination in the treatment of those people. The rights accorded to the freeholders shall be the rights accorded to any native title claimants and holders right next door.

I appreciate where Senator Harradine is coming from. This is one of the issues that is always a problem in relation to discrimination, but in our view it is discriminatory in a town or city to say that, when an area is being acquired for a development of that kind, the freeholder has the freeholding procedural rights that apply, but the native title claimants or holders next door have a different and—almost always, under the right to negotiate—superior right.

As a matter of policy, we think that is inappropriate. Outside towns and cities it is a different question. You are normally dealing with mining there, where, as we have said, on vacant crown land, that will remain, and where the right to negotiate may well be more appropriate. That is the policy. It is not some attempt to deny native title claimants and holders within towns and cities their rights. They have the rights of the freeholders who are right alongside them and who, in many cases, will have their property acquired as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that the Democrat/Green (WA) amendments, at least on this particular issue, are identical to Senator Harradine's amendment.

—I seek clarification of the amendment. Senator Harradine, in a number of townships and cities in regional Western Australia, specifically Port Hedland and Kalgoorlie, a lot of vacant crown land on the immediate outskirts of current city boundaries has not been developed in recent years. One of the reasons that it has not been developed is because there have been claims to native title over that land adjacent to the town boundaries. I want to understand your amendment clearly. Is it that—
—It is your amendment too.

—I understand that but I want to get it on the public record. Is it your position, Senator Harradine, in respect of that development that native title claimants should have the right to negotiate over that vacant crown land immediately adjacent to town boundaries?
—The purpose of this amendment is to put the native title holders in those areas of crown land in precisely the same situation as native title holders in crown land which may be four miles away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —That is why the opposition has a similar, if not identical, amendment to this. We maintain a very strongly held view that there is no basis to discriminate on the basis of the location. We can understand the government putting up this sort of proposal and thinking that it would have some popular appeal. But the reality is that there is no reasonable basis at law or otherwise to deny native title holders the protection of the right to negotiate simply because their land is within a town or city boundary.

SPEECH.PARA: This is particularly so in a number of cases. For instance, we have had evidence that there was supposed to be a township of Hatches Creek in the Northern Territory, but the proposed town was never developed. It has remained vacant crown land from the time it was gazetted. The nearest actual town is Tennant Creek, some 150 kilometres away. So we have had that sort of rorting of the system in the past and we are concerned that that should not continue—the basic principle being that native title in respect of crown land has some relevance.

But there is also another situation in the Northern Territory. The Anurette Aboriginal Land Trust has land lying within it, and that land is now subject to an accepted native title determination. Many of the native title holders actually live on a community nearby. If the government's proposal were to be passed in the Senate, they would be deprived of the right to negotiate over the township, an area which is highly prospective.

So we oppose this amendment for two reasons: first of all, the fundamental principle in respect of native title applying to crown land and non-acceptance by us of the artificial barrier that has been proposed by the government; and also the fact that there has been capacity to rort the system in the past. For instance, at one stage I think Darwin's boundaries were defined to be as big as Sydney's. This sort of blank cheque to governments to do what they like with is something that the opposition is concerned about.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do just want to respond to that, because you are dealing with an entirely different situation in towns and cities than you are outside towns and cities that Senator Harradine talks about. There is a lot more pressure in terms of development in growing towns and cities. They have to be able to expand.

SPEECH.PARA: What is happening in Western Australia is a very significant problem. Because the right to negotiate does not work as some people think it does, where you can have it all done in eight months, that does not happen. There are right to negotiate processes in Western Australia that are still taking three years. These things do not happen in eight months. Because of the complexity of the right to negotiate process, the avenues for legal opportunities to delay the process are enormous.

We are finding in places like Kalgoorlie that there has been no new land released for residential or industrial purposes since March 1995 because of native title claims. The people in Karratha, Western Australia, are experiencing land price hikes of up to 300 per cent due to a shortage of land for development, because of native title claims in and around the city and the impossibility of working through them and getting resolution of these issues.

It is a very major problem particularly in towns and cities in Western Australia but in other parts of Australia as well. It is causing considerable concern and social unrest in places like Kalgoorlie and Karratha. We believe this is the only way through this process. We have done this for genuine policy reasons that are a consequence of the problems that are being experienced on the ground in those sorts of towns.

You are getting social unrest because of the intractability of the native title claims, the incapacity to work your way through them because of current problems in the act. Because you have all these multiple claimants, you cannot get agreements; so people are resorting to court to break the process down. That is why you are getting these sorts of manifest problems in places like Kalgoorlie and Karratha.

We believe that what we are proposing is absolutely fair, equitable and non‐discriminatory because it is treating everyone in town and city boundaries exactly the same. They will all have the rights of freeholders in relation to any requirement for development of suburbs and growth of towns and cities, which is something all Australians should want. One of the problems we have is the contraction in Australia. We want our rural and regional towns and cities to develop. We do not want the social tension that is being caused as a result of problems like those in Kalgoorlie and Karratha. We think this is a very sensible, fair and equitable amendment. We ask the chamber to support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seldom heard so much nonsense. We are talking about disempowering and removing the rights of most of the Nyuangah community in Western Australia, where many of the claims have been lodged and are in process. The Nyuangah community in Western Australia are in land that may come within town or city boundaries on vacant crown land. We are talking about areas such as the airport bushland; we are talking about some lake areas; and we are talking about some areas which have been set aside for bushland—we are talking about the right to negotiate.

SPEECH.PARA: We are talking about areas like Carnarvon where legal rights have not actually been given to people who should have legal rights in places like that. We are talking about people who would like to be considered when vacant crown land within the town boundaries does get put up for development. We are talking about people who also want to look after whatever sites exist, and continue to exist, within the areas that they might—for you, Minister—inconveniently live. There are people living near towns and rivers. There are people living in those areas which you find inconvenient for them to be in, but they are there.

BREAK.PARA: They would like to continue to have the right to negotiate in the lands which are still special to them, to be able to negotiate in relation to sites to protect their land. This is what it is about; it is not about someone being inconvenient because traditionally they happen to live near where towns and cities have now developed. It might be inconvenient for you, but it is a basic human right for those people. To say it is the same or equal rights with other people is sheer nonsense and, in fact, grossly discriminatory.

PARA.EMPHASIS: An incident having occurred in the gallery—

TALK.START.PARA: —I would ask the gallery to know that that is strictly unparliamentary and we would be assisted if you would not interrupt the debate in that way. Senator Harradine, did you wish to speak again on your amendment?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I first of all put at rest the minds of persons around the chamber. I refer to the Native Title Act as it stands at the present moment on page 17. Under the act, if there is to be compulsory acquisition, it applies only in respect of compulsory acquisition and mining. That is what we are talking about. We are only talking about two things. When we are talking about the rights to negotiate in the country people are thinking of their backyards and all the rest of it. It is not that at all.

SPEECH.PARA: Certainly, I do not count Senator Bishop as one of those, because he is a lawyer and has been around. He is a very thoughtful senator and a great contributor to this place. I just put directly to him in response to his question that, under the act, if there is compulsory acquisition or mining on land, then there is a right to negotiate under the Native Title Act. It does not matter if the claim is in the city or the country. What we are really saying is that the native title claimant has the right to negotiate only if there is compulsory acquisition or mining. Otherwise, of course, there is a determination of the matter in the Federal Court. So let us get that perfectly clear.

The minister talked about the problems in a number of places in Western Australia. There are problems all over the place and there are matters which have to be determined. Might I just remind the Senate of one thing. If those provisions had not been in the act, then there would not have been such a ready result in the first native title successful claim at Crescent Head in New South Wales. If we had taken this away a while ago—as the government is proposing to do now—then that first native title claim would not have been able to be so satisfactorily settled in Australia. That is what the government is suggesting here.

I think it is important to put on the record the facts of that particular native title claim and how it was settled. It is a major milestone in Australia's history. The process of reconciliation was this determination of the first native title claim at Crescent Head in New South Wales on 7 April this year. If we are talking about reconciliation, this is an important measure. Obviously, there are other matters that are as important for reconciliation as these, but this is a very important Australian milestone.

This claim, in fact, involved land subject to a compulsory acquisition order. The land was in the boundaries of the country town Crescent Head in the Macleay Valley of New South Wales. There is much similar crown land in country towns throughout Australia, especially on the east coast of the mainland. The settlement which led to the determination of native title was the first such deed of settlement between the crown and indigenous people since white settlement in 1788. So it was a historic occasion. At the Federal Court on 7 April there were 60 Dainggatti elders as well as the mayor of Kempsey and the Attorney‐General of New South Wales. This determination of native title was a triumph for reconciliation and the negotiating processes under the Native Title Act.

It is a national scandal, surely, and an embarrassment to the Commonwealth parliament that the state processes for this category of claim are proposed to be eliminated. Were they too successful, one asks? From now on, compulsory acquisition or mining must be outside towns and cities to attract the right to negotiate.

BREAK.PARA: The Crescent Head claim was completed in two years and six months. The full submission to the claimants was filed within 12 months of the acceptance of the claim in 1994. The deed of settlement was signed 12 months later after extensive negotiations involving the state government, the shire council, the local residents and indigenous people. I am glad to see the Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate, Senator Boswell, come in at this vital time because, might I say, the first settlement of a native title claim in Australia was praised by the local state National Party member and the regional media. The involvement of the process through the right to negotiate was all important for this result. We are talking about process; that was the important issue.

There is no reason, in principle, why compulsory acquisition in a rural area triggers a right to negotiation and compulsory acquisition in a town or city does not, especially in widespread country towns in Australia. There has been no reason—with reference to history or experience—to suggest that good faith negotiations in claims such as that at Crescent Head should not be resolved in a reasonable time. This is particularly so where there is a body of expertise such as the National Native Title Tribunal to assist in the native title process.

The first native title determination attracted wide publicity for Australia in Asia and Europe in both the print and electronic media. It was a great national event. The statutory ingredients should not be discarded by this parliament for future similar claims.

PARA.EMPHASIS: An incident having occurred in the gallery—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief. I would remind everybody that Crescent Head was a compulsory acquisition which extinguished the native title. The Queensland government has just put together the Hopevale agreement which will result in the determination of native title exercisable by the native title holders. For the first time on the mainland of Australia we will have Aboriginal people exercising native title rights under that Hopevale agreement. That has nothing to do with the right to negotiate. There was no right to negotiate process triggered or operable in the Hopevale case. I suggest that, rather than prolong this, we put Senator Harradine's amendment 23.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment No. 23 agreed to.
Amendments Nos 33 to 35 (Senator Harradine's) agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (38) Schedule 1, item 34, page 125 (lines 5 and 6), omit ", 26B(1) or 26C(2)", substitute "or 26B(1)".
(39) Schedule 1, item 34, page 125 (line 13), omit "26C(6),".

I will briefly explain those two amendments. It really is to retain the current time limits that are under the Native Title Act rather than the Native Title Amendment Bill. In other words, the Native Title Amendment Bill which we are discussing has four months; the Native Title Act has six in both cases. My amendment is simply to restore the status quo.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry if I have the wrong running sheet, but on my running sheet it says: Opposition 197, Democrats‐GWA 166, identical with and in conflict with Harradine 38.
—The conflict is not enough for us to quibble with the Harradine amendment.

—I believe that there is actually some confusion here. There is mention, I believe, in the amendments of sections 24NA, 26A(1), 26B(1) and 26C(2). Recalling the immense confusion we had in those sections earlier, I believe we need to defer the amendment, adjust it and come back at a later stage. Amendments Nos 197, 166 and 388 all deal with the same sort of thing.

—I am advised that it is not necessary to move 38 and 39 at all because they are consequential on section 26C being defeated. That section was agreed to. That is the advice that I have. Is there any disagreement with the advice that I have had? We now move on, Senator Harradine, to your amendment No. 25.
—I wish to postpone that amendment.
—Is it the wish of the committee to defer amendment No. 25? There being no objection, it is so ordered. We now go to opposition amendments 124 to 128 and 130 to 134.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again, 124 goes to the right to negotiate renewal of mining leases. We have discussed this a couple of times this evening. Other amendments—125, 126, 127 and 128—have a different effect. There are some consequential impacts that need to be assessed in respect of 125, 126 and 127, but it is important that we do 124 at this stage. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (124) Schedule 1, item 9, page 83 (lines 14 to 27), omit subsection (1).

TALK.START.PARA: —As I was trying to say before, I understand from the amendments which we have just passed over—that is, 197 or Greens WA 166—that there is still a part which I would like to move. The problem with the way we are going on these amendments is that we are likely to miss things. I think we are doing that at a fast rate of knots because there is not the chance to consider things. Before going on to the next section and instead of being told to pass over amendments 197, 166 and 138, I wonder whether we could test the waters in relation to moving that as `omit 26A(1)'.
—Senator Margetts, I may be corrected because I have only just come into the chair, but I am advised that 26A(1) has already been agreed to.
—In which case, instead of agreeing that we are not going to deal with it, I ask that I have a chance to check and my advisers have a chance to check that everything is okay.
—I am sure you can check, Senator, and if you need to we can come back to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —Whilst Senator Margetts is doing that, maybe I can help. Amendments 124 to 130 follow on from the decision we took earlier on this evening with respect to the right to negotiate at the exploration stage. Amendment 124 deletes the retrospective provision the government was proposing with respect to the provision of a once‐only right to negotiate. Amendments 125 and 126 provide for the exclusion of the right to negotiate by reason only of an early agreement that there would be no further negotiations at production stage—that was a government proposal. They are part of our proposal to ensure that you can, by early agreement, ensure that there be no further negotiations at the production stage.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment 127 ensures that the right to negotiate can apply by agreement. Amendments 128 and 129 are consequential amendments and 130 provides a mechanism to ensure that governments follow the future act provisions by allowing a claimant to apply to the Federal Court to stop an act which should have gone through the right to negotiate process. These are all consequential on the decision we took earlier on to provide for a right to negotiate in the exploration stage. There probably does not need to be much debate on them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Margetts, perhaps I can clarify the position for you. I have been advised that opposition amendments 197 and 202, to which you referred previously, were superseded by sheet 835 which was circulated and voted on some time ago and dealt with R115 and 115A, if you remember when they were put. The amendments we are talking about are 142 and 148. They are in fact appropriate to be handled here. Our concern is that there is a capacity for ministerial intervention in arbitration.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Harradine, our amendments remove 36A and replace it with a process for intervention by a Commonwealth minister upon notice to the arbitral body and if it is in the national interest at the time. That is 142 and 148—the national interest requirement. The government amendment provides that a state or territory minister may intervene in the arbitration of a right to negotiate if the body has failed to make a determination in the specified four-month period. There are no notice requirements and the criteria for intervention are that the arbitral body is unlikely to make a determination within a reasonable period that is in the state or territory interest—or a national interest if it is a Commonwealth matter—to make the determination at the time.

There are procedural provisions in 36B(3) which require the minister to invite submissions with the notice for receipt of those submissions at the minister's discretion. The minister must distribute submissions to other parties and provide them with seven days in which to respond. The minister, unfortunately to say the least, is not required to consider the submissions.

So we are concerned as to three aspects. We are concerned as to the conflict of interest issue which Senator Harradine mentioned earlier on: a state or territory minister will be party to the right to negotiate negotiations in which he or she will find himself or herself intervening. We have to protect against that.

There is no requirement for the minister to consider the submissions and there is no review process. So not only do you have a conflict of interest problem but you really have a good faith problem as well. In terms of notice, the process and the time frames for registered claimants to make submissions are left to the minister's discretion. That also is a very unacceptable situation.

We accept that there may be rare situations such as, for instance, where an arbitral body refuses to make a determination where it is necessary to finalise the process for the benefit of all concerned. Due to the conflict of interest problems that I referred to, it is inappropriate for the state or territory minister to have the responsibility. So we have proposed amendments 142 and 148 which we think overcome the conflict of natural justice problems in the government's proposals.

They provide a process through which the Commonwealth minister may place the arbitral body on notice, giving them 30 days after the arbitral period of four months with respect to exploration or six months with respect to mining and acquisitions. That notice can be given and the minister can then make determinations if the body has failed to do so. If the arbitral body fails to make a determination after being notified, the Commonwealth minister may make a determination of the matter in circumstances where it is in the national interest to make a determination at that time.

That is the provision we are putting up. We think it provides for fair process and overcomes the conflict of interest issues, gives fair notification and puts parties on notice for some time that the matter is a serious one. It is in the national interest for it to be determined and we provide a process for that to happen. It is appropriate for me to move those amendments at this stage. I do not know whether we will deal with Senator Margetts's amendments first or ours but we can discuss that. Obviously, they are the amendments that we should be moving at this particular opportunity.
