TALK.START.PARA: —I feel that these matters deal with similar areas. It is going to be interesting to see what finally emerges if Senator Bolkus's and Senator Margetts's amendments are carried. I think it will be interesting to have a look at that. I was attracted to both of them but they are both covering the same field. I would have thought Senator Bolkus's amendments are maybe a little more rounded, if I could put it that way.

—I wonder whether I could make a suggestion. Because there does seem to be some confusion, could we postpone this section and revisit it again tomorrow morning? There does seem to be some conflict and some overlapping. We need to recast to accommodate some of the things that have already been passed. I am putting that to the committee only as a suggestion, but I do think it may be the best way to go. We could revisit it again in the morning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought what the ALP was attempting to do was amend clause 36A, but we seem to have voted to knock it right out all together. If we can sort this out, I think it would be a very good idea.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Harradine's amendment actually knocked it out. If we want to revisit it, it might be a good idea to do it a later stage. Is it the wish of the committee to postpone the section. It is so ordered.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Bolkus, the chair will need some guidance here. I am not sure which of your amendments, 166 or 168, actually relate to that previous section which we have deferred. So you may wish to choose where you want to come in with your next amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I actually had that all worked out about an hour ago. I suggest that we defer that whole page, actually. There are only two further minor amendments there. My understanding was that they were consequential, but we have to work out what the consequences are.

—We will defer page 6 and revisit that. We will move over to page 7 on the running sheet. Senator Bolkus, would you care to move the opposition amendment first, because I understand there is some conflict between the amendments.
—I think it is probably best for Senator Harradine to move his. His omits subsection (2); we amend it. I think it is best to handle that provision first.
—Senator Harradine, I know we have jumped ahead a bit but we are looking at your amendment 46 which omits subsection (2).
—I suggest we defer the matter.

—Certainly. There is a suggestion that perhaps we move down as far as those items where there is no conflict between the amendments that have been moved by the opposition, the Greens (WA), the Democrats and Senator Harradine. Perhaps we could move to page 8, which is amendment 138. There are some that are consequential on the others. I will give you time to look at page 8, but I think it might be best if we move to page 8 and look at those from the top.

—I think your call as to page 7 is right. If you look at it, some of them are consequential to what we have done to 34A, 36A, 36B and 36C and whatever. It would be, I think, an opportunity to work out what we have actually done to the substantive sections and then work out what to do here. One of the problems is that we have actually tried to do the consequential work as well as the substantive work and, as a consequence, we have got confused.
—Would you like to move to page 8, Senator Bolkus.

—Amendment 138 goes to the criteria which are to be taken into account in section 39. The government has altered the section 39 criteria which an arbitral body takes into account when making a determination—or at least, I should say, they have tried to do that. In doing so, they have tried to delete a couple of areas. The first one is a proposal to delete consideration of environmental aspects from the arbitral process. We believe that the provision that is currently in the legislation to ensure consideration of environmental aspects is an important one.

—I thought your amendment 171 dealt with the environment. Amendment 138 was the negotiating period being increased from four to six months, which was a government amendment which has already been agreed to.

—Thank you. Amendment 141, which is the next one, permits negotiations to continue while an arbitral body is dealing with an application for determination. Amendment 167 allows determination of financial conditions by an arbitral body—some part of the negotiation to be postponed by agreement for later determination.
—Senator Bolkus, I am advised that it would be useful if you first of all dealt with amendments 141 and 175. The government is supporting those.

BREAK.PARA: (141) Schedule 1, item 9, page 95 (after line 13), at the end of section 35, add:

PARA.TAB: (3) An application to the arbitral body does not preclude further negotiations referred to in paragraph 31(1)(b) and, if the arbitral body is given a copy of an agreement resulting from the negotiations (see section 41A) before it makes a determination, the application is taken to have been withdrawn unless the negotiation parties advise the arbitral body that a determination may still be made.

BREAK.PARA: (175) Schedule 1, item 9, page 107 (line 19), after "corporate,", insert "representative bodies,".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —Amendment 141, as Senator Minchin said, relates to the negotiating period and restores the notice/negotiating period from four months to six months. I do not think I need to speak longer about that. I think Senator Harradine indicated he thought the current timetable was appropriate as well.
—That was amendment opposition 167?
—Amendment 138.

—Opposition amendment 138, I am advised, has been subsumed by government amendment 142 already agreed. We are now dealing with a package of amendments—opposition amendments 167, 170, 172, 173 and 177. Are you moving those, Senator?
—I will move them all collectively:

SPEECH.PARA: (167) Schedule 1, item 9, page 101 (after line 18), after subsection (1), insert:

PARA.TAB: (1A) A determination may, with the agreement of the parties, provide that particular matters that:

TAB.TAB: (a) are not reasonably capable of being determined at the time the determination is made; and
(b) are not directly relevant to the doing of the act;
are to be the subject of further negotiations or determined in a specified manner.

PARA.TAB: (1B) If the matter is to be determined by arbitration otherwise than by the arbitral body, the parties must agree to the manner of determination or, in the absence of agreement, the matter must be determined by the arbitral body at an appropriate time.
Example 1: A mining lease may be granted subject to quantification of compensation etc. at a later time by an independent arbitrator.
Example 2: A mining lease may be granted subject to site clearance procedures to be determined by a third person.

SPEECH.PARA: (170) Schedule 1, item 9, page 101 (before line 28), at the end of section 38, add:

PARA.TAB: (3) If the act is with respect to a right the creation of which may constitute an earlier act for the purposes of section 26D, the determination may include a condition that:

TAB.TAB: (a) will provide for further negotiations in respect of an act that constitutes a later act for the purposes of that section; or
(b) will provide that this Subdivision will apply to the later act.

PARA.TAB: (4) Proceedings may be taken in a Court of a State or Territory in relation to a determination under this section:

TAB.TAB: (a) for specific performance of a condition of the determination, or
(b) for a declaration that the conditions of the determination have not been complied with by non‐native title parties; or
(c) for an injunction or prohibition restraining those parties from continuing to do things under the act or the later act; or
(d) for damages for the doing of the things or for a failure to comply with the conditions, or both.

SPEECH.PARA: (172) Schedule 1, item 9, page 102 (lines 24 and 25), omit paragraph (d).
(173) Schedule 1, item 9, page 103 (after line 28), at the end of section 40, add:

PARA.TAB: (2) Subsection (1) does not apply to an indigenous land use agreement, or an agreement in writing referred to in section 34, that identifies the agreement or determination affected.

SPEECH.PARA: (177) Schedule 1, item 9, page 108 (lines 31 and 32), omit ", or such longer period as the Commonwealth Minister allows,".

These amendments go to the operation of the arbitral body. They go to issues of what considerations the arbitral bodies should take into account. That is amendment 172. Amendment 173 allows for variation of determination by agreement. We do not deal with 176 there, but 177 requires that revocation of non-complying schemes take effect within 90 days. Essentially, these are technical amend ments which go to the ongoing operation of the tribunal and gives it some flexibility in terms of what to take into account in its processes.
Amendments 167, 170, 172, 173 and 177 agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (169) Schedule 1, item 9, page 101 (lines 19 to 27), omit subsection (2).

This amendment removes the limitation on financial conditions and ensures that a determination can provide for further negotiations at some later stage. It also provides effective enforcement mechanisms for the type of determination. We hold that amendment in common with Democrat-Greens (WA) amendment A3.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask Senator Bolkus to run that by us again.

—Amendment No. 169 is a provision which tackles some of the government amendments as to the process. For instance, on page 101 of the government's bill, it makes an addition to the sorts of conditions that the tribunal could lay down. In doing so, it gives the tribunal a capacity to include financial conditions. So you can have an arbitral determination in respect of financial conditions. It removes the limitation proposed by the government to exclude the same. Further, it ensures that a determination can provide for further negotiations at a later stage; that is in the hands of the system. It provides what we think are necessary and effective enforcement mechanisms for this type of determination. We do this by adding subsections 38(3) and (4) to the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —My understanding is that this attempts to reverse the position in the current act, which makes it clear that the arbitral body must not determine the condition under 1(c)—that is, the determination—which has the effect that native title parties are to be entitled to payments worked out by reference to the amount of profits made, income derived or things produced by any grant to any party. That is a very clear provision in the current act. It was quite properly put in there, I would have thought. You really are starting to get into a very grey area when you have a tribunal of this kind effectively imposing taxes on companies of the kind suggested in there. What seriously concerns us about what is now being proposed is that it is a reversal of that position. I think there could be quite serious questions raised about granting power to a tribunal to act in that way. That was clearly not provided for in the current act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —My amendment No. 30 is designed to allow the arbitral body to take into account the profits to be expected from the venture. These matters can be taken into account by the parties, of course, at the negotiating stage. The interesting part about it is that, in its initial discussion paper, this government said:

SPEECH.PARA: As a further encouragement to successful negotiation . . . this would merely give the arbitral body a discretion to determine such a payment, not oblige it to do so. Such a change could give parties a stronger incentive to reach a negotiated agreement. It would not impact on the obligations of miners to make payments under state or territory loyalty regimes.
That was in the government's own paper. Frankly, I tend to agree with the government's initial discussion paper.

One reason I was somewhat disinclined to move amendment No. 30 is that it may have some Brandy implications, and that concerned me somewhat. We have given Brandy a run around quite a bit during this debate. I just wondered whether the minister had anything to contribute to it. As I said, I have a line through my amendment No. 30—I was not going to move it—but since Senator Bolkus has raised his amendment now, I thought that I would put the comments from the initial discussion paper by the government on the record.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I may have been mistaken. Has opposition amendment No. 168 been withdrawn? I think it was the one that referred to financial conditions. I may be doing a disservice to the opposition.
—It is not listed here.

—I will operate on the presumption that it has been withdrawn from the original ALP amendments. Therefore, the remarks I previously made should be directed to Senator Harradine in respect of his amendment No. 30. It is true that the discussion paper we released early last year in an objective sense included in it this proposition. It was put to us by Aboriginal bodies in particular that the arbitral body should be able to determine a condition worked out by reference to the amount of profits.

SPEECH.PARA: That is in contradiction to section 38(2) of the current Native Title Act, which specifically prohibits companies from doing that. We were persuaded on a variety of grounds that it was right to retain the current prohibition on the arbitral body making a determination of that kind for a whole variety of reasons. It goes to the question of an arbitral body of this kind imposing a royalty payment when royalties are a consequence of the crown owning minerals and a tax levied in respect of that going to the crown; that is, the government representing all of us, as a consequence of the fact that all of us own the minerals. Companies might have charged a tax in the form of a royalty for the use of those minerals, which we all own.

There are legal questions about the capacity of an arbitral body to impose a tax or a royalty of that kind in making a determination as to whether or not an act should proceed. I think it is also the case that it could act as a disincentive to reaching agreement. If you could hold out and get the arbitral body to make a determination of that kind, it would act as a disincentive to reaching agreements. We were persuaded, for a whole variety of reasons, that the proposition involved in your amendment No. 30 is extremely unattractive, legally dubious and something that should not be adopted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Temporary Chair, I rise on a point of order. I have not and was not intending to move amendment No. 30. I just made the observations at a time that I thought was opportune.
—Accepted, Senator.

—The advice the Greens (WA) have received is that, because it is an arbitral body, in this instance there would be no Brandy effects. We might be in a stage of duelling lawyers at the moment, but it is the Greens (WA) position that Senator Harradine's amendment is supportable. However, we would support either Senator Harradine's amendment, if it is put, or amendment No. 83 in our own name or the equivalent opposition amendment No. 169.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (168) Schedule 1, item 9, page 101 (line 18), after "conditions", insert ", including financial conditions,"

I know that amendment No. 168 does not appear on the running sheet, but amendment No. 168 actually sits together with amendment No. 169. What we do by amendment No. 168 is add to section 38(1) on page 101 a further provision to allow the arbitral body to make determinations as to financial arrangements. Amendment No. 169 basically removes section 38(2).

The alternative way of doing it is to do what Senator Harradine's floated, though not moved, amendment does, which is to change the words `must not' to `may' in respect of (2). We still think it is an important thing to do. There are a couple of points to make in respect of it. We are moving to make the arbitral body take into account the profits, income or production flowing from a project conducted on native title land when it is making a future act determination.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bolkus, we have found opposition amendment No. 168. It is back two pages, on page 6, and it has been dropped in the moving over of a couple of pages. Do you want to move it in conjunction with amendment No. 169?

—I am glad you interrupted me to tell me that, Madam Temporary Chair, but it is obvious from what I said earlier that we still want to proceed with it in this particular part of the process. As I was about to say, I have explained the structure of what we are doing. We think it is important that profit be taken into account.

SPEECH.PARA: There is an inconsistency between this provision of the government and section 33 which allows profit sharing conditions to be quite legitimate as an aspect of mining projects going ahead on native title land. Senator Harradine raises the issue of Brandy. It seems to me that whenever the government gets into trouble in a debate on these matters it invokes Brandy. We do not have Brandy problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —We could have!
—You go for the bottle, do you? We do not have Brandy problems, and we have been advised of that by the Queen's Counsel who have been advising us on this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of that, one of the reasons why there is no Brandy problem is because the arbitral body would not be imposing a decision. The decision would only take effect after a court's determination as to that decision. In the same way that you have arbitration, if it is agreed to, then it can have effect, but if it is not agreed to, then it has no effect until it is adopted or a decision is made by the court. That is the advice we have had from our Queen's Counsel, and I have no reason to doubt that advice.

If we do not do something like that then we have an inconsistency where parties are allowed to negotiate as to agreements in respect of profit sharing, but if they cannot come to an agreement and it then goes to the arbitration process, this aspect is taken out of the arbitration process.

The real problem is that the incentive for parties to come to an agreement is not there. If you were a party against whom a claim was made on notice, and you knew that after a six‐month period you would not have to embark upon discussions with the claimants as to profit sharing, and that you would only have to find yourself arbitrated upon in terms of a more limited range of activities, then obviously you would hold out. There would be no incentive for you to sit down and negotiate on the broader range of aspects available at that early stage in the process.

It really works in an unfair manner against indigenous Australians. It is conducive to not having an agreement in the negotiating period. It stands to reason that if, at the end of six months, certain things are off the table in terms of capacity to negotiate, then you would hang out for the six months and you would make the other party go to the table on a narrower range of things.

As I say, Brandy is not a problem. It is not a problem because determinations are not binding and will have no binding effect. If they are agreed to, they can obviously be implemented. If they are not agreed to, then it is a court that makes a determination; and that determination is binding.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is 10 to 11 so I forgive Senator Bolkus, but that was a most confusing exposition. We have replicated exactly the same arrangements that are in the current act with regard to the difference between the negotiation phase and the arbitration phase. That is, as in our bill and as in the current act, the parties are free to come to agreement if they so choose—willingly and voluntarily enter into agreements about payments relating to profits, income derived or things produced.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, you should not constrain parties to reach an agreement on those things. But, as in the current act agreed to by you back in 1993, the arbitral body is expressly prevented from making a determination in relation to the right to negotiate process—this has nothing to do with the Federal Court, Senator Bolkus. It cannot make a determination where payments are worked out by reference to profits, income or things produced. This is arbitration in the right to negotiate. This has nothing to do with the determination of native title. This is about whether the future act can proceed.

That is why there is a problem. This is an arbitral body. It is the Native Title Tribunal or an equivalent state body—an administrative body—being given the opportunity to impose a tax. If you say it can impose financial conditions and you at the same time remove item 38(2) which says `Profit-sharing conditions not to be determined', as in the current act, you are running into some legal problems.

As I say, I forgive you for confusing the determinative role by the court and the arbitration role by the tribunal as to whether a thing can be done or not done, and the basis on which it can be done. You were quite right to say, as you did, that one of the reasons you put this in the original act was so that there was an incentive to come to agreement and not a disincentive not to by allowing this thing to occur at the arbitral stage. You are quite right in that argument. That is the reason why we have replicated in the bill the provisions in the current act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I think what Senator Minchin has done is actually confirm my point. He has said that the arbitral body can make determinations as to certain aspects. You do not have to make a determination purely as to financial aspects to be in breach of Brandy. Basically, you could make determinations as to other aspects and be in breach of Brandy, unless you work a mechanism to get around Brandy. What you have done is put in place a system where there can be determinations as to a whole range of matters by the arbitral body, and you tell us that that system is Brandy proof. And we accept that.

SPEECH.PARA: What we are saying is that, amongst those things that the tribunal can make an assessment of and a determination on, put in financial considerations as well. They are there at the moment. You are wanting to extract a range of them. We say that in the same way that the body has a constitutionally acceptable and valid power to make determinations as to a range of things, then you should not exclude from its range of determinative functions the capacity to make determinations as to financial transactions. That is all we are saying.

If your system is Brandy proof in respect of the range of activities which you can make a determination on, then adding one further activity to that should not be a problem. You say, `What we want to do is ensure that the arbitral body can decide on whether an act must not be done, whether that act may be done, the way that act may be done and the conditions to be complied with by any of those parties.' That is what you provide for now.

We say that is fair enough. You have worked out a system that is okay in terms of the Brandy decision of the High Court. We say that, in terms of all those determinations that an arbitral body can make, add another one; and that is that the body can make a determination as to financial considerations as well. I do not think there is a problem, Senator Minchin. I do not think I am the one who is confused at this time of the night. I suspect I should throw that back at you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to prolong this. My point was that we have replicated exactly what is in the current act. Our provisions in relation to the kinds of arbitral body determination that can be made and the specific exclusion of profit-sharing conditions not to be determined is exactly what is in the current act in section 38(1) and (2), which was agreed by you for very good reasons.

SPEECH.PARA: The trouble is that, if you put in a specific power to determine financial conditions and you take away the restriction or the prohibition on those financial conditions being profits, income derived, things produced, et cetera, then you do have a problem as to what is meant by `financial conditions'. For example, if financial conditions were interpreted as compensation, then you would have a problem. There is also the question of whether the arbitral bodies can tax by imposing royalties and all that sort of thing—the sorts of points I was making to Senator Harradine before.

We think you had it right in 1993. We think that, by having it as it is written here, you are more likely to provide incentives for agreements to be reached rather than going to arbitration. We think this is one part of the original act that was right and we suggest it not be changed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think what the minister has done is convince me to pick up amendment No. 30 of Senator Harradine's circulated amendments. If that is your concern, then what we will do is pick up the amendment to 38(2) that replaces `must not' with the word `may'. The minister has given absolutely no good reason to indicate why it is within the constitutional requirements to make determinations as to the first three factors and not within the constitutional requirements to make determinations as to what I would propose would be subclause (2). Can I say to you, Senator Minchin, you may have a problem with it in a policy sense. I do not think there is a Brandy problem.
—We think the policy is right.

—You might say the existing act is all right. What you have been claimed to be on about in the whole process has been to improve the act. What we say is that, to the extent that the act does not have this capacity as to financial transactions, let it so give the arbitral bodies that power. So I will withdraw opposition amendment No. 169 and I will move Senator Harradine's circulated amendment No. 30—of course, with the leave of Senator Harradine whom I think has probably still decided not to move it. If I could do that, Senator Harradine, I would be pleased to do so.
—I don't think I will support it, though.
—You may not support it. I will ask you: you are concerned about Brandy problems but—you are not concerned about Brandy problems?
—I am concerned.

—The question to ask is: why should there be a Brandy problem in respect of financial transactions—I will ask Senator Minchin this as well—when there are no Brandy problems in respect of other determinations?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not simply the question of the constitution. It is vague because what are financial conditions? If financial conditions include compensation, you do have a problem because that can only be determined by a court, but you have the issue of an imposition of what amounts to royalties by an administrative body of this kind and that is an extremely dangerous thing. If it amounts to a tax on a company, what does that mean in a legal sense?

SPEECH.PARA: Obviously, the policy constraints that you felt there were at the time in determining that profit conditions not be determined were right because there are a range of legal issues surrounding allowing an arbitral body, which is an administrative process, making determinations of this kind. You are effectively allowing it to either tax a company or impose royalties, which only the Crown can do. Where the financial conditions can be interpreted, as I say, as compensation, that raises legal questions. We recognise that you must have had good legal advice at the time. That is why you put this in here and that is why we have repeated it. You must have had the odd bit of good legal advice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens (WA) believed it was a very wise move by Senator Harradine to look at the way in which the arbitral body could consider profit and income of future act projects to determine payments to native title holders. I guess it is a pity if Senator Harradine is not going to support his own amendment. I think the argument that has been put by the minister is that it was in the act. He does not seem to think that any other part of the original Native Title Act was sacred. Everything else has been up for grabs, so that is not a particularly good argument.

SPEECH.PARA: He then said he was less worried about the constitutional aspects. I have certainly had reassurances from those who should know, from my office, that it is not likely to be a problem. I think we get down to whether or not it is a tax. That is somewhat hard to justify in these circumstances—that it actually could be called a tax. We are clutching at straws here, Minister. I hope that we can still support this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bolkus has indicated he will withdraw amendment 169. Is leave granted? There being no objection, leave is granted.

BREAK.PARA: Amendment—by leave—withdrawn.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bolkus, I believe you wish to move Senator Harradine's amendment 30.

INTERJECT.PARA: (30) Schedule 1, item 9, page 101 (line 20), omit "must not", substitute "may".

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee is now considering Senator Harradine's amendment 30 moved by Senator Bolkus and opposition amendment 168.
—I ask that these amendments be postponed.

—Is it the wish of the committee that opposition amendment 168 and Senator Harradine's amendment 30, as moved by Senator Bolkus, be postponed? There being no objection, it is so ordered. We will now deal with opposition amendment 171.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (171) Schedule 1, item 9, page 102 (after line 16), after paragraph (a), insert:

TAB.TAB: and

(vi) the natural environment of the land or waters concerned, to the extent that it, and the likely effect of the act upon it, are relevant to the native title rights and interests claimed or determined;
(aa) any assessment of the effect of the proposed act on the natural environment of the land or waters concerned:
(i) made by a court or tribunal; or
(ii) made, or commissioned, by the Crown in any capacity or by a statutory authority;
to the extent that the assessment is relevant to subparagraph (a)(vi);

SPEECH.PARA: This provision seeks to reinstate the consideration of environmental matters by the arbitral body. To date, there is a provision in the legislation that allows the arbitral body to consider environmental matters. We think it is important for them to keep doing so. Environmental matters are of immediate and important concern to indigenous Australians. The provision in the legislation has worked and no‐one has actually complained about the way it has worked over the last 2½ years.

We believe there is absolutely no justification for this aspect to be withdrawn. Some would say that this should be a matter for state and territory governments, but native title more than any other title is linked to the natural environment. Given that the right to negotiate is there for the protection of native title, it is probably unreasonable to admit this sort of thing.

I say to senators that this is not a new proposal or an innovation; the opposition is arguing that the existing clauses have operated with no detrimental effect and they should be allowed to continue.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no reason why you should take one group of people and exclude them from negotiating on particular issues which are most important to them. It is like saying that the environment is somewhere else and somehow or other native title has nothing to do with the environment. Of course, it is about protecting sites but it is also about protecting your lives and your health. You cannot separate that from the environment. It is about the quality of water. It is about whether or not aquifers are joined. It is about whether or not the tailings dams that are left in mines are toxic. It is about whether or not the impact kills the vegetation. There are all sorts of impacts. It is ridiculous to consider that you pull that out and say that you cannot consider the environment. It makes no sense at all. I agree with Senator Bolkus that the committee should stick with, in this particular case, the provision as it is in the existing act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —Any mining project has to go through a whole range of requirements and conditions before it can be approved; one of them is always the environment. We are talking here about the question of native title per se and the Native Title Tribunal. We require the arbitral body to take into account the effect of the act on the enjoyment by the native title parties of their determined or claimed native title rights and interests, the way of life, culture and traditions, the development of social, cultural and economic structures of any of the parties—in other words, everything to do with native title.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the role of the Native Title Tribunal in making an arbitral determination. This is not about negotiation; this is a determination as to whether an act can proceed. Those acts, of course, always have to go through environmental regulations before they even get to this point. That is why it was removed by us—to ensure that the Native Title Tribunal was focusing on the impact of the act on native title.

SPEECH.PARA: The natural environment of the land and water is concerned to the extent that it and the likely effect of the act upon it are relevant to the native title rights and interests claimed or determined.

What the minister has said means nothing. What we are talking about is the impact of the act on the environment, to the extent that it impacts on native title rights and any assessment of the effect of the proposed act on the natural environment of the land or waters concerned that is relevant to subparagraph A(6) made by a court or a tribunal or commissioned by the crown in any capacity or by statutory authority. It does relate specifically to native title and that is exactly what the words of this amendment say.
