TALK.START.PARA: —You do well to remind us. A little discussion happened here and I beg your pardon that everybody in the committee was not made aware of that.

INTERJECT.PARA: If we turn to freehold test, it is No. 17 of the sheets that I have. No. 10, freehold test, schedule 1, item 9.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —What a good time to hit upon a new topic. Freehold test is one where the opposition does have some amendments, so does Senator Harradine and so do the Greens and Democrats. We have heard often in this debate the government say that the test should be what happens in respect to freehold. One could very easily have gone on to argue: well, let's let the acquisition processes apply in respect to some of the acquisitions we are actually implementing in this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The freehold test is one that is in the Native Title Act and it ensures that future acts are only permissible if they are non‐discriminatory in the sense that the act applies in the same way to native title holders as it would for other ordinary titles to land. Ordinary titles in essence means freehold titles. In that respect a key principle is the non‐discriminatory freehold test, and that key principle was a basic foundation of the Native Title Act.

There are some exceptions to this rule under the current Native Title Act but they are very limited and they are limited compared with the government's proposed amendments which will not require the non‐discriminatory freehold test to be satisfied for many major developments. These are some of the aspects that we discussed earlier on in the committee process, things such as primary production activity, renewals, extensions, reservations and so on. As set out, the aim of those amendments, and the concern about the aim of those amendments, was to allow discrimination against native title holders.

In respect to the old freehold test, as set out in section 24MD, the government is proposing a couple of new amendments. In respect to opal and gem mining, they are proposing an amendment there because we believe that under some state legislation the holder of freehold has a right of veto over opal and gem mining. This means that if the non‐discrimination test applies, then the native title holders in those states would also have the right of veto over opal and gem mining. To prevent this, the bill has excluded opal and gem mining from the freehold test. What we are proposing is a more limited right of negotiation in respect to opal and gem miners. For us, it would be inconsistent to support a position that insists on an effective right of veto in this respect.

The other area of major concern is where land is compulsorily acquired. Then the native title is extinguished at the date of the acquisition, even if the land is never used. That is of particular concern to us. The common law position and the position under the act was that the non‐extinguishment principle applied and extinguishment could only occur when there was an actual act which took place that extinguished native title at common law, for instance, the grant of a freehold title. Until that occurred the mere acquisition of the land by the government did not extinguish native title. We are concerned that this proposal is to be an exception to the freehold test.

A further concern is in respect to extinguishment. What the government is providing is that extinguishment occurs for compulsory acquisitions, as I have detailed. We believe that this is unnecessary; it goes further than the common law. The mere acquisition without actual inconsistent use can coexist with the native title and should be allowed to do so. There is no reason also why such extinguishment should be permanent and not able to revive after the public work is no longer used.

We believe our amendments are an improvement in that they do qualify the parts relating to extinguishment. However, it should be noted that our concerns go to three or four areas. I must also add that the bill further limits the requirement in the Native Title Act that the native title holders should have the same procedural rights as ordinary title holders by excluding approved exploration acts and gold and tin mining et cetera. These are dealt with in the right to negotiate section.

A concern also is that the bill provides that notification is removed in some instances, such as notices to the public. Overall, we do not see a justification for most of these exceptions to the non‐discrimination principle. Our amendments are designed to remove the further acts of discrimination proposed by the government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will just speak to this section on the freehold test in terms of the relevant sections. Section 24MA sets out the basic freehold test for legislative acts that affect native title rights. The law must apply in the same way to native title holders as it would if they held ordinary title, generally the freehold test—which is what we have been saying throughout this debate—and that test would be met by a law that permits mining on native title and freehold land.

SPEECH.PARA: The freehold test is currently contained in section 23 and in definitions in sections 235 and 253. This provision moves the main definition provision from section 235 to within the future act regime in division 3 subdivision M, so it is a restructuring of the act and, of course, the test remains the same.

Section 24MB sets out the basic freehold test for non‐legislative acts, such as compulsory acquisitions and mining grants. The test is that the act could be done in relation to native title land if the native title holders instead held ordinary title, generally freehold title. For onshore waters, such as rivers and lakes, the test is that the act could be done in relation to the waters if the native title holders held ordinary title to the land joining surrounding waters.

Again, this is put here as part of the general restructuring of the freehold test that we have performed in the surgery on this particular piece of legislation. Section 24MC makes it clear that subdivision M dealing with `Acts passing the freehold test' does not apply to acts offshore, they are dealt with separately in subdivision N. In the current act, onshore future acts and offshore future acts are dealt with together in section 23 and relevant definitions in sections 235 and 253, and that is confusing for users of the act. Therefore, we have split them into separate subdivisions for workability reasons.

Section 24MD sets out the consequences for future acts which pass the freehold test set out in sections 24MA and 24MB. Acts that pass the test are valid. Native title can only be extinguished by a compulsory acquisition provided that the acquisition law permits acquisition of native title and non-native title rights and native title and non‐native title rights are acquired. If an extinguishing compulsory acquisition order does not provide just terms compensation, then that is provided by the section, as is an ability for the native title holders to request non‐monetary compensation. Apart from compulsory acquisitions which meet those requirements, all other future acts are subject to the non-extinguishment principle.

For those other non‐extinguishing acts, compensation is provided by the Native Title Act if ordinary title holders would get compensation in the same circumstances, but the law does not provide compensation to non‐native title holders. In other words, compensation is provided by these provisions.

The native title holders can recover compensation from the Commonwealth if it is an act attributable to the Commonwealth or the states and territories to whom it is attributable. The law may provide that if the act is done at the request of a person, that person is liable for the compensation. For example, compensation in relation to mining is often made payable by the miner.

In relation to compensation for the compulsory acquisition of native title on a non‐exclusive pastoral agricultural lease, the native title holders are not entitled to recover from the lessee and must recover from the relevant government. Native title holders generally have the same procedural rights as ordinary title holders in regard to future acts which pass the freehold test and, as I said before, the exception to that is acts subject to the right to negotiate. If these procedural rights require notification and there has been no determination of native title, then this notification can be to any rep body or registered claimant.

We have actually protected and strengthened the protection of native title from extinguishment. New section 24MDB provides that a requirement for extinguishment is that the compulsory acquisition take both native title and any relevant non‐native title rights in relation to the land. But there are clearly legitimate land management needs such as suburban developments, public infrastructure and agricultural developments where, in the event that agreement cannot be reached, compulsory acquisition of all title on the land will be necessary. That is provided for under these provisions.
We have moved several government amendments, Nos. 27, 28, 29 and 30. If you are happy with it, I will speak briefly to those. I move:
(27) Schedule 1, item 9, page 67 (line 13), omit "(whether compulsorily or otherwise)".
(28) Schedule 1, item 9, page 67 (after line 15), after paragraph (b), insert:

PARA.TAB: and (ba) the practices and procedures adopted in acquiring the native title rights and interests are not such as to cause the native title holders any greater disadvantage than is caused to the holders of non‐native title rights and interests when their rights and interests are acquired;

SPEECH.PARA: (29) Schedule 1, item 9, page 68 (lines 16 to 19), omit subparagraph (a)(i), substitute:

TAB.TAB: (i) if a law of the Commonwealth provides that a person other than the Crown in right of the Commonwealth is liable to pay the compensation—that person; or

SPEECH.PARA: (30) Schedule 1, item 9, page 68 (lines 22 to 25), omit subparagraph (4)(b)(i), substitute:

TAB.TAB: (i) if a law of the State or Territory provides that a person other than the Crown in any capacity is liable to pay the compensation—that person; or

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment 27 is to propose subsection 24MD(2) which provides that native title onshore can be extinguished by a non‐discri minatory compulsory acquisition. The requirement of such a non‐discriminatory process is that non‐native title interests are also acquired. The amendment removes the words `whether compulsorily or otherwise' from this requirement with regard to non‐native title interests. We have included that in response to concerns expressed by some that the words `whether compulsorily or otherwise' may in some way be discriminatory or permit compulsory acquisitions that are discriminatory. That is certainly not our intention, so we are happy to remove those words.

Amendment 28 is in a similar vein. It ensures that the practices and procedures adopted in relation to a compulsory acquisition do not cause native title holders to be any more disadvantaged than the holders of other rights and interests when their rights are required to further ensure a non-discriminatory process.

Amendment 29 is an amendment which adjusts the provision which allows the Commonwealth to pass on native title compensation liabilities to third parties. It will make it clear that if a law of the Commonwealth states that a third party is liable for the compensation, then that third party and not the Commonwealth is liable. Amendment 30 does that with respect to the states as well.

We do have some difficulty with the approach put forward by the ALP. There are amendments which deal with the application of heritage protection requirements. We had this debate before and we say that the Native Title Act is not about heritage matters. That is a matter for the relevant Commonwealth, state and territory legislation, and not for this legislation.

The ALP also seeks to omit reference to gem and opal mining, and that is something we also cannot agree to. It is our view that the effect of that amendment would be to render opal and gem mining impermissible under the Native Title Act where state and territory legislation allows freeholders a veto over mining. That is a significant problem and one, I would have thought, that the ALP would have been alive to.

There is also this issue of the nature of the extinguishment. The ALP would say that extinguishment occurs in relation to the acquisition of native title rights and interests only when the act for which the rights are required is actually done. There is absolutely nothing in the common law to support that proposition. It is certainly our view of the common law that native title is extinguished at the point of acquisition. We think that there are considerable problems if it is not at the point of acquisition. If you are talking about compensation on the point of acquisition, but native title is not extinguished, then there are major problems.

You also have significant problems if the government acquires land for suburban development—and you are saying that the native title is not extinguished by that acquisition. Let us say, then, that the land is passed on to somebody else before there is a development upon it and the native title is subsisting. When it is sold on, it is sold on the basis that there was a compulsory acquisition, but native title has not been extinguished and continues to subsist in the land even when it has been sold and it is there until the land is actually used, even though compensation has presumably been paid for the acquisition of the native title through the compulsory acquisition process. I think that that is legally chaotic and not consistent with the common law, and we could not support it. That is all I have to say at this stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Probably one of the most important amendments here is amendment No. 95—which I think is the equivalent of the opposition amendment 105—that limits the extinguishment of native title upon compulsory acquisition to those activities which would have extinguished native title at common law. Remember the government claims that there is no extinguishment of native title in this bill. This is, in fact, quite clearly extinguishment of those aspects of native title which would not have been extinguished under common law. So we are going further than the provisions that exist under common law. I really do not think that that is acceptable. It is very important that there are no further means of using such things as a freehold test to justify further extinguishment of native title.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —The government is seeking to remove the future act regime under the current Native Title Act and to replace it with provisions designed to ensure formal equality between native title holders and freeholders. The Democrats, the Greens and, most importantly, the National Indigenous Working Group, oppose the government's approach because native title cannot, and should not, be equated to freehold. The current provisions in the Native Title Act regarding future acts attempt to provide a comprehensive scheme for ensuring that native title holders are accorded appropriate procedural and substantive rights.

SPEECH.PARA: Without these provisions, native title could well be rendered unenforceable for indigenous people. Without the right to negotiate all future act provisions, native title can be extinguished and impaired piece by piece without any protection or recourse for native title holders.

Of course, native title holders' rights to just terms compensation when native title lands are compulsorily acquired remain under the government's provisions. I note that earlier in this debate the committee agreed to remove the need for governments to compulsorily acquire native title lands to develop public infrastructure facilities. The Democrats oppose this move. However, I note that the requirement for the payment of just terms compensation remains. As we are all aware, this is a constitutional requirement. Nothing the government can do in proposing its current amendments can take this away. Indeed, I believe that the government does not wish to take this right away.

To a very large extent, non‐indigenous people in this country have come to almost worship the notion of freehold title which, as we know, provides land tenure of exclusive possession. Let us think about that for a moment: the notion of exclusivity means not sharing with anyone. It is quite reasonable in a modern democratic state that people have some possession and some spaces in this land of ours that give them exclusive possession. Nobody would quibble with that.

BREAK.PARA: However, we presently have a government that has an ideological obsession rooted in economic fundamentalism that says all property needs to be in the hands of private individuals or under private control. That is why the Howard government sold Telstra, the national railways and a host of other government facilities.

No‐one in this place is under any illusion about the Australian Democrats' position on privatising publicly owned assets. On the other hand, when we look at the government's ideological obsession, it becomes a little easier to understand why the government is so keen on confirming exclusive possession. However, the High Court has confirmed the principles of coexistence; of sharing land of coexisting title. However much the government may wish that had not happened, that is the trend in many countries where indigenous peoples have a history of prior occupation of land. But this government wants to turn back the clock. The Democrats will not support going back to a time when indigenous people were pushed to the fringes.

The problem is that under the white legal system land title can only be understood in terms of exclusive tenure, so people get very scared and confused when anything else is suggested. Indigenous cultural and spiritual affinity with land is often explained in terms of English common land law. Understanding indigenous attitudes to land in this way is patronising in the extreme and a flawed and colonialist approach.

The government's freehold test removes the requirement for adequate notification which is in the current act. There is no justification for removing these provisions. In fact, the Democrats and Greens will move amendments to strengthen notification and other procedural protections. If there is to be any adjustment to the current system, the Democrats believe that it should be to strengthen the procedural protections afforded native title holders, not to weaken them.

The government's freehold test is discriminatory because it excludes the test from native title lands over which it is proposed to permit opal or gem mining. Why does the government want to exclude the freehold test from these matters? Because in some states freeholders have the right to veto opal and gem mining on their lands. If the government was genuine in its desire to see formal equality between native title holders and freeholders, it would clearly ensure that native title holders would retain the same right of veto on such activity.

The Democrats also maintain that extinguishment of native title from activities under these provisions should be limited to the extinguishment that would occur under the common law. There is no need for the amount of extinguishment to be greater than is necessary to give effect to the act that is required to be carried out.

In conclusion, I wish to explain that the philosophical underpinning of the Democrats' opposition to these amendments is based on our belief that it is not appropriate to seek formal equality between the rights of native title holders and freeholders. Native title holders have a special and unique relationship with the land. This relationship simply does not exist between freeholders and their land.

No-one is saying that non-indigenous people who have lived in a particular place for a long time do not develop a deep appreciation for the land upon which they live. No-one is saying that non-indigenous freeholders do not love their land or country. But it must be apparent to everyone here that the relationship that native title holders have with their country—a relationship which has existed for thousands of years—continues today and will continue. The relationship is cultural, spiritual and sacred and is no less important than, and is in the same category as, the relationship that Jews have to Jerusalem, Catholics to the Vatican, and Moslems to Mecca.

In 1993 this parliament moved to recognise that relationship by establishing protective procedures to ensure that native title can be extinguished only if appropriate procedures are followed, and then only to the absolute extent necessary for the proposed activity. I urge senators to recognise the reasons behind the decision that was made in 1993 and maintain, and indeed strengthen, the protections that were established then. I commend the Democrats‐Greens amendments to the Senate, which we move on behalf of the National Indigenous Working Group.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —My amendments 18 and 19 relate to 24MD, the treatment of acts that pass the freehold test. Amendment 18 seeks to delete in line 13 of 24MD(2)(b) the words `whether compulsorily or otherwise'. I hope it generally would be agreed around the chamber that it would be racially discriminatory to allow the compulsory acquisition of proven native title rights not for public purpose but simply for the grant of right of exclusive possession to a lessee who has voluntarily surrendered a non‐exclusive tenure.

SPEECH.PARA: If this upgrade of pastoral leases proposals were truly non-discriminatory, it would have to be non-discriminatory on its face and non-discriminatory in its application. This would mean it would be equally feasible for native title holders voluntarily to surrender their native title rights and to successfully request state governments compulsorily to acquire pastoral lease and then issue the native title holders with rights of exclusive possession.

Leaseholders attempting to upgrade could go along to a state government and say, `We want to upgrade. We do not want to go through all this hassle. You compulsorily acquire our leasehold rights, and then we will buy it back and have it as freehold.' Amendment 18 says that compulsory acquisition of native title rights should be possible only on the same terms and conditions as the compulsory acquisition of all involuntary resumption of other property rights. Compulsory acquisition of native title rights should not complement a voluntary surrender of a pastoral lease. In other words, it is keeping everybody honest. A similar principle applies to my amendment No. 19.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine, if I could just suggest that we do have the government amendments that have been proposed before the chair. Were you proposing your own amendments or just talking to them?
—No, I am just talking to them, as we have done over the—
—No, I understand; I just was not sure. I thought I heard you say that you were moving them.

—I may well have, and I apologise for that. I am a little bit distracted because I believe there are negotiations going along as to whether we sit until 2 o'clock or something like that. Okay, it is until a quarter past one. You have your negotiations and I will continue speaking.
—I am sorry, Senator Harradine, I was not trying to—

—Thank you. Amendment 21 is to clause 24NA(3)(b). I do not know whether any of the clerks have got the act as it is, or the bill as it has been amended up to date, but I suspect that, in an amendment, I think, two days ago, we did take out a particular word from that clause and what I am attempting to do is to remove those words whether compulsorily or otherwise from line 30 of that clause which is on page 70 of the act.

BREAK.PARA: It is not known if there are other rights and interests in offshore places which would ever be acquired by government, but if there are, they should be treated in the same way as native title rights. If native title rights offshore are to be compulsorily acquired and there are other rights to be affected, they should be treated equally—that is, to say compulsory acquisition of both—and that is the purpose of my amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that the opposition will support the Harradine amendments 18 and 21. We will only pursue our amendment No. 106, which goes to the issue of permanent extinguishment, the one that was discussed earlier. We would prefer to have Senator Harradine's amendment 18 put before government amendment 27, because we would prefer 18 to 27. If we can proceed, for instance, with Harradine amendment 18 then government 27, the rest of the government ones we are supporting, then our 106 and Harradine 21, we will probably get through this very quickly.

—Many things were happening during that time; I just need to clarify things with Senator Bolkus. He said 106 because of the non-extinguishment, but has our 95—and your 105 also deals with something similar—now been dropped and, if so, why?
—I am pleased you mentioned this; 105 is the one that we need to retain, not 106.
—Good, 105 and 106, thank you.
—Yes.

—I need some guidance. I understand that it has been suggested that Senator Harradine's amendment No. 18 be moved prior to government amendments 27, 28, 29 and 30. Is that what you were suggesting, Senator Bolkus?
—If you move that formally, we will support you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask that government amendments Nos 27 to 30 be postponed.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments postponed.
Amendment (by Senator Harradine) agreed to:
(18) Schedule 1, item 9, page 67 (line 13), omit "(whether compulsorily or otherwise)", substitute "compulsorily".
Progress reported.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Days and Hours of Meeting and Routine of Business

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Ian Campbell)—by leave—proposed:

That the order agreed to earlier today relating to the hours of meeting and routine of business for 4 December 1997, be modified to provide that the sitting of the Senate not be suspended till Friday, 5 December 1997 at 1 a.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to make a short statement; I am speaking to the motion. Clearly, there are sufficient senators in the chamber to carry this motion. But I was talking to my media officer a little while ago, and she had received a number of media calls. She said, `What can I say?' I said, `You can say that we haven't got a clue what's going on.' She said, `I can't say that,' and I said, `Yes, you can.' So she rang back to this particular person in the media, and that person said, `Yes, I've rung all the other senators' offices, and they've told me the same thing.' So I just say to you that is the situation, but I will stay here.

—Speaking to the motion, I think this is a ridiculous way to make legislation. I know some people would like to get away by lunchtime tomorrow. But if it means spending more time tomorrow afternoon and actually doing it right—when people are awake—that is what we should be doing instead of this ridiculous nonsense now.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been advised that, with the passage of Senator Harradine's amendment No. 18, perhaps the government should withdraw amendment No. 27 and then we will move on to Nos 28, 29 and 30.

INTERJECT.PARA: (21) Schedule 1, item 9, page 70 (line 30), omit "(whether compulsorily or otherwise)', substitute "compulsorily".

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine, could I just have some indication that you are not proceeding with No. 19?
—No, I am not proceeding with No. 19 or No. 20, Mr Chairman.
—Thank you, Senator Harradine.
—My amendment No. 105 goes to the issue of whether extinguishment is permanent or otherwise. We of course advocate that it should not be permanent. I move:

BREAK.PARA: (105) Schedule 1, item 9, page 67 (lines 17 to 19), omit paragraph (c), substitute:

TAB.TAB: (c) the non‐extinguishment principle applies to the acquisition, but nothing in this Act prevents any activity that is done in giving effect to the purpose of the acquisition from extinguishing native title rights and interests if such an extinguishment would occur under the common law; and

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to say, to show you that I am still here, that the Democrat and Green amendments are identical, so we will support the opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is not actually an amendment relating to permanency. It is more a question of the effect of acquisition. We think that this proposal introduces an extraordinary note of uncertainty. To propose that:

SPEECH.PARA: the non‐extinguishment principle applies to the acquisition, but nothing in this Act prevents any activity that is done in giving effect to the purpose of the acquisition from extinguishing native title rights and interests if such an extinguishment would occur under the common law—

I cannot think of a more appropriate recipe for vagueness and uncertainty. As I said before in my other remarks, if a compulsory acquisition of native title by the government does not amount to an extinguishment, I think it just leads to an extraordinary situation where you have no idea what the effect is, what native title survives, and what its relationship is to the nature of the land. And what about the question of compensation that may have been paid as a result of the compulsory acquisition? Presumably, that was compensation paid because the native title rights and interests were being acquired, but you get compensation for having your native title rights and interests acquired but you still have native title. The thing is a nonsense.

What happens if, as I said before, the land is acquired by the government and then sold on? Does this native title that was acquired but that still survives get carried on? What happens to it when it moves on to the new owner? This really is a legal nightmare. It adds dramatically to the uncertainty of native title. If it is not the case that compulsory acquisitions extinguish native title, then we have a dog's breakfast, as was said by Graham Richardson, and the ALP's professed commitment to certainty is shown to be utterly fraudulent.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very tempting at this stage of the night to actually pick any page of the government's bill and to read out a particular clause on it and ask Senator Minchin to tell us what certainty is provided by that clause.
—Don't be tempted, Senator Bolkus.

—I will not be tempted. But I make the point that anything out of context could be made to sound quite tortuous. Nowhere is that comment more relevant than to this Native Title Amendment Bill. You cannot even understand the explanatory memorandum let alone the bill.
—That is you!

—No, it is not just me. You ask anyone else. There is a radical new approach in terms of the memo. The principle is very clear: in this particular area, everything has to be spelt out in a circuitous way before you get to what you are stating. It has been drafted by very experienced parliamentary draftsmen. It does what we said we are seeking to do, that is, to ensure that the extinguishment is not permanent. I suggest that we put the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that I am not dreadfully clear about this. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the non‐extinguishment principle applies to the acquisition, but nothing in this Act prevents any activity that is done in giving effect to the purpose of the acquisition from extinguishing native title rights and interests if such an extinguishment would occur under the common law.

As I see it—and Senator Bolkus or Senator Minchin can correct me if I am wrong—it really is a way of saying that, if there is a common law effect and that common law effect is as a result of a decision in the matter of the nature of native title rights and interests, then this is really recognising that fact. The government has said all along that it is not about diminishing the common law native title rights. I wonder whether that is the point that the opposition is getting at. If so, I suppose it is really unexceptionable.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is precisely right. You cannot just say the non‐extinguishment principle applies because, in some circumstances, the common law effect does extinguish. We have those circumstances of freehold and extinguishment to the extent of inconsistency and for the duration of inconsistency. The clause basically reflects the common law. We want the non‐extinguishment principle to apply but we do not think the non‐extinguishment principle should apply in circumstances where the common law itself provides for extinguishment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —The difficulty with this is that the whole act was constructed on the premise that, in future, the only way in which native title could be extinguished was either by agreement or by compulsory acquisition—that is, that the act removes the general defeasibility of native title at common law whereby, as was said in Mabo, native title can be extinguished by the exercise of sovereignty in granting exclusive possession or interests that are inconsistent with the continued existence of native title.

SPEECH.PARA: When you compulsorily acquire something, you extinguish it. If you compulsorily acquire freehold title, the freehold title is removed from the person holding the freehold title. They are not paid compensation for the acquisition of their freehold title and then still hold the title. When someone compulsorily acquires title, the title is gone. You are paid compensation—end of story. The whole premise of the Native Title Act is that compulsory acquisition is the only mechanism, apart from agreement, by which native title can be extinguished in the future. We maintain that.

To introduce the circular argument, and the ludicrous situation, where you have a compulsory acquisition of native title but the native title stays there somehow—it is not extinguished—is an absolute legal nonsense. And there is the convoluted expression about the common law: that is the law; this seeks to change the law. The law is that, if a government acts using its compulsory acquisition powers to acquire title, it acquires the title, and that is the end of the title. That is exactly what happened at Crescent Head where the native title was effectively acquired and that was the end of the native title. That is the only way now—and forever—in which it can be extinguished. But now we are saying it is not necessarily extinguished. That is a legal nonsense.

TALK.START.PARA: —We could in fact be here on this point till one o'clock.
—I'm happy to stay.

—On this particular point to one o'clock—great. The short fact is that what we are on about here is reflecting the common law. I think Senator Minchin should acknowledge that. We are saying that the non‐extinguishment principle should apply. That is the starting point, but where extinguishment does apply at common law we save that.

—I understand that under the current act, when a crown to crown grant applies then the non‐extinguishment principle applies. Obviously, there will be times when it is decided that that land is no longer required for whatever purpose it was acquired. Therefore, it is quite reasonable to think that, although native title might have been in abeyance and there could be compensation for that, it is not unreasonable to suggest that if it is no longer required for the purpose for which it was acquired then native title should not be revived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —This totally and utterly contradicts the common law as stated by Chief Justice Brennan in Mabo where, at page 85, he talked about the ways in which native title can be extinguished. He said that the third category of ways in which it can be extinguished was:

SPEECH.PARA: laws and acts by which the Crown acquires a full beneficial ownership that extinguishes native title. That may occur by acquisition of native title by or under statute, in which case the question is simply whether the power of acquisition has been validly exercised.'
The common law is clear. What is being attempted here is actually by statute somehow to change the common law and, in so doing, create enormous legal uncertainty.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not right. I go back to Senator Harradine's point and the point that we seek to make, as well: what we are doing here is actually saving the common law by the proviso that follows after the word `acquisition' in the first line. That is the full intent of what we are doing. You cannot argue anything other than that. We are saying, `Apply the non‐extinguishment principle, but nothing in this act prevents any activity that is done in giving effect to the purpose of acquisition from extinguishing native title rights and interests, if such extinguishment would occur under the common law. It is pretty clear.
—May I also ask the minister just to clarify this? Under the current act, if a state government grants to another government, doesn't the non‐extinguishment principle currently apply?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Through you, Mr Temporary Chairman, to Senator Margetts: we are not talking about crown to crown grants here; we are talking about the compulsory acquisition of property by the government. Governments are the only bodies that can compulsorily acquire anybody's title. The effect of compulsory acquisition is to extinguish the title. As I say, that is what happens when freehold title is acquired. That is what Chief Justice Brennan, in the majority judgment in Mabo, said was the effect of a government exercising its powers under its compulsory acquisition legislation: when it acquires native title, it extinguishes it.

—The list of those things which would generate compulsory acquisition in cludes crown to crown grants. All I am suggesting is that there is already a category where this exists, and exists under law. So what is the problem?
—Sorry. Was that a question?
—Maybe you want to restate the question, Senator Margetts.

—I was saying that my understanding is that crown to crown grants are one of the bases upon which compulsory acquisition can take place; and, if it already can be done on a non‐extinguishment principle, what is the problem with what we are suggesting?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Crown to crown grants are not compulsory acquisitions. The crown in right of the Commonwealth can grant land to the crown in right of the state, or to itself within the state; or, within the Commonwealth sphere it can grant land to it.

SPEECH.PARA: We understand the common law to be that the grant of freehold, crown to crown, of valid land does extinguish native title. There was a provision in the current act that validated grants of that kind and, in a sense, changed the common law by providing this non‐extinguishment principle in relation to validated grants; but, for valid grants, the common law applies. We understand the common law to be that a grant of freehold, whether it be crown to crown or the crown to anybody else, extinguishes native title.

What we are talking about here are not grants but compulsory acquisitions by states or the Commonwealth exercising their powers under the compulsory acquisition legislation and the effect of that. It is clear from Mabo that compulsory acquisition of native title extinguishes the native title.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it best to put on the record the fact that the Mabo case did have an indication from Justice Brennan that you could not draw any necessary inference from a crown to crown transfer as to whether that would lead to a permanent extinguishment of native title. It is left open. It is left open in Wik, as well. That is essentially the point that we want to leave open here.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Minchin, we have actually expanded the time until 1 o'clock to try to get a few other things done. You can keep arguing on this one all night, and we are prepared to do it, but it is not going to make you very popular with your colleagues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to talk about the effect of compulsory acquisitions, not crown to crown grants. Senator Margetts introduced a completely different notion. This discussion is about compulsory acquisitions and their effect. We oppose your amendment because of the extraordinary legal uncertainty it will produce; it has nothing to do with crown to crown grants.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a very awkward position for this matter to be determined by me, who am not a lawyer. I would like to move that the clause be postponed so that I can get further advice on the matter. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the clause be postponed.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —That concludes sheet 17 for this evening. We move on to No. 18 on the running sheet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —Are we talking about confirmation of extinguishment?
—We are, yes.
—I have No. 7, but it is a long time between drinks, and it is rather inconsequential.
—It is a new one that has been drawn up, Senator Bolkus. Perhaps, if you use No. 18—

—Can I make a few introductory comments in respect of confirmation of extinguishment? Our view is that there is no need for it. Our view is in fact that, if you were being honest about what you are doing here, you would actually call it `extinguishment by false pretences'. What we are talking about here is going much broader and much wider than the common law, and doing so under some specious argument of `absolute certainty'. In criminal law, you would probably get put away for this.

SPEECH.PARA: The government says that people have assumed that such interests as freehold, all types of leases, public works, et cetera, all extinguish native title; but the Wik decision did show to some extent, in respect to some of these areas, that the law is unfair—and I do say `in respect to some of these areas'. There is no vagueness, no unclarity and no uncertainty in terms of what happens to people's backyards: they are safe.

The government will say that they need to make it clear that these interests extinguish native title; however, this has got to be seen as a poor description of the effect of the common law. What we are talking about here are the bucketfuls of extinguishment by division 2B and also by the schedule. In many ways, I think we will be remembered for this one, as well. This is one of the most discriminatory, unjust and, probably, loose part of this legislation. It is a blatant removal of rights from people of a certain race, without any justification. So‐called uncertainty is removed just by the mere act of removing the rights of one group of people. The only stated justification we have from the government for this confirmation is that they want to allow development and interest to be granted over land without having to consider native title at all.

What they are doing here is totally contrary to the spirit of Wik. They are rejecting the concept of coexistence and they are doing so in a way which really is unscientific. At the end of the day, Australian taxpayers will have to pay for both the uncertainty and the excessiveness of acquisition. We are talking about acquisition by division 2B and we are talking about, for instance, the schedule. If you look at the schedule, you will find that it is not a list of particular and specific leases but a list of categories of leases. In analysing that list of categories of leases, from time to time we found during the parliamentary committee work that some leases had been submitted that should not be there, and that some leases were in fact added to the list but should not have been there.

We are talking about rifle ranges, defence purposes, water tanks and so on extinguishing native title: if there was ever such a scheduled interest as the ones I have mentioned, even in the distant past, then native title is extinguished. That is bad enough in itself; but what the government then goes on to do—just in case they missed out on the shopping list from the states in terms of the categories of leases they wanted to put on—is give themselves a broad, unencumbered, undefined regulatory power to add further to the register of extinguishing lease categories.

That has to be a major concern in this place because, first, the government wants to give itself that power; second, that power is in no way defined; and, third, the impact of exercise of that uncontrollable regulatory power is something that will have direct impact on indigenous native title claimants. The other concern is that we are talking here not of actual leases that provide for exclusive possession but about generic groupings. The government did not spend the time to actually go through and define the exclusive possession leases. So we are concerned about that.

We are also concerned that in schedule 4 we have community purpose leases which extinguish native title. We are concerned about the curious arrangement that now pertains under this legislation in respect of stock routes. Stock routes were originally part of the definition of `public works', but this set of government changes will provide that stock routes are not public works except for the purposes of validation of past or future acts. In other words, what we will have is a situation where the old pre‐1975 stock routes probably do not extinguish native title. However, as `public works' under the new definition in this bill, they will extinguish native title when validated. This will leave a curious situation where 1975 to 1996 stock routes do extinguish native title.

We are concerned also that previous non‐exclusive possession acts are said to extinguish native title, and that includes pastoral leases which do not confer exclusive possession. We are also particularly concerned that, under clause 23E, states will be given similar power to confirm extinguishment if they have similar laws.

The ongoing concern that we have is that what is provided for here is a regime of permanent extinguishment, when the common law makes it clear that that particular aspect has not been determined. Permanent extinguishment is just unjustifiable in terms of the common law. We are adopting a position in this respect where our amendments are designed to remove the whole section dealing with extinguishment and to remove the definition of `extinguishment' which makes extinguishment permanent. There are also consequential amendments.

The government will raise some concerns with it. They will run the line of uncertainty and so on. But if you really want uncertainty in this regime of extinguishment, I say to you once again that this particular provision will finish up in the High Court within hours of it being approved by Executive Council. It will be open to challenge under the common law; it will be open to challenge under the races power. Once again, we are talking here of extinguishment of one race's rights without appropriately timed compensation.

Can I also say something else: if you want uncertainty, you basically poison the atmosphere; this particular unilateral, oppressive act will do just that. The just terms compensation provisions of the constitution are not satisfied. The government says that 53A provides for just terms value in a two‐step approach, but it does not even attempt to provide just terms in terms of the processes and contemporaneous—or otherwise—nature of the constitutional requirements.

The final point I make is that, under the government's amendments circulated this week—amendments we support—it has proposed to create in the future another statutory exception to the general rule that native title is extinguished and cannot ever be claimed when there has been a freehold title granted. It is a curious thing that the government is doing here, given the rhetoric of the last couple of weeks. But, for instance, where a claim is made under vacant crown land not currently covered by freehold estate or lease but where there has, in fact, been such a title then this situation will prevail. We are talking here about proposed new section 47B of government amendment No. 45.

Can I indicate that we will support all but one of Senator Harradine's amendments that he is moving. But in respect of one of them, we prefer ALP amendment No. 15 before Senator Harradine's amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling, Sen Grant

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I hold an interest, jointly with my wife, in a strata titled residence and a strata titled water boat berth in the Cullen Bay Marina Estate in Darwin. Accordingly, in the context of this debate, I make a personal declaration in respect of the amendments now being considered.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the government's amendments, I have no conflict of interest. However, under the Labor and Green amendments, there may be some question as to the current status of this land, given that it was leasehold after the Native Title Act commenced but has since converted to freehold. I understand there have been approximately 350 freehold titles created from development leases in the Northern Territory since 1 January 1994, and these amendments may similarly affect at least 350 of my constituents. There will undoubtedly be thousands more similar situations throughout Australia, particularly in developing cities and towns, and I certainly draw this to the attention of the Senate and my colleagues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Under this section—I would call it `legislative extinguishment'—we have further bucket loads of extinguishment. On 30 October 1996, a bipartisan resolution was carried unanimously in the Commonwealth parliament on a motion by the Prime Minister. The resolution stated:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House
(1) reaffirms its commitment to the right of all Australians to . . . be treated with equal respect regardless of race, colour, creed or origin.

Now the government wishes to violate this historical commitment by extinguishment of indigenous people's common law property right. The government's proposed division 2B goes far beyond the common law with regard to which land tenures extinguish native title and is malicious in both intent and effect. The type of land tenures which extinguish native title under this division of the bill are contained in section 23B and the associated schedule 4 of the bill, and what good reading it makes. Presumably such acts could date back as far as 1788.

They include community purposes leases, crown to crown grants and thousands of tenures under schedule 4 on which native title may exist. But with just one vote in this chamber, it may be extinguished forever. I repeat that: extinguished forever. If division 2B is supported, it will go down as the most shameful action in this parliament's history.

The government has been busy whipping up fear in the community that this provision is necessary to ensure that private freehold land cannot be subject to native title. We know that this is unnecessary. This division explains why the government has been busy making outrageous comments about private freehold land being subject to native title; that is, because the government wants to cloud its attempt in this division to go far beyond the common law and attempt to deliberately deceive both the public and senators in this chamber. This division is entitled `Confirmation of past extinguishment of native title' when what it actually entails is nothing like confirmation; rather it represents a massive overreach to extinguish native title on public lands where native title may and should exist.

Community purpose leases which are to extinguish native title by virtue of this section may not, in common law, give exclusive possession and, following the Wik decision, may allow for native title to coexist. In addition, this category of extinguishing tenures in the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 was not foreshadowed in the 10‐point plan. Of particular concern to those like myself from Western Australia is that grants from one government to another, for example, from state government to the Commonwealth or from state government to a statutory authority, will extinguish native title by virtue of this provision, even though the use of the land may be consistent with coexistence of native title. At the very least, the non‐extinguishment principle should apply to such grants.

It is important for those in this chamber to realise that crown to crown grants are expressly excluded from extinguishing native title in the current act, yet the actions of this government, if supported, will extinguish native title on this government controlled land forever.

Division 2B will extinguish native title on hundreds of crown to crown grants carried out in Western Australia over the past three years. A classic example of the potential injustice of this provision is in relation to the Wawarra native title claim in far north Western Australia. A very large part of this native title area is a military training area which was created by a crown to crown grant. The area is an extensive area of bushland used only occasionally by the military, and there is a strong existing attachment to the land by the traditional owners. Under the government's provisions, native title will be extinguished in this area forever. How can this be considered fair? How can the Senate consider the issue of native title with any shred of decency and allow such a gross injustice to take place?

Much has been written about the government's infamous schedule 4 list of leases and the many other interests which will be extinguished by operation of division 2B. This list has been compiled following recommendations from the state and territories in line with their understanding of whether the common law confers exclusive possession and therefore extinguishes native title.

We all know how wrong state governments—and, in particular, the Western Australian government—can be in their interpretation of the common law with regard to native title. The Court government, as I have mentioned before, wasted millions of dollars on ludicrous High Court challenges, challenging the Native Title Act 1993. Since then it has lost two other High Court cases related to native title.

Before Senator Minchin jumps to his feet to invoke his mantra that the Commonwealth carefully vetted all the land tenures in this schedule, let me also say that we all know that the Western Australian state government has played a big role in drafting this bill, a fact that Richard Court has confirmed on a number of occasions. Even the senators on the other side of the chamber will admit that the Premier of Western Australia has done, and will do, everything in his power to destroy the native title process. By contrast, indigenous Australians were not party to any of the discussions relating to the compilation of the schedule and, despite numerous requests for information as to the process and the outcome, they did not even see the list of so‐called schedule interests until 17 August when they were asked for comments in a matter of days.

I would like to discuss the schedule in a little more depth and, in particular, its effect on Western Australia. The government have listed a whole lot of lease categories with no released idea of the basis upon which these decisions were made. To quote from the National Indigenous Working Group submission to the parliamentary committee on native title:

The exercise undertaken resembles that of a client seeking advice from a lawyer as to his or her obligations as a lessee under a lease. No responsible and competent lawyer would consider giving such advice without having a copy of the document. In a similar vein, no assurance as to the legal effect of the interests listed in the schedule should be treated as having any claim to be a responsible expression of legal opinion.

One wonders what those who criticise the High Court after the judgment in the Wik case would have said if they had learnt that the court had handed down its judgment without bothering to obtain copies of the relevant leases.

Let us look at some of the land tenures listed in the schedule in Western Australia. Take, for example, non‐pastoral leasehold areas. Leasehold in Western Australia, other than pastoral tenures, comprises approximately 72,500 square kilometres, an area larger than Tasmania. Almost all such leases have been included in the schedule, notwithstanding that some include reservation clauses and may not grant exclusive possession.

Then there are tillage leases issued under the land regulations of 1851. These leases were issued for a term of eight years and, apparently, included broad reservations including full right to the Aboriginal natives to enter on any such part of the said premises to `seek subsistence therefrom to their accustomed manner'. Nevertheless, the schedule deems that these leases extinguish native title.

Let us look at leases ancillary to mining tenements. Both under the Native Title Act and the bill, the non‐extinguishment principle applies to mining tenements. Nevertheless, the schedule includes a number of leases which are ancillary to mining. For example, item 34(10) includes leases for the purposes of a plant for the treatment of mineral bearing earth and the treatment of ore. Items 34(2) and 34(12) refer to section 1528 of the Land Act 1898 and section 1168 of the Land Act 1933, which provide for the lease of areas for the purpose of general engineering works. Items 34(3) and 34(13) dealing with a large number of purposes gazetted for special leases under section 152 of the Land Act of 1898 and section 168 of the Land Act of 1933 may apply to leases associated with the mining industry. For example, item 34(13) refers to residence and the storage of mining equipment. Item 36 states that almost all leases issued pursuant to state development acts will be associated with mining in some manner.

The listing of these items in the schedule is inconsistent with the principle that non‐extinguishment principles apply to mining matters. With respect to leases granted pursuant to state development agreements, in Western Australia large‐scale mining projects are often supported by specific legislation which specifies an agreement reached between the state and the developer. These agreements authorise the grant of leases for a range of purposes associated with mining. The schedule specifies that all such leases extinguish native title, apparently without specific consideration of individual leases granted under the scheme. For example, clause 9 of the Hamersley Range iron ore agreement of 1963 enables the grant of leases, rights, mining tenements, easements, reserves and licences. The schedule ensures that native title is extinguished by all such leases without any examination as to whether exclusive possession was granted.

BREAK.PARA: We have crown to crown grants for defence purposes. As in the Northern Territory, the Commonwealth owns large areas of land in Western Australia for defence purposes. This includes a large vacant military training area north of Derby in the Kimberley region. Indigenous people retain a strong traditional connection to this land. The bill ensures that native title rights are extinguished.

Community purpose leases may not grant exclusive possession and on Wik principles may allow native title to coexist. The definition of a community purpose lease is extremely wide, covering leases whose primary purpose is for community, religious, education, charitable and sporting purposes. My particular favourite amongst the list is `reserve for the Royal Antediluvian Order of Buffalos'.

I think this is a disgraceful way for governments to be putting together something so important regarding the impacts of legislative extinguishment of native title. There is no indication of how they have reached it or on what basis. Quite frankly, so many of these leases, from a commonsense point of view, should not be involved with extinguishment of native title. I would like an explanation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —The most extraordinary decision by the ALP in this whole issue and debate is their decision not to confirm extinguishment by grants of exclusive possession and to leave the enormous uncertainty that flows from such a decision, although I note that the ALP has now decided that, despite the rhetoric we have just heard from Senator Bolkus, they do think it is a good idea to confirm the extinguishment of native title on freehold land. If I am not to read this opposition amendment, which has been circulated in your name, as a furphy, I take it now to be the case that you do agree that we should legislatively extinguish native title on freehold land.

SPEECH.PARA: Nevertheless, these provisions confirm that on the 13 per cent of Australia that is freehold land and on the 7.7 per cent of Australia that is under exclusive tenure, under exclusive lease, extinguishment has occurred. We are confirming that 79 per cent of Australia is open to native title claim and in the other 21 per cent, where grants of exclusive possession have occurred, native title has been extinguished.

There is a point at which we have to end the uncertainty. This is that point. We have just had the area of Australia over which native title may have survived doubled by the Wik decision. Now it is being suggested that we should leave the other 21 per cent completely open and uncertain as to what the real legal situation is.

I remind you in relation to this whole area that there is not one pastoral lease on the schedule of exclusive tenures. With respect to the 42 per cent of Australia that is pastoral lease land—including the western division of New South Wales where, as you know, the farmers argued passionately that their leases were grants of exclusive possession—we did not put them on the schedule; there is not one pastoral lease.

It is now being put to us that native title may have survived on at least the 7.7 per cent covered by exclusive agricultural leases, residential leases and commercial leases. We take it from this amendment that you are accepting that on the 13 per cent of Australia where there is freehold land we should confirm extinguishment there and end the uncertainty, but on the 7.7 per cent of Australia that is covered under the schedule and is land covered by exclusive leases, you are leaving the whole thing up in the air.

Either native title has been extinguished there and you are prepared to agree that we should confirm that by legislation or you are saying—which is presumably what you are saying—that native title may have survived on all those leases, including the agricultural leases. That is an extraordinary situation to put all those lessees in. You are now saying that they could well have native title claims made over them, they could well all be dragged into court to defend their leases against native title claims.

You are leaving the act in a situation where there is no future act regime to govern future activity on land on which you are now saying to us that native title may have survived, because that is what is now required of you. If that is the Labor Party's position, you are now required, as a responsible party in the parliament, to put forward a future act regime to govern future activity on all those leases because you think native title may have survived on them. Therefore, you are saying the Native Title Act does apply on all that land, yet the Native Title Act now, even under all our amendments, is silent on what should govern future activity on all that area. You are creating another legal nightmare, another area of extraordinary legal uncertainty, by your actions in not accepting this confirmation regime.

It seems to us perfectly sensible and reasonable to confirm what is the law—that is, where grants of exclusive possession occur, native title is extinguished; otherwise you find the legal quagmire I just described. With regard to the issue of permanency, may I remind you what Gareth Evans said in 1993:
Once extinguished, always extinguished. It doesn't come back into life . . .
Extinguishment means extinguishment.
The granting of the lease would achieve an extinguishment if there was a subsequent resumption or reclamation of part or all of that lease.
It would not help the native titleholders. Their interests would have been extinguished by the initial step.
As to the state of the law, let me read what Chief Justice Brennan said on this matter in the Wik decision:

Of course native title is not an estate and to treat native title as falling into possession on the determination of a prior estate is to create problems of title not easy to resolve. If the holders of native title were recognised as the owners of an estate in remainder in the land, could the priority right to a selection enjoyed by a lessee be exercised and would the holders of native title have become liable to pay for the improvements to the land effected during the expired lease? To what extent was the discretion to enforce a forfeiture against a lessee affected by this proposed subsistence of native title in the land? In the unusual event of the determination of estate in fee‐simple, would the land revert to the Crown or would it be taken by the holders of native title? These questions indicate some of the problems that arise once the fundamental doctrines that govern the title to land granted by the Crown under the 1910 act are departed from. In my opinion, the common law could not recognise native title once the Crown alienated a freehold or leasehold estate under the act. Consequently, the common law is powerless to recognise native title as reviving after the determination of a pastoral lease issued under the 1910 act.

He was stating quite clearly, as the Chief Justice, the lead judge in Mabo, the extraordinary dangers and legal uncertainty that flow from any notion that extinguishment is not permanent. The High Court has not ruled that extinguishment is not permanent. We take the common law to be as Chief Justice Brennan has stated it, and we draw to your attention the legal consequences of that not being the case, as he has described there; and as your former leader in this chamber said, `Extinguishment means extinguishment.'

The court would not have used the term `extinguishment' if it did not mean that. Extinguishment means to make extinct. If they meant suppression, suspension or something else, they would have said so. The court case says `extinguishment' and extinguishment can mean only one thing. The legal dangers and uncertainty that flow from any notion of revival are very dangerous for the legal system of this country and for property law in this country. As I say, Chief Justice Brennan has summarised it in full.

We believe this is one of the most important parts of this bill. It is essential that we end the uncertainty flowing from the question of whether native title may or may not have survived on these things. We say the common law is clear—that where grants of exclusive possession have occurred, native title is extinguished, but we think it is the responsibility of this parliament to confirm that in this legislation. We call on the ALP to support this in full.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to say a few things in response to that. Senator Minchin cannot help himself. If he wants a scare campaign, he will start it and he will keep coming back to it. When it comes to scare campaigns, Senator Minchin, you are a recidivist. I am sure Australians will get used to that over the next few months if you have your way. We should not subject this country to a scare campaign. We should not be subjecting it to the degree of uncertainty that you are trying to scare people into believing that they have.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me quote from the Law Council of Australia. They put out an extraordinary statement towards the end of last week. They called for an end to scaremongering in the Wik debate. Maybe, Senator Minchin, you should listen to them. They said:
At a time of such important debate in Australian society, a move to emotive, divisive, irrational argument is developing rather than substantial logical negotiation.
They go on say:

We have not yet had any case which saw a native title claim pitted against an ordinary freehold title such as a suburban home. It is unlikely we will ever have such a case. It will be surprising to find any lawyer who is knowledgeable in the area who could sensibly advise that such a claim would succeed on the basis of the Mabo and Wik judgments.
So to suggest that freehold title could be at risk from native title claims because it has not yet been decided in a case raising just that issue is starting at shadows.

TALK.START.PARA: —Save the taxpayers' money, Nick.
—Order! Senator O'Chee!

—That quote comes from the Law Council of Australia and is something that you ought to keep in mind as you embark upon an unprincipled, unethical and racist scare campaign throughout the Australia community. Senator Minchin, you ought to be ashamed of yourself for putting up this sort of proposal.

—Madam Temporary Chairman, I raise a point of order. That is an inflammatory remark. This debate has been carried on with a certain amount of decorum. We have about 10 minutes to go, and I ask Senator Bolkus to desist and calm down.

—Order! Senator Crane!

—We agreed to sit for another hour tonight so we can actually get some business done. But we have had this act of provocation which cannot be allowed to go through to the keeper unchallenged, and then we had this rabble on the back bench coming in here to act as a cheer squad. Senator Evans is right: you are embarking upon a very dangerous game here in terms of Australian society. You are drying the grassland for Pauline Hanson to live off, and you and your mob will suffer first.
—Order! Senator Bolkus, address the chair please.

—But the people who will suffer most are the Australian community. We should not be subjecting the Australian community to a baseless campaign based on race. There is no need for that. If one looked at the amount of opposition amendments going through in this process, one would be lucky to get to 10 per cent. Ninety‐five per cent of yours are going through in this process.

SPEECH.PARA: Those stakeholders who are barracking from the fringes for you to proceed with this legislation could never have dreamed of the result they are getting from this Senate. Nothing can justify you proceeding on a race based campaign in respect of this bill. Nothing can justify the assertions made by Senator Minchin in respect of people's backyards.

Senator Minchin, confront the truth. You said here in a very slippery way that the High Court has not determined that the extinguishment is not permanent. What the High Court has done is left open that question of permanent extinguishment. It is not just me saying that; your Attorney‐General (Mr Williams) is saying that. The Attorney‐General's Department is saying that.

What you are doing here is going further than the common law. You are going further than Wik. Basically you are acquiring people's property in a racist, discriminatory manner. Do you know who else says that? It is not just the opposition who says that. Senator Minchin, we do not need to embark upon an inflammatory scare campaign on this issue. We have some legitimate concerns and those concerns will finish up in the High Court within hours of this legislation being approved by the Executive Council. You can come in here later next year and explain to us, and the rest of the world, why this pernicious legislation has not given us the certainty that stakeholders want of it.

I say to you, cool off for a bit. Acknowledge what you have got through this process. Have a constructive debate for the rest of this process, as we embark upon the debate later tonight and tomorrow.
