I could go on for the next 10 minutes or so. I will not, because I would like to actually see some of these proposals put to a vote this evening.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder if the minister could tell us the location of the clubhouse for the Grand Lodge of the Royal Antediluvian Order of Buffaloes that he wants to protect through this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assist ing the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —My advice is that it is a clubhouse in Queensland. It is a grant of exclusive possession. There is a club on it and there are Australians who belong to such an order. They are entitled to the protection of the law, based on the fact that that was a grant of exclusive possession, along with every other lease that is included in this.

SPEECH.PARA: We went to enormous lengths to very conservatively put together this list on the basis that it contains only those leases which are grants of exclusive possession. It does not include one pastoral lease. We are talking about only 7.7 per cent of Australia that is covered by these leases. We think it is very carefully checked. We did not accept the proposition that we put in Western Division leases, to the great aggravation of the New South Wales farmers, who believe very strongly that their leases are grants of exclusive possession. I think that is the test of the merit of this list. We are talking about a small proportion of Australia.

If you are saying that native title may have survived on any one or all of those, there are 60,000 separate leases here. If you are saying every one of those is subject to native title claim and every one of those must seek somehow to comply with the Native Title Act, for fear that anything they do would be illegal because they have not complied with the Native Title Act, you are going to put us right back where we started with Wik.

This was the whole thing. You went out of your way to say, `Pastoral leases are extinguished; you can do what you like; everything is fine.' Now we have this mess of 26,000 leases that were issued in relation to pastoral leases on the understanding of what the law was. We have an invalidity problem that we are trying to resolve. You will end up in exactly the same situation.

The poor people with their clubhouse—whatever they are called—will not know whether they can build a barbecue outside if they want to do so. Is it possible under the Native Title Act? They will have to go to their lawyers and ask their lawyers whether, under the Native Title Act, they can do this. They have been told by you that the native title may have survived there. That means the Native Title Act must be taken account of and you can only do it validly and safely if you comply with the Native Title Act. There may be no way to do it under the Native Title Act.

If you are going to go down this path, you have to responsibly provide a whole regime for future acts on all those leases, including the grand order of whatever in relation to their clubhouse. That is the dilemma you face.If you are going to go down this path and say, `We mustn't do it because native title may have survived'—and we are talking on the basis that we know it may have survived on 79 per cent, but you are saying it may have survived on the rest as well—where is your future act regime to ensure that these people are not put in the position that you put pastoral lessees in? You really have a big responsibility here and you have to meet it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —The point I made earlier was that Senator Minchin cannot have it both ways. He claims that all he is doing here is confirming extinguishment where extinguishment has happened under the common law. He goes on to say that we need to give certainty where there may not be. The other thing that is important is that we are actually talking about historic leases as well. The government's initial proposal here was to cover historic leases—leases that may have been issued a hundred years ago under law lease categories, not specific leases. The leases may never have been taken up. In many cases the leases have expired. There is no‐one there; the land becomes vacant crown land. What does Senator Minchin say in that respect? He says, `Despite the fact that that might have happened, native title can still be extinguished and is extinguished.'

SPEECH.PARA: You are basically driftnet fishing with this particular proposal. You are going further than the common law, and you know it. That is precisely why you are running these lines to try to scare people. You are running further than the common law. You are trying to pick up anything that might have happened over the last hundred years or so. You are picking up the ghost leases—the historic leases. As a consequence, you might be concerned about club owners, and so are we, but we are also concerned about indigenous Australians whose rights might be unfairly taken away from them.

Do you know who else is concerned about that? Your Chief General Counsel, Mr Burmester. That is exactly why he identified this as being one of the important areas that breached the Racial Discrimination Act and the International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination. It is exactly why he mentioned it there, and this will be one of the first proposals that will be up for grabs in the High Court under the races power.

As I said, you cannot have it both ways. I thank my colleagues here for the note that has really distracted me from what I was saying. Senator Minchin, you cannot have it both ways. What you are trying to do is to scare people. You know very well that, where native title has been extinguished, you go further than that. In terms of uncertainty, the people who are actually stimulating uncertainty in this community—and I have got to say that it is a case of shooting yourselves in the foot—are the people out there in rural Australia, telling pastoralists that there is a degree of uncertainty as to their interests in land.

BREAK.PARA: So you are trying to have it both ways: you are walking both sides of the street; and you are working both sides of the street. TALK.START.PARA: —I thought it was important that I put the Democrats' position on this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALK.START.PARA: —All we have at the moment, Senator Margetts, is the common law which we understand to provide that grants of exclusive possession extinguish native title. The problem with the Wik judgment is that what it said was, basically, you have got to go through every lease and work out whether it is a grant of exclusive possession—meaning potentially. While it appears clear on the face of it that it is a grant of exclusive possession, we take it to be, therefore, extinguishing, and that is our understanding of the common law. Community purpose leases are grants of exclusive possession and therefore extinguish native title, so we have assembled this list on a very conservative basis of putting on it those leases that clearly are grants of exclusive possession as assessed by legal teams.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been legally assessed, not assessed in any other respect. Every class of lease has been assessed on the basis of whether it constitutes a grant of exclusive possession. If it is clear that it does, it has been put on the schedule. If there is any doubt, it is not included.
